If either the blooms armies or the sard are defeated, the bloom itself collapses, leaving behind a three-hundred-foot-diameter scar of barren sand.

Endure Bloom Siege

  • Downtime

If the bloom was active after the previous sundown, the kingdoms capital must Endure the Bloom Siege.

If the PCs defeated the bloom since the last Endure Bloom Siege activity (either by slaying the rampaging sard or by defeating the bloom army), the result of this Endure Bloom Siege activity is improved one degree of successthis represents the fact that the invaders had less than a full day to do harm.

You can Endure Bloom Siege with a Defense check or a Magic check. Regardless of the kingdom skill chosen, this is a DC 34 check on the first day. The DC increases by 2 every day thereafter until the bloom is defeated or the capital is completely destroyed.

  • Critical Success The capital endures the bloom siege with no damage, but the citizens are still worried. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Success The citys defenses hold back much of the assault, but damage still occurs. Gain 1 Decay and either destroy one wall or place Rubble into one lot of your choice in the capitals Urban Grid. If you have no empty lots, reduce one structure in the city to Rubble. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The citys defenses strain and threaten to collapse! As success, but place Rubble into three lots of the PCs choice in the capitals Urban Grid. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4]].

  • Critical Failure The citys defenses are overrun! As failure, but gain 2 Decay, place Rubble into six lots of the PCs choice in the capitals Urban Grid, and increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4+2]].

Ending the Bloom

The bloom sards first attack on the region is against an outlying farm, crossroads, or other location of your choice in the hex in which the capital is located. Its first attack occurs at noon on day 26, and it continues to rampage through the region as long as this bloom persists. These attacks panic the populace, and at noon every day after its first attack, until it is defeated or this bloom is finally ended, the kingdom gains 1 Unrest.

  • @UUID[Actor.eD1kydftMIp4CL2K]{Bloom Sard}

Defeating the Sard

Severe 17

If the PCs opt to fight the sard, they track it through the surrounding region automatically. Unless they use magic like teleportation to cut down their travel time, though, itll take the PCs [[/r 1d8]] hours to navigate the sards trail of destruction through the hinterlands to finally catch up to it; succeeding at a @Check[type:survival|dc:30] check reduces this to only 1 hour. Once confronted, the sard focuses its wrath on the PCs, but if it is reduced to fewer than 50 Hit Points it attempts to flee on its turn. If the sard escapes, it returns to the bloom, recovers, and continues its rampage the next day. Persistent PCs might be able to track it down in its lair in the bloom at your discretion, but only if the sard is slain does the bloom end.

If the PCs defeat the bloom by slaying the sard, the four First World armies become stranded in the region. They no longer make attacks on the capital, but they move through the kingdom and continue to be a nuisance until they are defeated, or until the PCs defeat Nyrissa at the end of this chapter, in which case these stranded armies disperse completely.

Armies

  • @UUID[Actor.2nCGeGTO7HQjEETs]{First World Armies (4)}

Defeating the First World Armies

This army is composed of an eclectic mix of fey, beasts, and plantsa supernatural mob of monsters with a wide range of options in battle.

Battlefield: All four of the First World armies attack the PCs capital one hour before sundown on Day 26. The capitals defenders can potentially have the advantage in the battle if there are structures that can be used to fortify armies with ranged attacks. At your option, if the PCs built their capital in a region with natural defenses (such as swamps or rugged mountains), then the First World armies might be penalized by difficult terrain as well.

If the PCs choose not to risk defenders against the army, or if there simply arent any armies in the city, and the PCs havent broken the morale of the armies by slaying the bloom sard, then the army surges through the capital and the conflict is an automatic defeat for the PCs. Otherwise, the battle plays out as a normal War encountersee @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD]{Appendix 3} for Warfare rules.

At your option, the PCs could confront the First World armies in the bloom itself, but doing so should be a much more dangerous fight, with difficult terrain combining with the dim light caused by the strange gloomy haze in the regionand neither of these battlefield terrain features impacts the First World army. Worse, the terrain in the bloom works against invaders, making all of the PC armies in the bloom @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.kingmaker-features.Item.oVhkdym3D6TiTbrN]{Mired 2} when a battle begins.

If the PCs win the battle, when you roll to @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD.JournalEntryPage.Sz7W36dIfOpzuRth]{Determine Victory}, on a success or better, the enemy is destroyed and the bloom ends. On a failure or worse, the First World forces retreat, but the bloom doesnt endthe army takes [[/r 1d3]] days to recover and recruit more monsters from the First World and then attacks once again with its recovered and rebuilt armies. In the meantime, the capital must spend those days continuing to Endure the Bloom Siege (unless the PCs end the bloom by defeating the sard).

If the PCs end the bloom by defeating the army, the bloom sard is stranded on the Material Plane. It becomes a weakened sard (an 18th-level creature) instead and staggers off into the wilds. At your option, the sard (still quite powerful even weakened) can continue to be a danger until the PCs defeat it, but its defeat at this point is not needed to end the bloom.

If the PCs lose the battle, you should @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD.JournalEntryPage.Sz7W36dIfOpzuRth]{Determine Defeat} normally. On a success or better, the First World army retreats back to the bloom but attacks again the next day an hour before sundown. On a failure or worse, the army occupies the capital. From this point on, starting immediately after this failed battle at sunset, each time the kingdom has to Endure the Bloom Siege, they automatically get a critical failure. Once the capital is destroyed, the armies move on to strike at other settlements until the bloom is destroyed.

@UUID[Item.2OZvR3q1KRX0PR6a]{Bloom Trophies}: Handfuls of sand taken from the scar left by the blooms passing, linked to the High Folly (@UUID[.C8iJTL8Fl1Vf7OxB]{area J}).

K16. Cellar.name: K16. Cellar
K16. Cellar.text:
This earthen-floored cellar contains all manner of mundane supplies such as firewood, food, tools, lumber, and a surprising number of gourds drying on twine hanging from the rafters.

The cellar is split into three rooms, with the farthest from the ladder having been converted into a bedroom.

@UUID[Actor.SVUjDSZHYmwbQgnq]{The Knurly Witch}Low 19

This chamber is the home-away-from-home for the Knurly Witch when she visits the Houseshe chose this room out of all those offered her by Nyrissa because she likes the ambiance. If the Knurly Witch fled a previous encounter with the PCs, she can be found here nursing her wounds and her pride. If confronted here, she fights to the death.

Researching Thousandbreaths.name: Researching Thousandbreaths
Researching Thousandbreaths.text:
Library 16

Recalled Knowledge A PC attempts to recall what they have learned over the campaign about the topica single PC cannot attempt any of the following Research checks more than once, but each of these attempts takes only a single action to Research;

Maximum RP 4

Research Checks @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:33|traits:action:research], @Check[type:nature|dc:35|traits:action:research], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:research]

Interviews The PC interviews a knowledgeable NPC (such as Evindra or Limm) on the topic (each of these checks takes 2 hours to Research);

Maximum RP 8

Research Checks @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:33|traits:action:research], @Check[type:intimidation|dc:37|traits:action:research] (with a critical failure annoying the NPC enough that they refuse to provide more information)

Library Research The PC spends 8 hours researching the topic in a Library or similar structure (either one theyve built in one of their settlements, or one located in an allied city such as Restov);

Maximum RP 10

Research Checks @Check[type:library-lore|dc:33|traits:action:research], @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:33|traits:action:research], @Check[type:nature|dc:35|traits:action:research], @Check[type:occultism|dc:37|traits:action:research], @Check[type:religion|dc:37|traits:action:research], @Check[type:perception|dc:37|traits:action:research]

2 Research Points The source of the blooms and fey incursion is certainly from the First World.

4 Research Points The specific source of the blooms within the First World is a realm known as Thousandbreaths, which is ruled by a nymph queen named Nyrissa.

6 Research Points Thousandbreaths earned its name in eons past when Nyrissa earned the pledge of a thousand powerful fey creatures who served hertheir breaths are what helped Nyrissa stabilize and claim this reach of the First World as her own domain. Visitors are not often welcome to Thousandbreaths, and most uninvited guests never escape the realm. When Thousandbreaths draws near to the Material Plane, its influence infuses a region with whispering sounds and abundant overgrowth.

8 Research Points Thousandbreaths drew near to Golarion 20 years ago, linking to a woodland known then as the Branthlend Forest. The other realms influence has resulted in this woodlands name changing to Thousand Voices. Thousandbreaths itself has touched upon other worlds in the pastthe Thousand Voices forest is but the most recent.

10 Research Points While visitors are rare to Thousandbreaths, one notable instance is said to be the painter Karn Zuddiger, who described his visit to the domain in the guise of a childrens picture book called Zuddigers Picnic. The book gained notoriety in part due to Karns murderous killing spree only a month after the books publication some 20 years ago. As a result of Karns violent outburst, most copies of Zuddigers Picnic were destroyed. If the PCs havent secured their own copy of Zuddigers Picnic by this point, this check also reveals that a local aristocrat named @UUID[.8AdKadlNNj4F3xTa]{Belinda Houten} is said to own a copy of this rare book.

12 Research Points Thousandbreaths is a heavily forested realm. Travel through the woodlands without taking advantage of its paths or rivers is exceptionally dangerous. Nyrissa, the ruler of the realm, is also known in some tales as the Queen of Forgotten Time, the Counts Last Mistress, or the Heartless Queen.

14 Research Points There are ten glades in Thousandbreathsnine lesser glades each ruled by one of Nyrissas favored minions, and a prime glade in which Nyrissas home, the House at the Edge of Time, stands. When Thousandbreaths links to the Material Plane, it manifests a worn-down, ruined duplicate of the House at the Edge of Time in that worlda ruin known to explorers of Thousand Voices as the @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]{Castle of Knives}.

16 Research Points Little is known of how Thousandbreaths affects those who visit it, but what has been deduced includes the fact that it is always twilight in Thousandbreaths, that travel off the path through the woods quickly grows dangerous as the thorny undergrowth resists passage, and that distance and time are strangely inconsistentthose who travel to Thousandbreaths and then return to Golarion find that much less time has passed than they expected.

18 Research Points The nine lesser glades not only provide a route to Nyrissas home, but also function as the realms foundation. Each glade is tethered to a powerful entity so full of life that its presence acts as an anchor, and without these nine entities, the glades of Thousandbreaths would be uprooted. This would have a calamitous effect on the realm, and while it would weaken Nyrissas defenses, it alone would not defeat her.

K4. Lower Hall.text:
The polished marble floor of this otherwise empty chamber depicts a carving of the sun being devoured by a great dragon. The walls are painted to resemble a twilit forest with strange, dark shapes hiding amid the trees.

@UUID[Actor.m8kwG6NskYDlBSCy]{Ankou Assassins (4)}

Moderate 19

The carving on the floor is harmless, but the dark shapes that seem to lurk amid the trees on the walls are not. These are powerful ankou assassins, guardians placed here by Nyrissa, eager to attack intruders and feel hot blood run over their dark talons. What Nyrissa doesnt realize is that these ankous are in fact also spies for the Lantern King; if she manages to capture the Stolen Lands or reclaim Briar, the ankous abandon this area and return to their patrons side to report. Otherwise, theyll slip out of hiding among the shadows on the walls to attack as soon as anyone notices that theyre not merely decorations, or as soon as someone attempts to leave the room.

If an ankou assassin is reduced to fewer than 50 HP, it flees the House and does not return.
K4. Lower Hall.name: K4. Lower Hall

L3. Guest Rooms.text: This wing of the House contains four large guest rooms. None of these chambers have been used in a long time, but each seems brand new and ready to receive guests. Temporal ripples and phantoms sometimes flit around the place, echoes of long-departed guests. The PCs may well observe echoes of their own passage through these roomsharmless but nonetheless disconcerting to see.
L3. Guest Rooms.name: L3. Guest Rooms

K15. Servants Wing.text:
This wing of the House serves as workrooms for the servants. If the PCs enter this wing, theyll quickly attract the anger of the wings guardians.

Area K15a was used for quick naps and relaxation. Area K15b, once used to arrange meals in pleasing presentations, is filled with rubble (this room is difficult terrain). Area K15c was used to prepare flower garlands, while area K15d was a parlor for discussing the days duties. Area K15e was the wings kitchen, while area K15f was used to store supplies. The servants themselves dined in area K15g, stored food and drink in area K15h, and kept preserved herbs and spices in area K15ithis last room also contains a trap door that opens at a touch (like the other doors in the complex) to reveal a ladder leading down to area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc]{K16}.

@UUID[Actor.gXbDaY9ci2u22ptT]{Ghostly Guards (12)}

Severe 19

No living servants remain here, but the wing is far from unoccupied. A group of a dozen ghostly guards can be found here, pantomiming various duties in the rooms. Areas K15cK15e and K15h are each occupied by two ghosts. A group of three ghosts mime eating a meal in area K15g, while the final ghost apes the cataloging of herbs and spices in K15i.

As soon as any of these ghosts notice the PCs, they use their Frightful Moans to raise the alarm. This causes all the other ghosts in this wing to join the fight as soon as possible. If the Knurly Witch has retreated to area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc]{K16}, she hears these howls and clambers up the ladder to join the fight as well. She makes good use of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wdA52JJnsuQWeyqz]{harm} to keep the ghosts healed.
K15. Servants Wing.name: K15. Servants Wing

D. The Nightmare Spire.text:
A mile-wide clearing in the endless forest opens under the twilight sky to make way for a field of jagged hills and thorny plains. A single stone spire rises a mile into the sky.

While the stone spire seems to be unnaturally tall, this is actually a strange visual distortion that affects creatures within 100 feet of the groundthe spires peak is in fact only 200 feet high.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.x9UldAAwoPhNLPU3]{Raven feathers from a nightmare}, linked to the @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB]{Nights of Dread} bloom.

@UUID[Actor.L3q7yQ0jKqH2IWy7]{Nightmare Rook}

Moderate 18

Perched atop the needle-like spire is what appears to be an enormous crow. This is one of the most notorious of Thousandbreaths denizens: the Nightmare Rook. This monstrous guardian of the skies above Thousandbreaths can visit the dreaming minds of outlanders who are foolish enough to sleep in Nyrissas realm, inflicting horrific living nightmares upon them. Yet it also serves as an expedient way to travel for many of the regions creatures, for the Nightmare Rook is one of two creatures (the other being Nyrissa herself) that can fly above the trees of this realm.

The Nightmare Rook carries passengers only at Nyrissas direct request or as a result of magical control. It has excellent vision, and unless the PCs take pains to be stealthy as they enter this glade, the immense bird sees them and turns to face them as they approach. If they move more than a hundred feet into the clearing, it shrieks, spreads its wings, and swoops to attack.

The Nightmare Rooks primary tactic is to split up the party by Snatching them and then flying to a different glade to drop them into the peril therein (it takes the Rook [[/r 2d6]] turns to reach another glade by flight, but it always takes it just one to return to its spire, regardless of how long it took to reach the other glade). The Rook is particularly fond of dropping victims into the Mire (@UUID[.xWZqVDCul4YpCaxc]{area G}) or the Fruiting Orchard (@UUID[.1pH3Z4bzZ12uCY78]{area E}). Thousandbreaths prevents creatures from being dropped into the woods themselves; a character whos dropped anywhere other than a glade falls [[/r 2d1010]] feet but finds themselves somehow landing at the same spot they were Snatched up from. The Rook returns to this glade as long as PCs remain within to repeat this process until it is reduced to fewer than 250 HP, at which time its frustration takes over and it lands to finish the fight with its spells and melee Strikes. It saves alter reality to duplicate a spell needed to remove a debilitating effect on itself as needed. If reduced to 90 or fewer HP, the Nightmare Rook calls for surrender and promises to fly the PCs to any glade they wish if they spare its life. Of course, this is a lie, as any PC who sees through its deception can tell. Any PCs who take the Rook up on this offer are brought to the Mire or the Fruiting Orchard (equal chances of either), whereupon it Bucks to dislodge its riders into the glade below before returning to its perch here to recover from the fight.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB]{Nights of Dread} bloom (page 432) hasnt been defeated, the Nightmare Rook gains the elite adjustments and becomes a 21st-level creature.
D. The Nightmare Spire.name: D. The Nightmare Spire

H. The Knurly House.name: H. The Knurly House
H. The Knurly House.text:
The forest opens into a narrow clearing surrounded by bent, extremely broad trees. At the center of the clearing rises a strange sight: what appears to be two dozen different houses tangled together in a semi-organized mess, forming a conglomerate building where right angles seem unwelcome. A tangled yard filled with bristly vines and thorns surrounds the cottage.

This building is the Knurly House, all that remains of Nyrissas first attempt to craft herself a house from the raw potential of the First World. She learned much from this initial attempt, and the House at the Edge of Time is a much more stable and well-organized affair.

The thorns that surround the Knurly House are 20 feet thick and 15 feet tall, save for a 10-foot-wide path leading to the house itself. A creature can move through the thorns but treats the overgrown area as both difficult terrain and hazardous terrain that deals [[/r 4d6[piercing]]] damage each time the creature takes a Move action.

Bloom Trophies: Two-foot-long vines of tangled, @UUID[Item.IZTr2HwEIRbBSwF2]{knotted brambles}, linked to the @UUID[.vTHOtZdnJXb9mKnP]{Knurly Briars} bloom.

Nyrissa gave this house to one of her few true friends, a powerful hag cleric of the goddess Gyronna. This twisted annis hag has abandoned and forgotten her true name in favor of being known as the Knurly Witch. When the Knurly Witch first stumbled into Thousandbreaths 220 years ago, Nyrissa offered the annis a choicedie and feed her pet tarn linnorm, or live as Nyrissas servant. The annis made the choice easily enough and does not regret it, for she has been treated well by Nyrissa. Over the centuries, Thousandbreaths has accepted her as one of its own, and she now functions as a native to the demiplane.

Although the Knurly Witch is as evil as they come, she doesnt immediately attack. Shes been warned of the PCs by Nyrissa, and shes curious. She invites the PCs up to share tea with her as soon as she spots them. If the PCs agree to the invitation, the Knurly Witch adopts a strangely forthcoming and honest tactic as she serves them tea. A successful @Check[type:perception|dc:40] check is enough for a PC to realize the mixture isnt actually tea. A PC that imbibes this foul mixture of crows blood and powdered maggots must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:38] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{sickened 2} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{sickened 4} on a critical failure). She simply starts asking the PCs what theyre doing here in Thousandbreaths and tries to discern their powers, their goals, and their weaknesses through blunt questioning. If she thinks that itll make the PCs more cooperative, she proposes a free trade of information: for each question of hers they answer, shell answer one of theirs about Nyrissa. Of course, the Knurly Witch lies with each answer, trying to feed the PCs completely false information about the nymph queen in hopes that even if they believe one of her lies, their tactics will be compromised in a later confrontation. Eventually, either the Knurly Witch or the PCs are likely to grow tired of this, at which point the Knurly Witch can roll for initiative with a Deception check (she rolls with Perception if the PCs simply attack her on sight).

The Knurly Witch

Moderate 18

On the first round of combat, the Knurly Witch casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.b5sGjGlBf58f8jn0]{air walk} and moves upward out of reach of foes on the ground. She casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.jSRAyd57kd4WZ4yE]{summon plant or fungus} the next round to summon a @UUID[Actor.NTXm3ee7WZJ92Sww]{wemmuth}, then uses her ranged spells against the PCs on the following rounds. If reduced to 250 Hit Points, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2Vkd1IxylPceUAAF]{regenerate}. Upon being reduced to 100 HP or less, she activates @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.nzbnTqHgNKiGZkrZ]{word of recall} to retreat to her sanctuary in the House at the Edge of Time (area @UUID[.OZdqRcR4qnDrgVQc]{K16}). There, she seeks out Nyrissa to report her failure to defend the Knurly House and prepares as mentioned in area K16 to confront the PCs one last time.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.vTHOtZdnJXb9mKnP]{Knurly Briars} bloom hasnt been defeated, the PCs also face a particularly powerful @UUID[Actor.xZf1oOzxRrSON6Lb]{athach gardener} herea monster who does his best to prevent any PC from approaching the Knurly Witch to fight her in melee.

@UUID[Actor.6ScEXKMZcWih1rKu]{Knurly House Treasures}: A search of the Knurly House takes an hour. With success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check, a PC discovers one of the treasures the Knurly Witch hid; a critical success discovers all four. These treasures consist of several journals written in Aklo that contain the formulas for two rituals (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7yWXx3qC4eFNHhxD]{blight} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.nzbnTqHgNKiGZkrZ]{word of recall}), a set of greater holy prayer beads, a +2 greater striking wounding dagger, and a ring of wizardry IV.

Day 1: The Whirling Lake.name: Day 1: The Whirling Lake
Day 1: The Whirling Lake.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.pl9Jhx5QomIaV5U8]{Whirling Lake}

The first bloom is not a bloom of vegetation but a bloom of churning water. Unlike land-based blooms, which manifest as sudden tangles of overgrowth, this bloom manifests as a whirlpool of black water in one of the Stolen Lands lakes.

Location: This bloom can appear in any lake in the Stolen Lands. Its effects can spread only through waterit cannot spread into hexes that dont contain water connected to the source bloom via a lake or river.

Bloom: The whirlpool is 500 feet across at the surface and reaches all the way down to the bottom of the lake where it leaves a 50-foot-diameter area of the lake bed exposed to the air. Any creature that enters the whirlpool must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:38] save; on a failure, their turn immediately ends, they take [[/r 8d6[bludgeoning]]] damage (and accidentally ingest some of the water on a critical failuresee below), and theyre swept up by the vortex. While a creature is swept up, they rotate around the vortex and are essentially @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the current. A creature can attempt a @Check[type:athletics|dc:38|traits:action-escape] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} by swimming free of the current. Each time a creature ends its turn in the vortex, it must attempt a new @Check[type:reflex|dc:38] save to avoid damage and being swept up.

Eerie, silent black swans congregate in the waters surrounding the whirlpool; as theyre drawn into the vortex, they fly up into the air and settle down back in the water some distance away only to slowly drift back into the whirlpool. The swans are ill-tempered but otherwise normal. Attempts to communicate with them via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.BBvV7qoXGdw09q1C]{speak with animals} or similar magic reveals that they fear the whirlpool because its loud and scary; they dont have memories of their life in the similar lake in Thousandbreaths (@UUID[.hwO3Kbh0Izx5mQtF]{area B}). The swans are immune to the disease brought by the churning waters.

Anyone who drinks the water in this hex or any hex that the bloom has spread to is exposed to a 14th-level strain of blinding sickness (see the @UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH]{elder elemental tsunami}).

@UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH]{Elder Elemental Tsunamis (4)}

Severe 17

A group of four extremely powerful elemental tsunamis swim and froth in the region surrounding the vortex. The elementals can move through the vortex with ease, ignoring its effects just as they ignore the swans and any animals of that size or smaller. They quickly move to attack larger creatures that approach, using Stealth for initiative as they split off from the whirlpool in their own vortex shapes and assume their natural forms: immense swanlike shapes of dark water.

If all four elementals are slain or banished from the Material Plane, the central vortex immediately collapses in on itself as the bloom vanishes. The resulting geyser of water calms quickly, and all the black swans die and bob to the surface.

@UUID[Item.U4QON5JFeGRdAZ3k]{Bloom Trophies}: Black swan carcasses, linked to the Lake of Midnight Swans (@UUID[.hwO3Kbh0Izx5mQtF]{area B}).

M6. Nyrissas Garden.text:
The vines and leaves of an overgrown garden fill this high chamber, the ceiling of which is obscured by a dense canopy of mold and fungus that hang like wet, glistening sheets. The walls are difficult to make out through the riotous green growth, but at the rooms center sits a rippling pool of water.

The pool of water is one of the four entrances to the Fableit leads to area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7a}.

@UUID[Actor.VUJrPHKOjYkIQnWn]{Mu Spore}

Moderate 19

At first glance, this strange garden might seem to be a dualistic display of verdant plant life below and glistening fungus above, both sustained by the life-giving primal energies of Thousandbreaths. In fact, the fungus above is a single immense creaturean elite mu spore that has floated quietly within the garden, dreaming strange dreams for the past several centuries. Much smaller than most mu spores, this specimen is still large enough to fill the upper half of this 40-foot-tall room. Anyone other than Nyrissa who enters this room immediately awakens the immense creature. It fills the upper portion of the room so completely that it cant move, but it has no problem reaching creatures on the ground below, and it can even send its tentacles slithering through nearby rooms to pursue those who flee.
M6. Nyrissas Garden.name: M6. Nyrissas Garden

K10. Poisoned Well.name: K10. Poisoned Well
K10. Poisoned Well.text:
A covered well is this chambers only feature.

This well drops 100 feet into waters that, while cool and crystal clear, are tainted with diseaseanyone who drinks from the well is exposed to an especially dangerous 20th-level strain of @UUID[Actor.L6ANJQoCyk5dWcdH.Item.KtA9MV7RA5nWRmko]{blinding sickness}, with a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:40] save).

Traveling to Thousandbreaths.text:
Unbloomed Encounters

If the PCs make it to Thousandbreaths before the month of destruction concludes, theyll face more dangerous encounters here, but if they wait too long in hopes of defeating more blooms, they run the risk that Nyrissa might absorb their kingdom. Eight of the nine glade encounters detailed here (areas BI) are presented with the assumption that their associated bloom has manifested and been defeated, and are thus Moderate 18 encounters. If a glades associated bloom hasnt manifested or hasnt been defeated by the PCs, though, some of the creatures and energies that would have been expended on that bloom remain active in the glade and it becomes a Severe 18 encounter. Notes on what to add to each glade encounter to make it a Severe 18 encounter appear at the end of the encounter in an Unbloomed entry.

If all of the creatures in a glade encounter are defeated before the glades associated bloom manifests during the month of destruction, that bloom does not manifest at all when its day comes.

When @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD]{Nyrissa} founded Thousandbreaths, it existed fully in the First World, but after she was punished by the Eldest, they shed this domain from that plane. Today, Thousandbreaths exists as its own demiplane, where much of the realities of the First World hold sway, yet it serves also as a prison from which Nyrissa cannot stray for long.

Due to its nature as an obscure demiplane, travel to Thousandbreaths from another plane is difficult. The PCs could use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{plane shift} to travel there but only if theyve fully researched Thousandbreaths by gaining at least 18 Research Points. Even then, theyll need a special tuning fork to travel to the realmalthough a copy of @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg]{Zuddigers Picnic} can function in place of such a focus for spellcasting. @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U13bC0tNgrlHoeTK]{Gate} can create a portal to Thousandbreaths, although as an uncommon 10th-level spell, the PCs might not have access to it.

A fixed portal does exist that links Thousandbreaths and the Material Planethe main entrance to the ruins known as the @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]{Castle of Knives} deep in the forest of Thousand Voices. This portal flared open for a few months when Nyrissas attention first came to the stolen lands about two decades ago (it was at this time that Karn Zuddiger stumbled through the portal while exploring the forest, emerging just before it closed to go on to pen Zuddigers Picnic), but has remained inert since then. Its not until the blooms begin during Part 1 of this chapter that the Castle of Knives portal opens back up. As long as the blooms remain active, the portal remains impossible to missany who approach the Castle of Knives see it as a vine-shrouded rent in reality. While the PCs wont learn of this portals activation while researching Thousandbreaths, they can certainly infer its existence, but its most likely theyll learn about it from one of their fey allies such as Evindra or Limm Ticklewing. Of course, unless the PCs carry three different Bloom trophies with them, they wont be able to pass through this portal at all.

Once the blooms begin, a remarkable transformation takes place in the castles ruinsthe castle appears as a strange structure of sharp towers and confusing architecture of dozens of colors that seem strangely too vibrant for the surroundings. The entire castle is surrounded by a wrought iron fence that contains a single gate flanked by statues of beautiful women. The transformation lasts until the PCs uproot Nyrissas realm, but the iron gate itself continues to function as a portal to Thousandbreaths as long as that realm continues to exist as a demiplane.

Regardless of the method the PCs use to travel to Thousandbreaths, they always appear in the same place: the Byway (@UUID[.2Z65BXwMzTkQ9dRZ]{area A})
Traveling to Thousandbreaths.name: Traveling to Thousandbreaths

The Power of Forgiveness.name: The Power of Forgiveness
The Power of Forgiveness.text:
Some of the creatures in the House at the Edge of Timethe ghostly guards and defaced naiad queens, but most notably Nyrissa herselfstill harbor vestiges of goodness in their minds and souls that can be appealed to by PCs who seek to forgive them for their actions. A PC can learn about the Forgive Foe action accidentally if they seek to appeal to a creature in the House at the Edge of Time in this way on their own, or they can learn about it by closely observing how certain creatures act when they attack certain foes.

These foes have a Shame entry in their stat block. When such a foe attacks specific targets delineated in their Shame entry, they suffer a 2 status penalty on attack rolls and to all save DCs to resist their spells or attacks. Whenever such a creature takes an action that triggers this penalty, all creatures within 30 feet can attempt a Perception check against the acting creatures Deception DC. On a success, the creature attempting the check realizes the creature taking the action is suffering from guilt and shame at their own action; this reveals that a Forgive Foe action might help the acting creature recover from its plight.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.adventure-specific-actions.Item.764EVGVADrDSbdqu]{Forgive Foe} 2

  • Auditory
  • Concentrate
  • Linguistic
  • Mental

You make an attempt to force a foe to confront its guilt and face its shame for its actions. When you do so, attempt either a Diplomacy check or another check as indicated in the creatures Shame entry; the DC is the creatures Will DC.

  • Critical Success Your words strike home and allow the creature to escape its servitude to the House at the Edge of Time. The specific effects of this are listed in the creatures Shame entry.

  • Success Your words give the foe pause. It suffers a 2 status penalty on all attacks, effect DCs, and its Will DC against additional Forgive Foe attempts until the end of your next turn.

  • Critical Failure Your attempt fails so dramatically that you instead fuel the creatures wrath and effectively blind it to its sense of shame and guilt. For the next 24 hours, it no longer suffers the effects of shame when it attacks you and you can no longer attempt to Forgive that Foe.

M2. Ivy Tower.name: M2. Ivy Tower
M2. Ivy Tower.text:
This tower looks out over the House grounds, leaning at a vertiginous angle over the courtyard below. The entire area has been covered completely with a nest-like tangle of vegetation.

A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check notes the vine- and root-covered trap door that leads down to area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg]{M1}. The ironwood vines that choke it must be cleared before the trap door can be opened easily; otherwise, it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Forced Open} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check.

@UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]{Elite Sard}

Low 19

This towers open rooftop is the den of Nyrissas elite sard, a creature who takes up the entire space, its tangled roots hanging over the edges. It observes the PCs as they approach, even if they challenge foes down in the courtyard or atop the lower manor walls in areas @UUID[.COhCF3Ki8BXn1jLz]{K1}@UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2}, but it wont join a fight there unless it is attacked. If someone forces open the trap door from area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg]{M1} below, they wont be able to climb up onto the roof of the tower since the sard occupies that space completely, and the sard gets to roll Athletics for initiative as it shifts its bulk ponderously above. Once roused to anger, the monster pursues foes as best it can, either clambering over the Houses roofline or using its melee Strikes reach to attack anyone who tries to retreat into area M1 for refuge. It abandons pursuit only if the PCs retreat deeper into the House or flee to the lakes far shore; otherwise, it fights to the death.

If the PCs have slain the lesser jabberwock in @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt]{Part 1}, Nyrissa relocates this sard down to area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2}, in which case this area is empty.

K8. Storeroom.text:
What this oddly-shaped storeroom may have once held is impossible to tell, for its shelves today are empty.

While the room appears to be empty, success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:30|traits:action:search] check or a @Check[type:architecture-lore|dc:20|traits:action:investigate] check reveals that the shelves in the room seem to have been installed upside down.

In fact, the room itself is upside down, and anything that enters the room, be it a thrown coin or a PC or anything else, suddenly falls upward to the ceiling. This is hardly even a minor hazard for high-level PCs (its just a @Check[type:reflex|dc:15] save to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.3yoajuKjwHZ9ApUY]{Grab the Edge} of the doorframe to avoid a fall for 5 points of damage), but it should serve as a dramatic reminder that not everything in the House is as it appears.
K8. Storeroom.name: K8. Storeroom

K19. Ruined Washroom.name: K19. Ruined Washroom
K19. Ruined Washroom.text:
The walls of this forty-foot-high room have fractured, and whatever once decorated it now lies in pulverized fragments heaped in small drifts of sawdust and sand on the floor. This was clearly once some sort of washroom with stone walls and numerous tubs, but now the place is in a shambles.

When the House at the Edge of Time was created, the way it distorted and twisted time itself attracted the angry attention of a trio of bythos aeons, but when they arrived to oppose the construction of a structure that warped time and space, they ended up being trapped within it.

These same three aeons have remained trapped in this room ever since, and today they exist in a mindset simultaneously of initial fury at discovering the House and of someone who has been trapped in a room for centuries. Nyrissa and her minions avoid this room as a result.

@UUID[Actor.2evDJNdhsUEGe2w0]{Elite Bythos Aeons (3)}

Low 19

The aeons attack any intruders on sight. While theyre elite bythos aeons, theyre also limited by the nature of this roomthey cannot leave the chamber by any means, including teleportation or planar travel. Worse, unlike other monsters in the House, these three aeons, thanks to their strange association with time itself, also reset whenever the House itself resets, and are restored to life as trapped as ever. Only if Nyrissa is defeated (either by killing her or forgiving her) will these three aeons ever escape.

Helix Theorem Feedback: A PC who is under the protection of the Helix Theorem adds their +4 status bonus from that to their Armor Class against these aeons, as each time the creatures attempt to attack such a PC, flashes of purple energy intervene with a gut-churning hum. The first time the bythos damages a PC who is protected by the Helix Theorem, the bythos must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:40] save. The bythos is then temporarily immune to this feedback for 1 hour.

  • Critical Success The aeon is unaffected by the feedback.

  • Success A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{slowed 1}.

  • Failure A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{stunned 3}.

  • Critical Failure A flash of light lashes out from the PC to strike the aeon, causing it to be banished from the House at the Edge of Time.

Treasure: The aeons understand the cause of their freedom if the PCs defeat Nyrissa. They plane shift to Axis, but within a few days of Nyrissas defeat, they return to the Material Plane to thank the PCs with an envisioned explanation of the mercy the PCs granted them, along with an orichalcum weapon (choose a weapon used by one of the PCs who would most benefit from the weapon) before they return to Axis.

Part 2: A Thousand Breaths.text:
The PCs should be 18th level before they enter Thousandbreaths.

As this chapter begins, the PCs should be aware that their kingdom is under attack by something beyond the mortal realm. The manifestation of the blooms, the incursions of strange monsters, and even the appearance of the strange trophies after a bloom is defeated all point to the First World as the source of the dangers.

Thousandbreaths

There are many events in Part 1 of this adventure that should convince the PCs that some force from the First World has taken an interest in the Stolen Landsspeaking with the nereid Evindra, the pixie @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT]{Limm Ticklewing}, or interrogating captured prisoners from blooms will confirm this. They can also @UUID[.Z9tXO2BefaG40wFP]{research} the topic in libraries theyve constructed in their kingdom, or they might even know about it from using skills to Recall Knowledge. Eventually, the PCs should learn that if they wish to confront their enemy, they must travel to a specific part of the First World called Thousandbreathsbut the more they know about this realm beforehand, the better their chances will be.
Part 2: A Thousand Breaths.name: Part 2: A Thousand Breaths

The Final Glade.name: The Final Glade
The Final Glade.text:
The forest path opens at the shore of a vast lake, its waters still and dark. A stone bridge crosses the lake to an island at its center, where a walled gatehouse bars entry to the isle beyond. Beyond the gatehouse looms a sprawling manor, its steep roofs and twin towers stretching up into the sky. The tops of these towers seem to shift and shimmer, sometimes appearing to be simple stone edifices and other times being crowned with twisted, twitching trees or sinister-looking foliage. Likewise, the far side of the lake flickers and shimmers, one moment featuring images of vast mountains, the next featuring the endless expanse of the night sky, as if reality itself isnt sure what it wants to be.

While in Thousandbreaths, the lake surrounding the House is effectively bottomless. Just as one can fly upward and never rise above the tree level, one can swim down into the lake without ever reaching the bottom. Fortunately the surface is never more than a few hundred feet away should a swimmer elect to return, despite the fact that the lake itself seems to be a mile across. The lake spills over the edge of its mesa in two places, to the left and right, to form the twin nameless rivers that frame Thousandbreaths and eventually meet again at the Whirling Lake, where the waters drain away to nowhere. If Thousandbreaths is uprooted, the waterfalls soon run dry as the lake drains to equilibriumthis results in a surface height change of only 20 feet. Additionally, the lake gains a bed at this time, although at 150 feet, it is still quite deep.

Scene

@UUID[Scene.e3aUzjPZMnu8fK7G]{The Approach}

This scene depicts the bridge connecting the House to Thousandbreaths.

The House can be reached via a long stone bridge that connects its island to the mesas edge. A flight of stairs rises up from the lakeshore to the bridge, which itself runs at a height of forty feet above the water. A gatehouse flanked by towers guards the far sides entrance to the House, while in the courtyard beyond, tall dark trees rise and rustle in the constant soft breeze. Dozens of windows stare out of the House itself, and stone fey hang from every gable. The outline of the House is as beautiful as it is dangerous, with knifelike crenellations, spear-topped towers, and eaves and shingles made of blades. Some parts of the House seem new and others old, but the structure as a whole is ancient and unchangingeven the sections of the House that appear to be ruins have always been that way (with exceptions noted in the text).

A PC who studies the two towers extending above the manors roofs and succeeds at a @Check[type:nature|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check notes that the treelike vegetation that shifts in and out of reality atop the taller towers is a sort of visual projection from the First World, suggesting a concentration of primal magic there. A critical success on this check identifies the tree atop the shorter tower as a powerful sard (unless this creature has been relocated to the courtyardsee areas @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2} and @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]{M2}).

  • @UUID[Actor.2IrbfdtWyXiGOLBA]{Tarlaxian}

Approaching the House

Moderate 19

Regardless of whether the PCs use the bridge, swim, boat, or fly to the House, the approach is well protected. A tarn linnorm named Tarlaxian dwells in the lake, and it watches those who fly above its waters or cross the bridge. Tarlaxian wont pursue the PCs into the House itself, but he does encamp on the bridge to serve as a menacing guard against any attempt to flee the manor, ready to resume the attack if the PCs emerge. If the PCs attempt to use ranged attacks or spells against him from within the safety of the House, Tarlaxian simply retreats back into the waters of the lake.

L4. Stairwell.text: This flight of spiral stairs leads up to area @UUID[.z9nhyC2rLauXRQRg]{M1}.
L4. Stairwell.name: L4. Stairwell

K1. Gatehouse.name: K1. Gatehouse
K1. Gatehouse.text:
A stone gatehouse bars entry into the sprawling manors courtyard beyond with a lowered portcullis. In the walls above, arrow slits leer down while a forty-foot-high wall extends from the gatehouse in both directions to connect to two more towers.

The iron portcullis (Hardness 18, HP 72 [BT 36]) can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Forced Open} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:38] check. Alternately, it can be raised or lowered from the upper floor of the gatehouse (area K1b). Although there are several guards posted here and along the wall, the denizen of the courtyard (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2}) comes to defend the area if it notices anyone breaking into area K1a.

@UUID[Actor.gXbDaY9ci2u22ptT]{Ghostly Guards (8)}

Moderate 19

Undead are rare in the First World, for it is a realm infused with life, but here in the House at the Edge of Time that overabundance of life is muted. Nyrissas house guards are thankful for this because they are ghosts. Once members of an ancient elven kingdom on a distant world, these elves were the first victims of Nyrissas quest to claim a thousand kingdoms. She has never been able to replicate the transformation of a nations greatest warriors into ghostly guards like this since that first conquest, but since these ghosts rejuvenate as long as Nyrissa lives, shes never had need for reinforcements.

As ghosts, these guards are eternally vigilant; they need not take breaks to eat, sleep, or entertain themselves. At any one time, four stand guard in area K1b, one atop each of the towers (areas K1c and K1d), and one atop each of the walls to either side of the gatehouse, amounting to eight ghostly guards in all.

When these ghosts spot intruders, they use their frightful moan more as an alarm than an attack, then they proceed to use Ectoplasmic Maneuver to attempt to disarm the intruders. After a few rounds, four of the ghosts swoop down to engage the PCs in melee while the other four fly up to make ranged attacks. The ghostly guards fight until destroyed.

Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock.name: Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock
Day 28. Beware the Jabberwock.text:
If the PCs dont force the House at the Edge of Time to manifest on the Material Plane in the forest of Thousand Voices by day 28 of the month of destruction, and Nyrissa has not yet retrieved Briar, then the fey queen sends in her deadliest minion: a lesser jabberwock she grew from blood left over from her ancient battle with the true jabberwock so long ago. The procedure by which she created and raised this lesser jabberwock is a closely guarded secret known only to a few denizens of the First World, for the resulting monster, while not as deadly as a true jabberwock, is a devastating foe nevertheless. It has orders to destroy the PCsNyrissa figures that their deaths should render her visions of her own demise moot just as surely as her recovering Briar. If she has already retrieved Briar, she wont send the lesser jabberwock to attack the PCs; in this case, feel free to have the PCs encounter the monster in Thousandbreaths or in the House at the Edge of Time/Castle of Knives as you wish.

On the dawn of this final event, a strange thing happens in the skies above. Although theres not a cloud in the sky, roars of thunder echo across the entire Stolen Lands. The thunder comes in diminishing intervals, initially every 10 minutes, but by noon, the thunder booms like the approaching footsteps of an immense creature. Use this ominous event to let the PCs know that something is coming.

Exactly 1 hour after noon, the loudest peal of thunder yet strikes, and with a flash of unsettling green light above the PCs, the boundaries between this world and the First are sundered, and a true monster steps througha lesser jabberwock. To do this, Nyrissa must first cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.CeSh8QcVnqP5OlLj]{discern location} on a PC. If she hasnt observed them via the Horned Hunters Fey Conduit, shell need a body part or significant item once owned by the PCs. While its unlikely she has a body part, she might own an itemany particularly powerful or noteworthy magic item or object a PC had an emotional attachment to will work, and if over the course of this campaign a PC sold or lost such an item, you can rule that Nyrissas agents recovered it. (If you do so, make sure to let the PC discover it in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7d} later in this chapter!)

@UUID[Actor.XQyXoOe7FCpZilaF]{Lesser Jabberwock}

Extreme 17

A lesser jabberwock is, despite its name, a deadly foe. This hideous reptilian beast stands nearly 30 feet high, with a long, scaly neck, a vaguely draconic body, and a long whiplike tail. Its arms and legs are thin but incredibly strong, ending in sharp talons. Immense draconic wings flap on its back, and its ovoid head is a nightmare of bulging eyes, sharp teeth, and long, thin antennae or whiskers.

If this battle begins in a settlement, the lesser jabberwocks arrival can potentially damage or destroy a structurewhen this battle begins, have one PC attempt a @Check[type:engineering|dc:42|roller:party]. On a failure, the structure closest to the targeted PC becomes damaged, while on a critical failure that structure is destroyed and reduced to @UUID[JournalEntry.BIu4C1T1RR17QNwl.JournalEntryPage.uLknnDCOpL0HvNPq]{Rubble}.

Briar: As the battle begins, if the PCs have the sword Briar, it immediately glows with a vibrant green light and wakens to its full capacity, as if it had gained 20 sharpness points. The sword returns to its proper level of awakening once the lesser jabberwock is defeated.

Strategy: The lesser jabberwock uses Intimidation to determine its initiative, then races into the midst of the PCs on the first round of combat to Strike with its bite. On the second round, it Burbles to confuse the PCs that surround it. On following rounds, it makes melee Strikes, preferably against the PC wielding Briar. If the monster is reduced to fewer than 215 hit points, it takes to the air and circles, firing eyes of flame while it heals back up to at least 320 hit points before landing and entering melee again. If denied this level of mobility, the monster simply focuses its fury on single targets, hoping to take the PCs down one at a time. If the monster defeats Briars wielder, it claims the weapon and takes to the air. The gate through which Nyrissa sent the creature into the Material Plane is closed, so it must return to the First World via the portal at the Castle of Knivesit flies toward that site with all due haste, eager to return the hated weapon to its mistress. Otherwise, the lesser jabberwock fights to the death.

K17. Throne Room.text:
Turquoise tiles adorn the walls of this chamber, with a false gallery hanging some ten feet above the tiled floor. An ornate wooden bridge crosses the chamber thirty feet above the floor, connecting doors on the buildings second floorthe vaulted ceiling rises another ten feet above that. Incredible paintings depicting animals in sylvan scenes cover this ceiling. The first shows a wolf in a forest with a severed hand clenched in its jaws. The second depicts a great viper approaching a crib, while the third shows a huge bear stalking a mother and child. An archway decorated with a dragon eating a mounted knight at one end of the room opens to a great iron spiral staircase leading upward, while at the other end of the hall sits a regal throne made of marble shot through with green veins. Two statues of beautiful women wielding upraised swords stand to either side of the throne, while a long purple carpet runs the length of the room. Numerous chairs and benches line the walls.

Nyrissa has not used this room in agesher followers know what to do and there is little need for the nymph to address them. The stairs lead up to area @UUID[.xUo04MURzBvvjVcx]{L1}, and the wooden bridge is area @UUID[.BERVHJyeUHv28SS3]{L7}. The walls can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climbed} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30|traits:action:climb] check.

The throne is one of the four entrances to the Fable; it leads to area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7c} (see that area for how one can enter the Fable via the throne).

With Nyrissa all but abandoning this room, its care has been entrusted to one of her most dangerous allies: her personal advisor, the Wriggling Man.

@UUID[Actor.NMCee869vhJjP5Ri]{The Wriggling Man}

Moderate 19

The Wriggling Man does not recall his life before his death and subsequent transformation into a worm that walks, save that he came to the First World on a long-forgotten mission. That he failed in this mission seems obvious, for it was after his failure and death that his mind and spirit infested the worms that fed upon his rotting remains and he was reborn as a worm that walks.

The Wriggling Man soon found work as Nyrissas advisor in all things arcane; while Nyrissa herself is a talented spellcaster, her gifts are inborn, not the result of study, and she appreciates help with her more complex plans. His aid has been instrumental in helping Nyrissa manipulate nascent kingdoms on hundreds of other worlds to prepare them for absorption into the Apology; currently, his only task is to await the PCs, ambush them, and kill them.

Warned by Nyrissa of the PCs approach as soon as they enter the House at the Edge of Time, the Wriggling Man has settled upon a cunning plan to both amuse himself and potentially disrupt the PCs plans. He casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Ucf8eynbZMfUucjE]{illusory scene} on the northern end of the room to make it appear that the two statues of Nyrissa stand to either side of the throne rather than behind it, and includes a wall just behind the throne itself to completely obscure the northernmost five feet of the room. He then hides behind the throne north of the illusion to await the PCs arrival.

Effect

@UUID[Item.8wP9e8qQdrtTXYyk]{Angel Man}

This effect changes the subject's token to that of an angelic being, and can be used to support the Wriggling Man's disguise.

As soon as he notices the PCs entering the chamber, he rolls for initiative using Stealth. On his turn, he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx]{time stop}, then casts veil to appear as an 8-foot-tall, Medium-sized angel with golden skin on the first of his three rounds. On the second round he casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.yV7Ouzaoe7DHLESI]{ventriloquism}, and on the third @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O]{project image} to make himself appear (as an angel) 30 feet south of the throne in the middle of the chamber.

When his time stop ends, the Wriggling Man, in his disguise, seems to appear out of nowhere in the middle of the room. He continues to sustain @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O]{project image} each round while remaining hidden behind the throne, and asks the PCs to stay their hands, hoping to trick them into thinking hes actually an angelic guardian.

If the PCs hold off on attacking, the Wriggling Man imperiously informs the PCs that they must leave this House at once, lest they further intrude upon the works of one under the protection of Heaven itself. This is, of course, a liethe Wriggling Man doesnt expect the PCs to fall for it for long (if at all), but the tactic does amuse him. If the tactic works, he strings the PCs along with stories of how Heavens armies have come to the House at the Edge of Time to contain its dangers, and that from this point forward, no further action on the PCs behalf is needed to keep their kingdom safe. If the ruse works and the PCs leave, the Wriggling Man is somewhat surprised, but as soon as the PCs exit the room, he drops the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O]{project image}, casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.VDudQ4x2ozosAbTb]{invisibility}, and then follows them for a minute to make sure they leave. If they dont, hell keep on them until they get into a fight or his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.VDudQ4x2ozosAbTb]{invisibility} is about to end, at which point hell join the battle to make things even more dangerous for the PCs.

If the PCs see through the ruse, though, the Wriggling Man is more than willing to fight. He continues to sustain his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.0873MWM0qKDDv81O]{project image} as long as it makes sense to do so, casting offensive spells through the illusion as needed to fight the PCs. If his illusions are penetrated, hell work to avoid melee as best as he can, but if his magic incapacitates a character, he cant resist approaching the poor PC to engulf them in his Squirming Embrace. He relies on his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WG91Z5TiR6oO5FOw]{contingency} spell to rescue him if he gets into trouble; if he does manage to escape to area @UUID[.WvVPzlZL3XDYxu2f]{M6} hell remain away only as long as it takes for him to recover his health, at which point he @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vTQvfYu2llKQedmY]{dimension doors} back into this room to track the PCs down and attack againbut this time he fights to the death.
K17. Throne Room.name: K17. Throne Room

Day 12: Nights of Dread.name: Day 12: Nights of Dread
Day 12: Nights of Dread.text:
The most insidious of the blooms does not manifest physically, but in the dreams of those it touches upon.

Location: This bloom manifests in the PCs capital. Unlike other blooms, this one does not physically change the region it influences or spread into neighboring hexes.

Bloom: This blooms effects manifest in the dead of night, at which point many who sleep in the hex suffer nightmares of being chased through the woods, being savaged by wild animals, and of being pursued by an immense dark bird whose wings blot out the stars.

In some cases, these dreams have a greater effect than merely unsettling sleepfor some, they become living nightmares that end with a real magical effect. On the first night, only one creature experiences a living nightmare. Each night it persists, it causes one additional creature to experience a living nightmare (so, two victims on the second day, three on the third, four on the fourth, and so on until the bloom is destroyed). The bloom targets PCs randomly if they sleep in the bloom hex, or random citizens if not (who are slain by the living nightmare). At your discretion, key NPCs or companions can be targeted, in which case you should have a player control the NPC and play out the blooms effects rather than having the NPC automatically slain.

When a character is targeted by a living nightmare, they endure the phantasmagoric visions and then awaken with a scream as the nightmare culminates in a powerful spell effect. You can use the table below to randomly determine what sort of nightmare and spell effect the character is targeted by or use these suggestions to create similar effects of your own design (note that all of these spells are ones that target a single creature). All of these spells are heightened to 9th level, have spell attack +30, and are DC 36.

@UUID[RollTable.RyETqIR5yFNv4BmP]{Living Nightmares}
[[/r 1d8]]Spell EffectLiving Nightmare Description
1@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.dN8QBNuTiaBHCKUe]{Baleful Polymorph}You are hunted by predators and wake as a harmless animal.
2@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.VosLNn2M8S7JH67D]{Blindness}You gaze upon something so horrific that you are blinded.
3@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]{Dominate}Your allies are possessed. Kill them before they kill you.
4@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.5BbU1V6wGSGbrmRD]{Feeblemind}Your thoughts are not your own, as if something else were thinking for you.
5@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.znv4ECL7ZtuiagtA]{Flesh to Stone}You are buried alive but remain aware as the years pass and you fossilize.
6@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.tlcrVRqW1MSKJ5IC]{Phantasmal Killer}You are attacked by a frightening monster or your most fearful foe.
7@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.BKIet436snMNcnez]{Polar Ray}You endure an eternal blizzard after the world has frozen.
8@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.8kJbiBEjMWG4VUjs]{Warp Mind}The world around you keeps changing into different horrifying realities.

Regardless of the nature of the living nightmare a given victim endures, the living nightmares share a feature in common with the standard nightmares suffered by everyone in the bloom: the presence of an immense black bird that watches over the nightmare from the dark night skies above. This monstrous shape never takes direct action in the nightmares, but the dreamers always wake with the conviction that the bird caused the nightmare.

This shape is a creature called the @UUID[Actor.L3q7yQ0jKqH2IWy7]{Nightmare Rook}, an immense avian that dwells in Thousandbreaths and directs the horrific nightmares from that realm (see @UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]{The Nightmare Spire}). A PC who experiences a nightmare can attempt a @Check[type:nature|dc:36|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check or @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} to identify the Nightmare Rook as a mythological creature said to dwell in the First World; on a critical success, the character also remembers that a creature very similar to the Nightmare Rook was a character in a strange picture book called @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg]{Zuddigers Picnic} published long ago in Pitax. In the tales and the picture book, the protagonist encounters the Nightmare Rook and is carried away, only managing to escape by luck. The PCs can secure a copy of Zuddigers Picnic by completing the @UUID[.praFCrBA8AMlJRhV]{Houten Legacy} quest. See @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v]{Part 2} of this chapter for more about the book.

To defeat this bloom, a PC must ignore the nightmare itself and confront the watching, ever-present Nightmare Rook. Whenever you describe a PCs nightmare, but before they wake to endure the resulting spell effect, describe the nature of their nightmare and the fact that a giant black bird looms watching nearby. Give the PC a chance to react to this element of the nightmare. If they confront the rook in any way, the PC can take the following activity. If they dont confront the bird, describe the nightmare ending in a horrific fashion, much to the watching birds delight, and then have the PC awaken to endure the living nightmares spell effect.

Confront the Nightmare Rook

  • Concentration

If the PC confronts the Nightmare Rook, ask them to describe how they wish to do so, then select an appropriate skill check to match. For example, a direct physical attack would be modeled by @Check[type:intimidation|dc:40], for example, while a sneaky attack or ambush would use @Check[type:deception|dc:40]. An attempt to appeal to the bird for mercy would use @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:40], using music or song to distract it uses @Check[type:performance|dc:40], and simply sneaking away from the birds view would use @Check[type:stealth|dc:40]. Any spellcasting solution would use the corresponding @Check[type:arcana|dc:40], @Check[type:nature|dc:40], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40], or @Check[type:religion|dc:40] skill. Regardless of the skill, the PC attempts a DC 40 check.

  • Critical Success The confrontation catches the Nightmare Rook off guard and frightens it away; the PC awakens with the bloom trophy clutched in a hand, does not suffer the living nightmares spell effect, and the bloom is defeated.

  • Success The Nightmare Rook is startled by the PCs brazen confrontation. It retreats but does not leave. The PC awakens knowing that the nightmares will continue but that the birds resolve has been shaken. The PC does not suffer the spell effect of the living nightmare. Reduce the DC to Confront the Nightmare Rook by 2 for all further attempts by any PC.

  • Failure The Nightmare Rook caws in delight at the PCs failure. The nightmare catches up to the PC, who wakens with a scream and endures the living nightmares spell effect.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the living nightmare is particularly harrowing. The PC takes a 4 circumstance penalty to their saving throw against the spell effect or the spell gains a +4 circumstance bonus on its attack roll, as appropriate.

@UUID[Item.x9UldAAwoPhNLPU3]{Bloom Trophies}: Black raven feathers pulled from a nightmare, linked to the Nightmare Spire (@UUID[.VooytwmPZQrM1I7N]{area D}).

Story Award: Award the PCs 40 XP upon defeating this bloom.

M4. Nyrissas Library.name: M4. Nyrissas Library
M4. Nyrissas Library.text:
This room is both a laboratory and a library, with numerous large tomes sitting on sagging shelves along the walls and several tables covered with notes and strange schematics.

The majority of the notes on the tables are poetry written by Nyrissa, but if the PCs have unanswered questions about what Nyrissa is up to or why shes out to take the Stolen Lands, they can discover fragmentary notes here to help clear up any lingering last-minute questions that you know dont hinge on the events of @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs]{Chapter 11}. The PCs can also learn about the Fable by studying these notes. A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:nature|dc:30|traits:action:investigate] check or a @Check[type:arcana|dc:40], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:investigate], or @Check[type:religion|dc:40|traits:action:investigate] check made as part of an hour spent @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EwgTZBWsc8qKaViP]{Investigating} these notes learns not only what the Fable is capable of and how it works, but also the locations of the four portals that open into the Fable. Such a character also learns the method of opening the portals, as well as the method of leaving the Fable once one is inside it. See area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7} for these details. If the PCs arent stealthy about investigating these notes, Nyrissa may notice them from her vantage point in the Fable and alert any surviving minions to make all haste to this area to stop the PCs from learning too much from these carelessly forgotten notes.

@UUID[Actor.qvgVySLNYbyKY0Y7]{Nyrissa's Library}: This library contains a large number of books about the First World, the Stolen Lands, and magic theory. Any @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} checks made while using this library to research a topic tied to one of these three subjects gain a +3 item bonus. The collection weighs several hundred pounds in all, but as a set is worth 14,000 gp.

L6. Servants Wing.text: This wing of the House served as chambers for servants, but since Nyrissa created her ghostly guardians, these rooms have gone unused. Areas L6a and L6b are both bedrooms. L6c is a storeroom, while L6d is a privy. L6e is a lounge stocked with a large number of old (but relatively mundane and worthless) books, while L6f is an open room for exercise and gatherings.
L6. Servants Wing.name: L6. Servants Wing

Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll.name: Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll
Day 25: The Misbegotten Troll.text:
This bloom manifests on the site of a large structure or ruin, filling the region with tangles of vegetation.

Location: A hex with a refuge, ruin, or structure that the PCs have already explored but havent developed into a settlement or (if possible) havent even claimed as part of their kingdom. Its best if this is a site that is supported by a map from a previous chapter, so that when the PCs come to this bloom, theyll be on familiar ground yet facing a new enemy. Excellent choices include the hexes containing the @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.W2JjcQj6vysfR53G]{Forgotten Keep}, the @UUID[JournalEntry.36YItDu6VgX6IRWV.JournalEntryPage.0NksPXFzWv8YI4Jn]{Troll Lair}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OcO78IbhsDP8cUof.JournalEntryPage.RzHbxYswWo3145mp]{Vordakais Tomb}, @UUID[JournalEntry.yGGSDRma9yTWwdeo.JournalEntryPage.jXuSbtaOAWEuRXtr]{Whiterose Abbey}, or the boggard village of @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{Mbotuu}.

Bloom: While the majority of the blooms do not bring the more powerful denizens from their connected glades in Thousandbreaths, this one does. Sprouting in an immense cage-like fortress called the Baleful Lantern, this bloom of tangled trees and spiny berry bushes manifests in the Stolen Lands along with the Lanterns denizen, a hateful and cruel monster known only as the Misbegotten Troll.

The vegetation that radiates out from this bloom grows swiftly, but the core of the bloom is linked to the Misbegotten Troll, who hitched a ride into this world to find fresh new victims to torment and eat.

Its likely that the PCs will first hear about this bloom after rumors of raids on outlying areas of the kingdom appear. After countless years preying upon fey, the troll is looking for some variety to add to his dinner tablea human or half-orc in particular. Whether the PCs come to confront the troll after hes first started to raid or after hes abducted one or more possible meals is left to you to decide. If you want to inject a particular sense of urgency, the trolls victim could well be an NPC important to the PCs.

  • @UUID[Actor.jUNnWUuiVueOTvHt]{The Misbegotten Troll}
  • @UUID[Actor.ndoXVn6MPPxSJvcC]{Black Smilodons (4)}

Encounter

Severe 17

As the PCs approach the Misbegotten Trolls new home, it should be obvious that someone has moved into the ruin. Smoke from unseen cook fires billows from the entrance or vents, and numerous territorial markers made of fresh bones, slaughtered locals, or other grisly trophies decorate the approach to the site.

The methods that the Misbegotten Troll uses to defend his new lair from attackers depend greatly on the layout and nature of his new home, and thus no details are given here apart from the villains stat block and notes on his basic combat tactics. If his chosen lair is too small to easily admit him physically, he sets up his new home at the locations entrance. The troll is a loner, but he does keep four particularly large and ill-tempered, black-pelted smilodons handy to serve as guardian beasts. The Misbegotten Troll deploys two of them as guards near the entrance to his lair; the other two remain at his side at all times for additional protection. The troll also wears a short chain threaded through his belt, from which hang several tiny cold iron cages, each of which contains a tormented spriteLimms sisters (see the @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT]{Pixies Sisters} quest). The cries and shrieks of these sprites as the troll moves give him an unsettling accompaniment. Since the Misbegotten Troll himself is the living heart of this bloom, his death causes the bloom to collapse.

Treasure: In addition to his glaive and armor, the string of cages carried by the Misbegotten Troll have value. There is one cage per PC, and as long as the four sprites remain trapped, this chain of lovelies (as the Misbegotten Troll calls them) is worth 500 gp for its craftsmanship but no one other than the troll himself can jangle the chain to produce any magical effect. While trapped, the sprites cannot take any actions at all. The cages dont have doors, but it requires success at only a @Check[type:athletics|dc:15|traits:action:force-open] check to force a cage open. Doing so releases the sprite trapped within; if all of the sprites are released, the grateful fey swarm around the PCs with cries of thanks before vanishing back to the First World. As they do, each PC gains the Fey Luck reaction below, usable once only. Freeing the sprites also fulfills the @UUID[.vT0pu88DsfkvKjOT]{Pixies Sisters} quest.

@UUID[Item.54HZ0h9J3LGkm4Lt]{Bloom Trophies}: Broken cages from the chain of lovelies, linked to the Baleful Lantern (@UUID[.lcZMjY4ZNjcysz2I]{area I}).

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.adventure-specific-actions.Item.7WczIXwjOs9raMja]{Fey Luck} R

  • Fortune
  • Primal

Trigger: You fail or critically fail a saving throw.

Frequency: once

The luck granted to you after freeing the sprites from their cruel cages saves you from an undesirable fate. Adjust a failed saving throw to a success, or a critically failed saving throw to a failed saving throw.

K11. Teleporter Entrance.text:
This small chamber seems to have been decorated with an eye toward meditation. The themes herein are all of the natural world; a sumptuous stained glass window dominates the far wall, while six green candlesticks carved to look like writhing trees light the room. A large round dais of stone sits in one corner of the room.

Success at a DC 40 check made to Identify Magic while studying the stone dais reveals that it once functioned as a portal to come and go from the First World, but that functionality has been lost. Nonetheless, the dais does have a useful feature, for any attempt to teleport to this dais automatically bypasses the @UUID[.JcAvEG7qrQeNWnPF]{teleport trap} that wards the House. Nyrissa isnt aware of this strange side effect yet, but each time the PCs use this to teleport to area @UUID[.zsReYKTm9pOYrbYZ]{K11}, roll a @Check[type:perception|dc:50] check for Nyrissa to determine if she notices the strange fluctuation in the Houses ambient magic. If she does, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.R9xqCBblkS5KE4y7]{sending} to order one of her minions to investigatethe Wriggling Man is the most likely choice. Once shes made aware of what caused the fluctuation, Nyrissa manipulates the Houses magic; an hour later, this dais loses all magical properties, potentially setting up a shock to the PCs the next time they try to teleport to this room.

@UUID[Actor.38RAf2sgbE9Rn1kn]{Jade Candlesticks}: The six intricately carved jade candlesticks are worth 5,000 gp each.
K11. Teleporter Entrance.name: K11. Teleporter Entrance

Day 17: The Knurly Briars.name: Day 17: The Knurly Briars
Day 17: The Knurly Briars.text:
Scene

@UUID[Scene.hKVIiPI9XsBMWuf1]{The Knurly Briars}

This bloom links the Stolen Lands to the not-quite-abandoned Knurly House.

Location: A hill or plains hex.

Bloom: This bloom manifests in an immense mound of creeping briars and brambles. These hideous, fast-growing brambles extend from the unkempt yard of the Knurly House, the home of a bitter and wretched hag known as the Knurly Witch.

The brambles and briars grow to a height of 15 feet, creating heavy undergrowth (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 514), making it difficult for creatures to move around. Their sharp thorns are mobile and angry, functioning as hazardous terrain. A creature that takes two Move actions in a round in this hex takes [[/r 2d6[piercing]]] damage from the thorns at the end of their turn, or [[/r 4d6[piercing]]] if they take three Move actions.

@UUID[Actor.fbsy6zPV4HjHiis7]{Bloomborn Athachs (3)}

Severe 17

While the Knurly Witch herself doesnt emerge from her house in the Stolen Lands, her presence can be felt throughout these briars in the form of half-heard cackles, insensible mutterings, and brief glimpses of a strange but towering humanoid shape moving just out of sight through the brambles. These shapes are the gardeners of the Knurly Briars, immense and hideously malformed athachs.

As the Knurly Witchs gardeners, these athachs carry sickles and large bags of strangely pulsating seeds. They move through the brambles, pruning back dead plants and harvesting the eerie red seeds that periodically grow on the vines, only to replant the seeds in the ground. It is this act of pruning and seeding that keeps this bloom growing; if all of the athachs are slain, the bloom reacts by causing the brambles and vines to shriek and whip about in a frenzy. All creatures in the brambles at this time take [[/r 8d6[slashing]]] damage from the thorns (@Check[type:reflex|dc:35|basic:true] save). One round after the death of the last athach, a foul-smelling pod of plant matter erupts from the ground at each location where an athach was slain. A pod takes 1 minute to grow to full size, after which a healthy new athach emerges from it and attempts to return to work. In order to defeat the bloom, all three pods (Hardness 10; HP 50 [BT 25]) must be destroyed before they can spawn. When this happens, the brambles shriek again, but instead of slashing at those caught within them, they melt away into green light and smoke, leaving behind scattered lengths of knotted vines and brambles.

@UUID[Item.IZTr2HwEIRbBSwF2]{Bloom Trophies}: Two-foot-long vines of tangled, knotted brambles, linked to the Knurly House (@UUID[.JBCvbybSaiZnm7iK]{area H}).

L1. Great Hall.name: L1. Great Hall
L1. Great Hall.text:
This huge and ornate chamber has a vaulted ceiling, with supports carved to resemble serpentine dragons holding great beams aloft. Seven statues of a beautiful woman holding a sword, or posing in a seductive way, stand against the walls, along with several chairs and tables. Two long tables with benches sit in the middle of the room astride a large marble statue of a snakelike dragon.

This room serves as a grand banquet hall for when Nyrissa has enough guests to warrant such an occasion, although she hasnt used it for this function since turning her attention to the Stolen Lands.
