The secret door to the servants wing can be found with success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check. It hasnt been opened in ages and is somewhat stuck; succeeding at a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30] check is enough to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Force it Open}.

@UUID[Actor.oM1AvORITfhzwrDk]{Barbtongued Wyverns (2)}

Low 19

A pair of Nyrissas pets, lithe and quick wyverns with long, barbed tongues capable of lashing out and pulling prey into their jaws, sleep and play in this chamber. If they sense intruders, they attack on sight, fighting to the death.

A. The Byway.text: All who travel to Thousandbreaths from other planes arrive here, at the Byway. This archway is formed by a pair of beautiful women shaped in iron. Each statue raises one hand toward the other, forming an arch; the other hand holds high a sword that bears a striking resemblance to @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}. The first time Briar is brought through this gate, it gains a Sharpness Pointas this occurs, both it and the blades of the statues momentarily glow with green light. Nyrissa notices this effect and thus knows when Briar enters Thousandbreaths, but she does not react. If the sword is in the hands of her agents, theyll bring it to her soon enough, and if it is in the hands of her enemies, she does not want to confront them and instead hopes that the various perils of Thousandbreaths finish them off.
A. The Byway.name: A. The Byway

Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms.name: Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms
Day 22. Rise of the Mire Worms.text:
A worm-infested bloom of algae, moss, and drooping swamp trees erupts into a remote part of the Hooktongue Slough.

Location: A hex in Hooktongue Slough.

Bloom: The source of this bloom is a hideous swampland in Thousandbreaths known as the Mire, a trackless, soggy realm ruled by a squirming, noxious wizard called the Wriggling Man. This dangerous foe does not enter the Material Plane with this bloom, but he does send four squirming worms cast off from his writhing body into the Stolen Lands.

@UUID[Actor.iD3YlM0QzI2SrjD6]{Mire Worms (4)}

Severe 17

Upon arriving in the swamp, the four worms grow to immense size and slither their way through the surrounding swampland, consuming any living creature they come across. These four worms travel together at a rate that matches the blooms expansionthey can always be encountered in the latest hex to be claimed by this bloom.

These so-called mire worms are hideous segmented creatures with hook-shaped jaws that extend from their rubbery maws when they bite. Each worm is also armed with a jagged, poisonous stinger-tipped tongue. They function identically to azure worms, save that their sting attack is at the tip of their tongue instead the tip of their tail.

Killing the mire worms defeats the bloom and causes their bodies to shrink back down to their original sizethe length of a human finger. Although dead, these worms continue to twitch in a most unsettling manner. The worms resemble no known species, but a @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} suggests the worm may be one from a worm that walks.

@UUID[Item.x3r5hAzgXxZN8IFD]{Bloom Trophies}: Twitching worms, linked to the Mire (@UUID[.xWZqVDCul4YpCaxc]{area G}).

C. The Frozen Boneyard.text:
Snow falls steadily in this forest glade, which appears to be an ominously oversized cemetery. Dozens of ten-foot-tall headstones rise from the snow, leaning awkwardly as if the ground below had grown unstable. An old tower leans precariously against the supportive branches of several trees at one end of the glade, while an immense marble vault looms at the other, at the edge of a frozen lake.

The temperature in this glade is extreme cold (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 518). Nyrissa rarely comes to this grove anymore; she has little interest in this frigid corner of Thousandbreaths and leaves its care to Kargstaad, a foul-tempered, four-armed frost giant who lives in the vault at the edge of the boneyards frozen lake. This glade, despite the appearance of a frozen cemetery, is not an actual cemeteryNyrissa simply found the appearance of a frozen burial ground soothing when she was in her darker moods.

The tower is little more than a spiral stair built into a 200-foot-tall circular stone shell. It is in dreadful repair but is in no danger of collapsing. The stairs end at a dizzying vantage point in the open rooftop that somehow still doesnt allow a view over the treetops.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.hYWe65P8cQyV2A0F]{Icy gravestone shards}, linked to the @UUID[.0KoVNo4JXSXcViBI]{Frozen Bloom}.

@UUID[Actor.wJDtBtvRtyxtyqHS]{kargstaad}

Moderate 18

Kargstaad and his giant followers dwell here, eternally provided for by the glade when it comes to hunting for food or water. Collected as trophies ages ago by Nyrissa, these giants know little but their lives in this glade. When this glades bloom opens, Kargstaad sends his minions through to protect the bloom, but the giants, starved for entertainment, quickly abandon it. Once the bloom closes, Kargstaad knows his giants have failed him, and the arrival of the PCs gives him an opportunity to smooth over this failure if only he can capture them for his mistress.

In combat, Kargstaad rages and charges in to engage his foes in melee. If unable to reach them, he hurls gravestones as rocks. Kargstaad fights to the death.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.0KoVNo4JXSXcViBI]{Frozen Bloom} has not been defeated, four of Kargstaads giants are encountered at his side. (The remaining two can be encountered elsewhere in Thousandbreaths as you see fit, perhaps as an encounter while traveling a pathway between glades.)
C. The Frozen Boneyard.name: C. The Frozen Boneyard

K18. Dressing Chamber.text:
This dressing room has several wardrobes and long mirrors.

@UUID[Actor.kEIkoEde7PxQUIbG]{Dressing Chamber Wardrobes}: Long-neglected clothes fill the wardrobes. There are 20 noble outfits and a similar number of courtiers outfits. A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:perception|dc:30] check finds a beautiful platinum signet ring worth 1,500 gp in the pocket of one of the noble outfits.
K18. Dressing Chamber.name: K18. Dressing Chamber

M5. The Abandoned Treasury.name: M5. The Abandoned Treasury
M5. The Abandoned Treasury.text:
This room is falling into ruin. Plaster hangs from the ceiling, furniture lies buried in fallen leaves, the walls sag, and dust covers everything. Numerous empty and toppled treasure chests strewn about the place hint that it may have once been a grand treasury.

Although it appears close to collapse, the room is structurally sound. This is indeed Nyrissas treasury, but the majority of the magical items and treasures kept here were taken long ago by the Eldest when they exacted their punishment on Nyrissa. The nymph never bothered restocking the place, instead opting to keep her greatest treasures close at hand.

@UUID[Actor.qs8IhPOOU1ICfY5g]{Nyrissa's Treasury}: The agents of the Eldest didnt take everything. A 10-minute search of this area reveals bits and pieces of treasure that still remain: a miniature castle of jade wrapped in the coils of a silver serpent (an old table centerpiece designed to hold flowers) worth 6,000 gp, a pig-shaped casket containing 999 pp with each coin set comfortably in its own velvet slot, a gold decanter bound in gold with a ruby stopper worth a total of 8,000 gp, a greater storm flash, a gold and ivory scroll tube worth 75 gp that contains a scroll of dragon form heightened to 8th level and the formula for the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.kqhPt9344UkcGVYO]{resurrect} ritual written in Sylvan, and a slightly dented helm that acts as a greater hat of the magi.

Evindras Warning.text:
The following assumes the PCs have earned @UUID[JournalEntry.yGGSDRma9yTWwdeo.JournalEntryPage.hApY4fHj30PWilNG]{Evindra}s thanks and aid, but you can provide this information via any other supernatural NPC with whom the PCs may have forged a strong relationship.

Evindra warns the PCs as this chapter begins that powerful forces from the First World are likely to be drawn to the Stolen Lands soon, for shed been charged with keeping Briar hidden by a mysterious agent of the Eldest named Weren, who told her it was important to keep Briar from the agents of the nymph queen Nyrissa. She blames herself for allowing the weapon to fall into Irovettis hands, and even though this didnt result in the swords return to Nyrissa, the close call shames and distresses Evindra for some time. Evindra responds as follows to topics that the PCs are likely to ask about.

@UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}: Evindra began her watch over Briar seven decades ago. Weren told her the sword was valuable to an upstart nymph named Nyrissathat Nyrissa desired the blade, and that the Eldest did not want her to have it. Evindra can explain to the PCs what Briar is currently capable of, and that more of its powers are likely to awaken the more its exposed to the raw energies of the First World or is used to slay denizens of that realm. While Evindra doesnt know all of Briars potential powers, she does know that, fully awakened, the sword is both intelligent and a vorpal sword, among other things. Once capable of speech, Evindra notes, Briar itself may be able to tell them more.

@UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs.JournalEntryPage.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]{Weren}: Evindra doesnt know much more about Weren. She doesnt believe thats his full name and, while he appeared to be an attractive fey man with pointed ears, orange eyes, and long fingers, the way his form shimmered a bit leads her to believe he had disguised his true form when he delivered Briar to her. She says that he was very persuasive in convincing her of how important it was to keep the sword hidden. She believed him when he said he served the direct interests of the Eldest, but the more the PCs suggest that maybe he tricked her or even used magic to compel her, the more suspicious she grows about Weren.

@UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD]{Nyrissa}: Evindra relates the legend of how Nyrissa fell in love with one of the Eldest and then how her resulting rise in power led her to proclaim herself one of the rulers of the First World. The other Eldest reacted poorly, first sending the jabberwock against her and then trying to rip her domain out from under her, but Nyrissa defeated the jabberwock and used a thousand promises of fey fealty to ward her domain. But when Nyrissas lover was exiled, she was punished. Evindra doesnt know the details of that punishment, but she does know that Nyrissa still holds a grudge against the Eldest and suspects Briar has something to do with it.

Evindra knows that Nyrissas domain is called Thousandbreaths, and that it lies close to the Material Plane in the similarly named Thousand Voices, or Forest of Breath. She knows too that Nyrissa has long had an interest in the Stolen Lands, and that many of the regions fey know of her and fear her; there are even rumors that the nymph queen walks the Stolen Lands now and then, visiting cruelties on those who annoy her and strange rewards upon those who please her. These rumors make Evindra suspect that there may be some physical connection between the Stolen Lands and the First Worldand logic would dictate that a likely place for such a connection to exist would be the depths of the forest of Thousand Voices.
Evindras Warning.name: Evindras Warning

K9. The Swill Feast.text:
This was obviously some sort of dining room. A great oak table is pushed up against one wall while several rickety chairs line the opposite wall. The rotting remnants of a vast feast lie upon the tablesilver tureens spill fungal rot, a tarnished silver salver lies ruptured on its side, and old bones cover a number of plates. The entire place reeks of garbage and decay.

@UUID[Actor.NMAvneOXrW7aRk1y]{Silver Serving Set}: This room is unremarkable, but if the silver service is cleaned, its worth 1,300 gp.
K9. The Swill Feast.name: K9. The Swill Feast

The Blooms Begin.text:
In previous chapters, the PCs could afford to take months or even years off during the course of play. If there are still parts of the Stolen Lands the PCs wish to explore, consider delaying this chapter until that itch for exploration is scratched, because once Nyrissas blooms begin to manifest, they come fast and furious. This is by designthe assault on the kingdom is meant to be swift, so the PCs should not have a lot of time to rebuild resources and recover between blooms.

The events in Part 1 take place over the course of a single month, with only a few days passing between each new manifestation of a bloom. Since a Kingdom turn lasts a month, this means that no kingdom management or development can occur during Part 1 once the blooms begin.

Assuming the PCs defeat all of the blooms and survive this month of destruction with their kingdom intact, the adventure and campaign can immediately return to a more laconic pace if you desire. After the month of destruction, if the PCs have not yet fully explored Thousandbreaths or defeated Nyrissa, theyll be rewarded for enduring that month by being able to tackle @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v]{Part Two} and @UUID[.AhoW6h9pYiABWk5K]{Part Three} of this adventure at a pace of their own choosingalthough if they take too long, you should feel free to have Nyrissa start a second or even a third round of blooms.

All of the events detailed in this part start with a date listed as Day 1, Day 14, Day 27, and so on. Its convenient if you set Day 1 on the first day of the month, but its not required. If you start the month on a day other than the first, though, you should delay the next @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.406nR8T69GIGW6bc]{Kingdom turn}, having it play out at the end of this part.

When a PC encounters a bloom, success on a @Check[type:nature|dc:36|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:34|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} confirms that the incident is caused by a planar breach between the Material Plane and the First World, although the breach is not large or stable enough to allow creatures to cross between the planes. Learning the same information about a bloom the PCs have not personally visited is possible, but the DC is increased by 10.

Bloom Effects on the Kingdom

When a bloom manifests, it does so in a single hex somewhere in the Stolen Lands. Most blooms are assigned a type of hex that it can appear inthe exact hex in which the bloom appears is left to you to determine, although the hex containing the PCs capital should never be chosen. Once a bloom manifests, that hex is lost from the PCs kingdom (see @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.kitlt28oPiGVyHCH]{Kingdom Statistics} for the repercussions of losing a hex). If a bloom is defeated, the hex remains lost and must be reclaimed before it is returned to the PCs kingdom.

Once a bloom appears, it spreads at a rate of 1 hex per day into a single adjacent, unbloomed hex, determined randomly. The original hex always remains the core hex in which the mechanism for defeating the bloom remains. When a bloom is defeated, all hexes it has spread into revert to normal (but must be reclaimed individually).

Noticing the Blooms

Although a newly formed bloom is obvious to those in the hex in which it appears, it sometimes takes time for word to spread. In particular, the first bloom may well catch the PCs off guard as theyre unlikely to be expecting such an event.

If the PCs enter a hex containing a bloom, either on the day it manifests or thereafter, they automatically notice the bloom. Otherwise, each time a bloom manifests, use the secret Notice Bloom activity to determine how long it takes before news of the new bloom reaches the PCs attention. Once the PCs have learned of the first bloom, they can use the Bloom Watch downtime activity to actively search the Stolen Lands for undiscovered blooms.

Notice Bloom r

  • Secret

Trigger A bloom manifests in the Stolen Lands.

When a bloom manifests, its effects are not subtle. Nonetheless, it can take some time for witnesses to report the bloom to the PCs. When a bloom begins, roll a secret kingdom skill check to determine how long it takes before the PCs learn about it.

If the bloom manifests in an unclaimed hex, roll a @Check[type:exploration|dc:35|traits:action:notice-bloom|roller:party] check.

If the bloom manifests in a claimed hex, roll a @Check[type:defense|dc:30|traits:action:notice-bloom|roller:party] check; if the hex contains a settlement, the result is automatically improved by one degree of success.

If the bloom manifests in the kingdoms capital, or in a hex thats currently occupied by a PC, the check is automatically a critical success.

  • Critical Success The PCs automatically learn about the bloom the same day it manifests.

  • Success The PCs automatically learn about the bloom [[/gmroll 1d4]] days after it manifests.

  • Failure The PCs automatically learn about the bloom [[/gmroll 2d4]] days after it manifests.

  • Critical Failure The PCs wont automatically learn about the bloom; they must discover it via the Bloom Watch activity or by entering the blooms hex.

Bloom Watch

  • Concentration
  • Downtime

You spend the day working with agents in your nation examining field reports, speaking with scouts, listening to rumors, interviewing allies, or researching with divination magic to try to pinpoint the locations of undiscovered blooms. Attempt a @Check[type:defense|dc:40|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] or @Check[type:survival|dc:40|traits:action:bloom-watch] check, a @Check[type:intrigue|dc:36|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] (expert) or @Check[type:perception|dc:36|traits:action:bloom-watch] (expert) check, or a @Check[type:magic|dc:32|traits:action:bloom-watch|roller:party] (master) or @Check[type:nature|dc:32|traits:action:bloom-watch] (master) check.

  • Critical Success Choose a hex on the map of the Stolen Lands. You discover the two closest undiscovered blooms to that hex. If there are no undiscovered blooms currently active, your research notes a growing magical energy in the hex where the next bloom will manifest. This doesnt indicate when that bloom will occur, but it does allow the PCs to prepare to handle that bloom when it occurs (for example, if a PC is present in that hex when the bloom manifests, they automatically know its happening).

  • Success Choose a hex on the map of the Stolen Lands. You discover the two closest undiscovered blooms to that hex. If there are no undiscovered blooms currently active, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus on the next Notice Bloom reaction.

  • Failure If there are undiscovered blooms in claimed hexes, you discover the closest one to your location.

  • Critical Failure You fail to determine the location of any undiscovered blooms.

Defeating Blooms

As blooms manifest, the PCs can defeat them. The method of defeating each bloom is different. Once a bloom is defeated, the PCs can harvest special trophies that allow them to enter and navigate Thousandbreaths with increasing ease; theyll need at least three different types of bloom trophy before they can even open the portal to Thousandbreaths at the start of @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v]{Part Two}.

When the PCs defeat a bloom, the strange energies and First World power are released in a dramatic way. The energy suffusing the area rises up from the surrounding terrain in a vortex of green light and a high-pitched keening not unlike the sound of a mortally wounded rabbit or deer. This energy is eerie and disturbing, but ultimately harmless, and it disperses quickly. The majority of the energy returns to Thousandbreaths, though a number of objects at each bloom site are infused with a small bit of power turning them into bloom trophiesitems that are magically linked to a specific area of Thousandbreaths. Each bloom encounter lists the type of object that becomes its bloom trophy along with its linked area. A dead creature that becomes a bloom trophy does not decay, cannot be transformed into an undead, and wont be eaten by scavengers (such as maggots) for 100 days.

Bloom trophies radiate strong conjuration and transmutation magic. A successful DC 35 check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.eReSHVEPCsdkSL4G]{Identify Magic} allows a PC to note that the item has become infused with the blooms energies and now holds within it a magical link between the object and the First World. A character carrying a bloom trophy receives a +1 status bonus on attack rolls, weapon damage rolls, skill checks, saving throws, and ability checks while in the trophys linked area in Thousandbreaths.

Bloom Growth

While the exact nature of each bloom varies, all of themsave for the @UUID[.AMmC4r0Kija5A9XZ]{Whirling Lake} (below) and @UUID[.2k8Sa5ntykeuBzZB]{Nights of Dread}cause vegetation in their hexes to grow rampant and uncontrolled. These hexes are treated as difficult terrain as a result, and the DC of Survival checks attempted in them is increased by 5.
The Blooms Begin.name: The Blooms Begin

Part 1: A Month of Destruction.text:
The PCs should be 17th level when this month of destruction begins.

It has been said that to look into the future and to see ones fate is the surest way to meet it. Such worries have bothered @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD]{Nyrissa}, who has long feared that heroes would come to her home and defeat her with a sword forged from her own fractured spirit. Though she has hoped this vision was but a nightmare, it was not until the Age of Lost Omens brought an end to the tyranny of prophecy that she began to hope that her future was not writ in stone.

Yet she is taking no chances. In order to fully deny this vision, she hopes to reclaim @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}, mend her own shattered spirit, and remove from existence the very weapon so long ago foretold to herald her death. Yet in taking these steps, she may have empowered the very heroes that could be her undoing.

Awakening Briar

If the PCs havent recovered @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}, you should give them a chance to do so by letting them further explore Irovettis palace, perhaps at the advice of an NPC ally if the PCs dont seem eager to continue exploring the location. When the PCs recover the sword, its a +3 greater striking cold iron bastard swordbut as this chapter progresses, Briar becomes much more powerful, not only becoming a potent weapon against its source, Nyrissa, but also serving a critical role against the Lantern King himself in @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs]{Chapter 11}.

The process of awakening Briar and its accumulating powers are detailed @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{here}.

Kingdom in the Background

When this chapter begins, the PCs kingdom has grown to encompass the majority of the Stolen Lands. Pitax has been welcomed into the nation, and the people of the kingdom are finally able to relax after the trauma of war recedes. Of course, a new threat is about to strike, but since the kingdom building part of the campaign has more or less concluded, you can simply run this chapter as-is without having to catch the players up on their kingdoms growth.
Part 1: A Month of Destruction.name: Part 1: A Month of Destruction

Nyrissas Revenge.text:
Nyrissa doesnt take an active part in the defense of her House until the PCs confront her in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7}. Until then, she focuses on preparing to absorb the Stolen Lands into the Apology.

If the PCs have already defeated this plan, either by enduring the month of destruction or by uprooting Thousandbreaths, Nyrissas plans shift to vengeance. The PCs have foiled her plans, but if she can defeat them and recover @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}, she hopes that she might be able to sidestep the final kingdom needed to fill the Apology. As long as the PCs remain in the House, she bides her time in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7}, but if the PCs retreat back to the Material Plane, Nyrissa sends agents to attack them. She draws these agents from the First World via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZc8ZwtsyWnxUUW0]{primal call}, calling upon four of her defaced nymphs to serve as secondary casters.

  • @UUID[Actor.edP108Bh51Ktxn9T]{Elite Primal Bandesnatch}
  • @UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]{Elite Sard}
  • @UUID[Actor.ap9Q8j7pjLAhHHSZ]{Elite Terotricus}

Nyrissa's Revenge

Low 19

Nyrissa performs this ritual in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7}, which alters the way the ritual functions. Here, the chance to perform primal call is a DC 35 check. The ritual, if successful, manifests a creature from Thousandbreaths itself. Nyrissa must still expend ingredients when she performs the ritual. If Thousandbreaths has been uprooted, this energy is drawn instead from the House at the Edge of Timeall that remains in the demiplane. In this case, Nyrissa and the defaced nymphs suffer a 4 circumstance penalty to their skill checks to perform the ritual.

Nyrissa always performs this @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZc8ZwtsyWnxUUW0]{primal call} ritual at 10th level. She uses it to call an elite primal bandersnatch, elite sard, or elite terotricus, varying her choice each time so that the PCs wont quite know what to expect. Each attempt at the ritual costs her 200 gp in resources, drawn from the supplies in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7}; she has enough supplies to attempt the ritual 10 times. She doesnt need to offer additional payment to the creature, and she sends it on its way into the Material Plane to track down and attack the PCs. The creature manifests at the Castle of Knives (encounter site @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]{TV1}) in Thousand Voices. How it tracks down and attacks the PCs is left to you to determine.

Nyrissa continues performing primal call rituals in this way daily. Once she depletes her resources for casting the ritual, or once she rolls a critical failure on her check, she can no longer pursue this avenue of vengeance. Unwilling to leave her demiplane or to risk the Houses actual guardians, Nyrissa now turns her attention to hunkering down and waiting out the PCs. Itll take her years to refocus her attentions on a new kingdom on a different world to attempt to gain her final apologyif it comes to this, the PCs can simply leave her alone and this chapter concludes. Yet the campaign continues, for the Lantern King himself grows impatient if this stalemate continues for too longsee @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs]{Chapter 11} for details.
Nyrissas Revenge.name: Nyrissas Revenge

L7. Throne Room Bridge.name: L7. Throne Room Bridge
L7. Throne Room Bridge.text:
This walkway crosses over the throne room (area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u]{K17}) below. The door to area @UUID[.2RWV0uhIckv9e10j]{L8} is one of the few that is kept locked. It is made of ironwood (Hardness 22, HP 100 [BT 50]) and it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Forced Open} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:41|traits:action:force-open] (expert) check or its Lock can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Picked} with a @Check[type:thievery|dc:39|traits:action:pick-a-lock] (master) check.

Development: If the Wriggling Man has not yet been encountered, hell react to intruders on this bridge as detailed in area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u]{K17}.

J. The High Folly.name: J. The High Folly
J. The High Folly.text:
Thousands of mossy stone statues, each depicting a different creature, stand in this grassy clearing. At the clearings center rises a low but strangely round hill, atop which rises a three-hundred-foot-high tower of white stone.

This glade contains the High Folly, a gatehouse that watches over the only path that leads to Nyrissas home. The field of statues is an entire army of petrified First World monstrositiesa stone army that Nyrissa has been collecting with the aid of her medusa ally Phomandala (see area @UUID[.8sZ4iXozKx9wHzp8]{M3}) for many years. When the @UUID[.iGUBEHB2bWskpRFL]{War of the High Folly} begins on day 26 of the month of destruction, this final bloom restores this army to flesh, and they are unleashed upon the PCs capital city. Here on the First World, though, they are harmless. If the PCs have already defeated the War of the High Folly bloom, this clearing is empty of statues, and only the white stone towerthe High Folly itselfremains.

The High Folly is a hollow tower within which a single curving stairway rises to an observation platform under open roofsthe structure and purpose of the tower is similar to the leaning tower in @UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN]{area C}, but a character who looks out from this towers observation platform can see all of Thousandbreaths laid out belowalmost exactly how the @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg.JournalEntryPage.71I38vDWfJaf8A1g]{map} at the end of Zuddigers Picnic shows.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.2OZvR3q1KRX0PR6a]{Handfuls of sand} taken from the scar left by the High Follys passing, linked to the @UUID[.iGUBEHB2bWskpRFL]{War of the High Folly} bloom.

Ilthuliak terrorized the River Kingdoms of Pitax and Mivon as well as Numeria and Brevoy in her youth. She murdered and ate all would-be dragonslayers who hunted her, eventually attracting Nyrissas attention. The nymph wooed Ilthuliak to relocate her lair to the High Folly with promises of power, treasure, and glory soon after the Stolen Lands drew her attention about two decades agoand so far, Nyrissa has made good on those promises.

@UUID[Actor.n82GZhM6joceE91v]{Ilthuliak}

Severe 18

Ilthuliak remains vigilant at all times in the shadows atop the High Folly, a light sleeper and a keen observer as she looks out over the surrounding glade. If she notices the PCs approaching, she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx]{time stop}, then uses that opportunity to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wfleiawxsfhpRRwf]{disappearance}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OOELvfkTedBMlWtq]{spell turning}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.uqlxMQQeSGWEVjki]{true seeing}, while positioning herself in the air so she can use her breath weapon to maximum potential on the first round of combat when time stop ends. She opens combat with her breath weapon, following up with a few rounds flying overhead and casting spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.37ESlJzUvVbOudOT]{reverse gravity}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2w4OpAGihn1JSHFD]{black tentacles}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qDjeG6dxT4aEEC6J]{weird}. Once her breath weapon has recharged, she swoops down to land amid the PCs to make good use of it, then loses herself in the glory of melee battle, periodically taking to the sky to cast a few more spells. Ilthuliak fights to the death.

@UUID[Actor.O1Jd6pN97AFJlmw9]{Ilthuliak's Hoard}: Ilthuliaks treasure lies atop the High Folly in an impressive mound at the center of the observation platform. This hoard consists of 57,000 cp, 4,800 sp, 1,900 gp, 120 pp, a silver scepter set with strips of jet and ivory worth 250 gp, a darkwood jewelry box worth 100 gp that contains a tangle of costume jewelry and one necklace of precious gems worth 1,200 gp, a strange chunk of amber in which is trapped a mosquito that seems to have tiny hands at the tips of its feet (this strange bauble is worth 900 gp as long as the truth of it being a fanciful hoax remains obscureda successful DC 35 Crafting check reveals the truth and its actual price of 5 gp), and assorted additional gemstones and minor trinkets worth an additional 1,000 gp. In addition, her lair contains several potent magic items: a +2 greater striking returning thundering starknife, bracers of armor type II, a cassock of devotion, a cloak of the bat, a moderate thurible of revelation, a rod of negation, and a circlet of persuasion.

Day 30. Months End.text:
On day 30 of the month of destruction, the event ends in one of two ways.

One or more blooms remain active: Nyrissa can attempt to take the Stolen Lands out of the Material Plane and into the Apology. She must attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:19] to do this if there is only a single active bloom. For each additional bloom that remains active, the DC is reduced by 2. If shes successful, consult @UUID[.k2Llwg0jHjCQQWfs]{Concluding the Chapter} for the ramifications of this disastrous development. If she fails, all of the blooms collapse, and she must wait [[/gmroll 1d6]] months before attempting the theft again by causing new blooms. In this event, feel free to re-use some of the blooms presented on the previous pages, or use them as inspiration for designing blooms of your own.

No blooms remain active: The PCs have thwarted Nyrissas plans for now, but in time she can start the process all over again. She must wait [[/gmroll 2d6]] months before starting a new month of destruction in order to attempt to take the Stolen Lands again. This should give the PCs plenty of time to begin rebuilding their kingdom, and to take the fight to the nymphs own realm of Thousandbreaths. During this time, the PCs should either encounter minor blooms of strange plant life, or hear rumors of such, so that they know that while the threat posed by the previous month of destruction has passed, another one could well be looming in the near future. A character who studies one of these smaller blooms can attempt a @Check[type:nature|dc:38] or @Check[type:religion|dc:38] check can confirm that the danger has only been stalleda critical success at this check gives the character the exact number of months remaining before Nyrissa starts a brand new bloom.
Day 30. Months End.name: Day 30. Months End

M1. Attic.name: M1. Attic
M1. Attic.text:
The wooden floor of this attic space is covered with thick layers of dust. Cobwebs hang in curtain-like sheets, and four skeletons slump against the southern wall. A ladder leads up to a trap door in the ceiling in one corner, with tendrils of thick roots pressing through around its edges from above.

The stairs lead down to area @UUID[.jYQkG4h3ci9x0cbG]{L4}. The trap door leads up to @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]{M2} but is overgrown above by vines and roots, and as such must be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Forced Open} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.IA0r4dD0J3R6SMxT]{M1 - Toggle Trapdoor Visibility}

Reveals the trapdoor hidden underneath the vines in area @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]{M2.}

@UUID[Actor.M6RknN77XTo23v45]{Banshees (4)}

Moderate 19

This room has long been abandoned. The skeletal remains are those of four powerful elven priestesses of Calistria, enemies Nyrissa captured and imprisoned after her first absorbed kingdom. Rather than transform into ghosts like the other heroes Nyrissa captured, these four priestesses became banshees after finally dying of old age in this room. They rise up instantly as soon as they notice intruders, and fight until destroyed, but even in undeath they cannot leave this room. Unlike the ghostly guards, their religious drive for vengeance has been only magnified in undeath, and as such they do not bear shame at their fate.

K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds.text:
This salon is decorated with vivid frescoes depicting primeval forests filled with floral blooms and beautiful women. Two plush sofas sit against the walls, while three low tables in the middle of the room hold beautiful floral arrangements. The sounds of some sort of celebration may be heard in this room as if from a great distance.

@UUID[Actor.MABh0eh1VKh3izdf]{Eldritch Echoes}

Complex hazard 20

The faint sounds of celebration are phantoms and echoes from the past; the longer one remains in this room, the more the listener loses track of whether its the sounds themselves that are distant or if its themselves who are distant, being pushed away out of time and space by eldritch forces.

A PC who is under the protection of the Helix Theorem applies their +4 status bonus to all rolls and checks made against this hazard.

@UUID[Actor.PioS4R4ch9JWEsaw]{Platinum Flute}: The decor in this room is elegant and impressive, but the expensive furniture decays to rot and mold if brought out of the room. Nonetheless, a 10-minute @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Search} of the room and success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check are enough to discover a slender platinum flute under one of the sofa cushions. This flute is a greater maestros instrument.
K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds.name: K13. Salon of Confusing Sounds

Day 16. The Frozen Bloom.text:
An incursion of giants from a frozen graveyard ruled by a deadly, four-armed warlord in Thousandbreaths accompanies a bloom of ice and snow.

Location: A mountain hex.

Bloom: Snow begins falling over this hex regardless of weather conditions in the skies above. The vegetation that blooms and grows here consists of tangles of alpine shrubbery, twisted pine trees, and sheets of thick, slippery lichen. The temperature in this area drops to extreme cold (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 517), and bodies of water in the region freeze over.

An intimidating link to Thousandbreaths rises in this blooma towering, 30-foot-tall gravestone made of ice and inscribed with a thousand names manifests at the center of the hex. The language of these names appears to be in each readers native tongue, and anyone who thinks to look for their own names or the names of friends or family invariably finds them on the gravestone with eerie speed. To destroy this bloom, the massive ice gravestone must itself be destroyed. The gravestone is 10 feet wide and as hard as stone (Hardness 14, HP 150 [75 BT]). It can be knocked over with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:45] check made as a three-action Manipulate activity; the DC decreases to @Check[type:athletics|dc:35] if the gravestone is below its Broken Threshold. Knocking the gravestone over in this way destroys it. The gravestone is immune to acid damage but has weakness 15 to fire and sonic damage. Cold damage repairs the gravestone for a number of Hit Points equal to the damage the cold would normally have inflicted; the freezing temperatures in the bloom repair damage done to the gravestone at the rate of 15 Hit Points per turn. If destroyed, the icy gravestone topples and shatters into countless razor-sharp shards, each the size of a dagger; these serve as the bloom trophies.

@UUID[Actor.s0BfmFWAhLQkQEbg]{Kargstaad's Giants (6)}

Severe 17

When this bloom opens, a four-armed frost giant named Kargstaad sends six hearty frost giants from Thousandbreaths through to hold the region; Kargstaad himself remains in the @UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN]{Frozen Boneyard} (area C). These giants are natives of the First World, with skin blue as ice and eyes that glow with white light; they heal wounds at an astounding rate and are stronger and more dangerous than normal frost giants. Once the giants arrive in the Stolen Lands, the urge to chase and crush the delightfully fragile creatures they find proves too much to resist, and they move out of the bloom to explore the Stolen Lands. The wandering band of giants can be encountered anywhere you wish, but most likely the PCs will first hear of them after they attack a small outlying village or start crushing merchant caravans. The giants meet no real opposition as they travel and raid, so they quickly come to see this worlds denizens as trivial challenges. They fearlessly fight to the death until one of them falls, forcing the others to finally appreciate that there is real danger on the Material Plane. At this point, the giants adopt a more defensive pose and make a fighting retreat back toward the bloom.

@UUID[Item.hYWe65P8cQyV2A0F]{Bloom Trophies}: Icy gravestone shards, linked to the Frozen Boneyard (@UUID[.CAA97Vaxu4bq0sdN]{area C}).
Day 16. The Frozen Bloom.name: Day 16. The Frozen Bloom

M7. The Fables.text:
For all of the impressive features possessed by the House at the Edge of Time, none can match Nyrissas greatest creation: an extradimensional tower known as the Fables. This region exists as part of the House, but not wholly in the same place or time. The Fables consist of four relatively tiny, unique, and overlapping demiplanes nested within the demiplane that is Thousandbreathseach of which are their own Fable.

Entering a Fable: Each of the four Fables are linked to a portal trigger located in the House at the Edge of Time; see the nearby table for a list of these portal triggers and their locations. These portal triggers each radiate powerful primal magic. A character can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.eReSHVEPCsdkSL4G]{Identify Magic} on a portal trigger with a @Check[type:nature|dc:40|traits:action:identify-magic] check or a @Check[type:arcana|dc:45|traits:action:identify-magic], @Check[type:occultism|dc:45|traits:action:identify-magic], or @Check[type:religion|dc:45|traits:action:identify-magic] check. (If none of your PCs are capable of this activity, you should include an opportunity for the PCs to learn how to use portal triggers in this part of the chapter, either learning from an NPC, or discovering the method of opening the portals in a journalperhaps one found in area @UUID[.3cmfbrd3de7hNKFV]{M4}.)

A PC can activate a portal trigger as if it were a magic item by performing two actionsfirst Interacting with the portal trigger and then by Envisioning a specific thought. A PC who successfully Identifies Magic while studying a portal trigger automatically learns its activating thought, as listed on the nearby table. Once a portal key is activated, the triggering creature and any number of other willing creatures within 60 feet that are chosen by the triggering creature are transported into the corresponding Fable (see the table below).

Fable Portals
Portal TriggerActivating ThoughtPortal Destination
Tallest tree in area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2}Flying as a crow through an endless forestArea M7b
Throne in area @UUID[.WJOgkOqARENBP60u]{K17}Holding court before a crowd of thousandsArea M7c
Bed in area @UUID[.2RWV0uhIckv9e10j]{L8d}Caressing or embracing a loverArea M7d
Pool in area @UUID[.WvVPzlZL3XDYxu2f]{M6}Lying on ones back on the grass in the sunArea M7a

The contents of each Fable are detailed below, but all four share similar features. When a creature first arrives in a Fable, they do so surrounded by darkness in a twenty-foot diameter room at the Fables heart. A moment later, that darkness lights up, revealing what appears to be an entire realm. In fact, this realm is a self-contained demiplane that extends out in a sphere for 100 feet from the center. Attempts to travel beyond this distance meet an impenetrable solid barrier; the world beyond exists only as an image along the Fables internal borders.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.8rUihUC2KUnMfch2]{M7. Fable Teleporter}

When navigating between Fables run this macro to dynamically move your players to their destination. It will find any player-owned and friendly tokens in the scene, pull them to the center of their Fable and then teleport them to their next location in darkness before becoming bright again.

A character can exit a Fable by standing within that central 20-foot diameter room at the core, then taking one action to Envision. This returns the character to the House at the Edge of Time adjacent to the Fables corresponding portal trigger.

The individual Fables themselves appear as follows.

Fable M7a

This Fable appears to be a boundless open field under the noontime sun on a bright summer day. In the distance, a thin line of forest obscures the horizon in all directions. The ground bisects the sphere, filling its lower half with solid earth. A sun above provides bright light in this Fable.

Fable M7b

This chamber appears to be a single, immensely tall tree that extends forever in either direction inside a silo of impenetrable green leaves, with the trees 5-foot-wide trunk rising up at the center of the sphere. The number of branches and thick, sturdy leaves allow creatures to move in any direction by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climbing} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|traits:action:climb] check. A critical failure at this check results in a heart-stopping moment when the creature experiences a disorienting fall of [[/r 1d10*10]] feet before landing prone at the place where they started the fall, taking falling damage as appropriate (this can occur even when the PC is standing on the Fables floor below). Only by deliberately Climbing or flying up or down can a character change their elevation in this Fable. The tangle of branches provides all creatures with standard cover against ranged Strikes. Shafts of sunlight filtering in from above provide bright light in this Fable.

Fable M7c

This chamber appears to be a vast stone plaza in a forest clearing under a moonlit night sky. At the center of the plaza stands a statue of Nyrissa, one arm held out as if in greeting. An inches-deep layer of crystal clear water covers the plaza itself, while the edge of the plaza (and the edge of the Fable itself) is ringed by an impenetrable forest. It is in this room that the Houses power is concentrated, and its here where Nyrissa spends much of her timefrom here, she can observe every single room in her House simultaneously as if via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.zvKWclOZ7A53DObE]{clairvoyance} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.HXhWYJviWalN5tQ2]{clairaudience}, switching her focus from one room to another by Envisioning. Nyrissa can immediately destroy any of her allies (but not intruders) in the House that she observes from here, taking a single Envisioning action to simply snuff out their lives and causing their bodies to burst. Nyrissa only uses this ability to destroy an ally who has become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.9qGBRpbX9NEwtAAr]{controlled} by or seems to be allying with the PCs (an event likely to occur only with the unfortunate mephit in area @UUID[.sIRNvGkvWITSdBni]{K20}, but if the PCs manage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]{dominate} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vLA0q0WOK2YPuJs6]{charm} an important ally, Nyrissa opts for its destruction as well). Likewise, if the PCs are about to learn something important, the nymph may well send her closest allies to intercept the PCs. Moonlight from above provides dim light in this Fable.

This fable is likely to be where the players will meet Nyrissa. See @UUID[.k2Llwg0jHjCQQWfs]{Confronting Nyrissa} for information on how that encounter unfolds.

Fable M7d

This chamber is Nyrissas private bedchamber; its lit by several everburning torches. Unlike the other three rooms, this chambers borders are those formed by the twenty-foot-tall room itself, as depicted on the map; this room is what existed at the top of the Houses tower before Nyrissa created the Fables.

@UUID[Actor.yJuzwlk8GUlxTPnB]{Fable Trophies}: If Nyrissa reclaimed Briar, the weapon lies casually tossed on the bed in area M7d. The room also contains a large number of trophies and prizes she has picked up or had her minions collect over the years, all of which have been collected from the Stolen Lands and help to focus the Fable upon this region. If these trophies are taken out of the Fable, Nyrissa cannot bottle the Stolen Lands until they are regained. These trophies consist of things such as a unicorns horn, a silver dragons claw, a tooth from Armags skull, and so on. Add other objects that the PCs at one time possessed but have since lost or sold. The more unique and recognizable these items arelike @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.DRmaSbUHZnLAZEpl]{Ovinrbaane}, the @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.e28PY873NQzsrsdj]{Oculus of Abaddon}, or the @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.i2bqAshUwNh9IClT]{Stag Lords helm}the more disturbing and shocking they will be for the PCs to find. Even items the PCs have destroyed can appear here, fully functional once more. Only if the PCs retained such treasures or locked them away safely should these things not appear here as trophies. Amid all of these treasures are numerous other obscure and expensive ritual supplies amounting to 2,000 gp in all for use in performing @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZc8ZwtsyWnxUUW0]{primal call} rituals.

Perhaps the greatest treasure in area M7d, though, is the Apology. This glowing, bejeweled chalice sits on a nightstand near the bed, nearly filled with 999 glowing grains of sandeach of which represents a previously claimed kingdom. It is into this chalice that Nyrissa hopes to place the PCs kingdom as the final grain of sand. Rules for this powerful artifact are not presented in this adventure, as its goal is to serve more of a story element than to serve as a reward for the PCs or a viable tactic for Nyrissa to use against them in the final confrontation, but a few additional notes about it appear in @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.Jm18obt6pQZCl3jf]{Appendix 4} in this book.
M7. The Fables.name: M7. The Fables

Day 9: The Horned Hunters.name: Day 9: The Horned Hunters
Day 9: The Horned Hunters.text:
Nyrissa knows that Briar can slay her, and as this chapter of Kingmaker progresses, she becomes aware of rumors that the PCs have discovered the sword. This element, seemingly fitting so perfectly into the ancient visions she received of her own death, increasingly distresses her, and on day 9 of the month of destruction, she sends a group known as the Horned Huntthe protectors and wardens of the realm of Thousandbreathsinto the Material Plane to find the PCs and secure the sword.

  • @UUID[Actor.OhuPV1g5LfejhtAz]{The Horned Hunter}
  • @UUID[Actor.kKH3uMHbVZQmEtxj]{Jotund Trolls (3)}

Encounter

Severe 17

The Horned Hunt consists of a trio of jotund trolls led by a deadly satyr ranger known as the Horned Hunter. They first appear in the Stolen Lands deep in Thousand Voices at the Castle of Knives (encounter site @UUID[JournalEntry.btt2UVnNmyuPWfHF.JournalEntryPage.rRpbmn5PXfDOTiy9]{TV1}) and immediately seek out the PCs, leaving devastation in their passing.

The Horned Hunter knows quite a bit about the PCs; assuming the PCs have displayed a tendency to protect their people, the Horned Hunter knows that the best way to lure the PCs into a conflict is to begin wreaking havoc to draw them out. If the PCs seem not to care about their people, the Horned Hunt either travels to the next bloom site to ambush the PCs when they come to defeat it, or they attempt to infiltrate the PCs homes when each of them is alone to try to take them down one at a time. How you use the Horned Hunt is up to you, but the PCs should first learn of their location and actions on this day.

When combat begins, the Horned Hunter Plays the Pipes after positioning himself to affect as many foes as possible. He then attacks with his bow, targeting one enemy at a time. Although his natural inclination is to fire upon humans before any other target, if its obvious whos carrying Briar, he and his trolls focus their attacks on that character.

If the character carrying Briar is defeated, the Horned Hunter claims the sword as soon as he can, then uses @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.F1qxaqsEItmBura2]{tree stride} as soon as possible to make his way back to the Castle of Knives to deliver Briar to Nyrissa. See @UUID[.AhoW6h9pYiABWk5K]{Part 3} for details of what happens if Nyrissa gains control of Briar in this way.

House Features.text:
Raised Alarms

The occupants of the House at the Edge of Time are aware of the PCs and await their arrival, so the structures defenders are already on high alert. If the alarm is raised, all of the Houses occupants become hypervigilant, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus on initiative checks for the next 24 hours.

The House at the Edge of Time exists in the past and the future, the maybe and the never. One room may be clean and bright while others are collapsing and decayed. Some have been damaged by the arrival of the PCs who slew Nyrissa yesterday and will do so tomorrow in this land of the impossible. Yet as strange as this warping of time may be, stranger still is the fact that such ripples and transformations remain constant, as if a storm of fractured time tore through the structure, only to be frozen forever in the middle of a chaos of a hundred different eras. This is how the House was when Nyrissa created it so long ago, and how it remains.

Doors, Walls, and Windows: The outer walls are covered in ironwood vines that have grown over the windows, effectively barring them. While these vines make climbing the walls easy (@Check[type:athletics|dc:10|traits:action:climb] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb}), they make breaking in through windows very difficult, as the vines are Hardness 22 and have 100 HP (BT 50). A character who succeeds at a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:force-open] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Force Open} the vines allows someone to bend and rip a hole in the vines large enough to admit a Medium creature. Anyone climbing the Houses outer walls quickly attracts the attention of the creatures that dwell atop the ivy tower (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{M2}), or the denizen of the courtyard (area @UUID[.sDeReU4MO5QlQDp2]{K2}).

All of the doors in the House are wooden. Each is carved with images of laughing, frowning, or frightened faces and open with a touch unless otherwise indicated. All stairwells in the House are steep and function as difficult terrain. Ceiling height in the House itself is 10 feet unless otherwise indicated in the text.

Helix Theorem: A PC who was present in the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth when the Helix Theorem was successfully performed (see @UUID[JournalEntry.45g079GlbehLJpmo.JournalEntryPage.ZPtDIkEsiwPp3Gem]{The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth}) gains additional protection in the House at the Edge of Time, as the theorem bolsters their temporal presence in the flow of time. Any PC who is thus protected automatically realizes that the theorem protects them the first time they set foot in the House at the Edge of Time as they experience a disturbing sense of dj vu and a memory that almost feels as if theyre remembering something in the future that hasnt yet happened to them. At this point, the PCs know that they have gained a +4 status bonus on all saving throws made against teleportation effects or attempts to banish them to another plane while in the House at the Edge of Time. Additional protections manifest during a few specific encounters as well, as detailed belowwhen these occur, the PCs experience the same brief dj vu and strange memories of the future, alerting them that their exposure to the Helix Theorem has protected them.

In addition, any PC who is protected by the Helix Theorem in this way knows that they can reflexively shed this protection in order to manipulate time itself once only. The PC gains the following free action as long as they are in the House at the Edge of Time and is protected by the Helix Theorem.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.adventure-specific-actions.Item.LRuwz61jNmIfQYby]{Shed Time} F

Trigger You fail or critically fail a saving throw, are hit by a Strike, or would increase your @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.yZRUzMqrMmfLu0V1]{dying} conditions value.

Requirements You are located in the House at the Edge of Time (including any of Nyrissas fables) and are currently under the protection of the Helix Theorem.

You shed the timeline you currently occupy, then return to it once the triggering event passes. The exact effects depend on the nature of the triggering effect, as detailed below. You are no longer protected by the Helix Theorem; once this protection is lost, it cannot be regained.

Failed Saving Throw: Shift the degree of success up from Failure to Success, or a Critical Failure up to a Failure, for the triggering saving throw.

Hit by a Strike: If the triggering Strike was a Critical Success, change it to a Success. If the triggering Strike was a Success, change it to a Failure.

Increase to Dying Condition: Instead of increasing your dying condition, you lose the dying condition.

Phantoms: The House is full of phantoms of yesterday and tomorrow. They can be glimpsed in mirrors, the scent of their perfume lingers at times in the air, and the meals they have yet to eat lie steaming on the table. The PCs are occasionally able to see or hear these phantoms, if only briefly. These phantoms can variously be of people and creatures they do not recognize, but now and then the phantoms draw from the PCs own minds, pasts, and futuresthese phantoms might remind the PCs of allies, old enemies thought dead, or even younger or older versions of themselves. In some cases, these temporal phantoms can actually interact with the presentthe text of the encounter provides details as to where these effects can occur. In others, you should feel free to liven up an otherwise empty room with a strange glimpse of something half-seen or partially heard as you see fit.

Static Time: Features in the House can be altered (walls destroyed, doors bashed down, windows broken, furniture burnt, and denizens slain), but the contents of the House periodically reset as long as Nyrissa still lives. This reset occurs each time the PCs leave Thousandbreaths for any amount of time, unless they manage to uproot the demiplane. In this case, with the Houses glade being the only part remaining, the reset occurs 24 hours after the PCs leave the House; if the PCs return before this time passes, the reset doesnt occur and the next time they leave, the 24-hour countdown begins anew.

When the House resets, broken doors reform, windows become unbroken, destroyed and disarmed traps rebuild themselves, and so on. Any resident of the House is restored to full Hit Points, and any ongoing affliction or magical effect that hampers them is subjected to a counteract attempt by the House, which has a 10th-level counteract check of [[/r 1d20+35]]. Residents that are killed remain dead, and when the PCs next return, any remains left behind have decayed away to skeletons as if years had passed. Residents that have been relocated to another plane entirely are similarly not restored by the Houses reset. Any items (such as treasure) the PCs brought with them out of the House when it resets do not vanish, but upon returning to the rooms where they found these items, the PCs discover phantasmal images of the removed items lingering in the places where they were originally found.

Warped Dimensions: Time is not the only thing thats warped in the Housethe dimensions themselves are as well. In most cases, these manifest as strange curiosities, such as the elevation change in the courtyard not being reflected in the surrounding House itself, or the inverted storeroom at area @UUID[.GTFGgSdMJ5uJIMCj]{K8}, or simply the fact that while some of the rooms have different ceiling heights or floor depths when explored, the exterior of the House suggests each floor has a constant level.

Of greater concern, though, is how teleportation effects function in the House. When a visitor to the House attempts any teleportation action, allow them a @Check[type:perception|dc:40] (master) check (or @Check[type:perception|dc:35] for any PC under the influence of the Helix Theorem) to notice something strange going on with the magic as they begin the actionthe effect simply seems off. The PC can halt the action at this point without losing the resource to teleport. If the PC doesnt notice the strange sensation or proceeds to take the action anyway, they activate the Houses teleport trap. This trap does not affect any natives to Thousandbreaths or the House itself (including those like the Knurly Witch who have acclimated to the demiplane over time).

@UUID[Actor.hW40C78kV4MBDs4v]{Teleport Trap}

Simple Hazard 19

The House at the Edge of Time folds time and space back on the target, who teleports painfully into their own body an instant before they travel.
House Features.name: House Features

G. The Mire.text:
The trail ends at a great space in the forest that opens up into a foul-smelling marsh perhaps a mile or so across.

The mires waters average 10 feet deep, but numerous crisscrossing troughs drop to depths of 30 feet throughout the swamp. Likewise, a maze of ridges that rises to within inches of the water surface (but average 1 foot below it) wind throughout the mire; a character can move through the mire along these ridges treating them as difficult terrain, but any character who makes more than one Move action in a round while walking along these ridges must succeed at a @Check[type:acrobatics|dc:30] check or slip off the edge of the ridge into one of the 30-foot-deep troughs.

Bloom Trophies: @UUID[Item.x3r5hAzgXxZN8IFD]{Twitching worms}, linked to the @UUID[.lCpKc2S7LiEpQmgd]{Rise of the Mire Worms} bloom.

@UUID[Actor.iD3YlM0QzI2SrjD6]{Mire Worms (4)}

Moderate 18

This bog is normally the den of he Wriggling Man, but Nyrissa asked him to join her in her home while she prepares to absorb the Stolen Lands. Yet the Wriggling Man has not left his swamp unguardedfour immense mire worms swim through the waters of the marsh, and they quickly surge forth to attack anyone who enters the glade.

Unbloomed: If the @UUID[.lCpKc2S7LiEpQmgd]{Rise of the Mire Worms} bloom hasnt been defeated, the PCs face an additional two mire worms here.
G. The Mire.name: G. The Mire

K2. The Great Courtyard.name: K2. The Great Courtyard
K2. The Great Courtyard.text:
This large courtyard is a two-tiered region covered with thick grass. Paths wind to and from various doors, and a single, wide flight of stairs allows easy access to the courtyards second tier, where several towering oak trees loom over the main body of the House.

A subtle but strange warping of reality exists within the boundaries of this courtyardwhile the main body of the House is all on the same level as the upper tier, the entrance to area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT]{K14} lies on the same level as the lower tier despite the fact that one can walk from area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT]{K14} to K2 via the House without seeming to change elevation. The branches of the tallest tree in the courtyard (the one just south of area @UUID[.WSfWb1KkPdkDeB0g]{K12}) are one of the four entrances to the Fablethey lead to area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7b} (see that area for how one can enter the Fable via this trees branches).

  • @UUID[Actor.XQyXoOe7FCpZilaF]{Lesser Jabberwock (Moderate 19)}
  • @UUID[Actor.VQDUcDvomaNuiJGQ]{Elite Sard (Low 19)}

Encounter

Varies 19

The guardian of the Great Courtyard is a huge and dangerous creaturebut its nature depends on whether the PCs have already encountered and slain the lesser jabberwock at the end of Part 1. If the events of @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt]{Day 28} have yet to occur, then the lesser jabberwock still lurks here amid the trees of the courtyards upper tier. If, on the other hand, the lesser jabberwock has already been slain, Nyrissa has replaced it with the less dangerous but equally enormous sard from area @UUID[.Bz3CEwlEfOKy8TqS]{M2}. In either case, the monstrous guardian wont pursue foes into the House itself, but it will chase intruders for several minutes if they attempt to flee the region.

Confronting Nyrissa.text:
Nyrissa spends most of her time in area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7c} so she can track visitors and intruders in her House, and she goes there as soon as the PCs arrive. If she has reclaimed @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar}, she has placed the sword in her personal chambers (area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7d}). Regardless, she watches the PCs progress through her lair with amusement and, perhaps, a growing sense of worry.

Nyrissa has spent a significant portion of her long years brooding over what she regards as an unjust exile and plotting violent revenge against the Eldest, whose power she still considers to be hers by right. She sees the PCs as the latest manifestation of this betrayalbe it pawns of her enemies or upstarts who dont know their place. If the PCs enter one of the Fables other than area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7c}, she uses Switch Fable to confront the PCs one round later, after she casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.2Vkd1IxylPceUAAF]{regenerate} on herself.

If the PCs still possess @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.vcs1LE9FHFZEQber]{Briar} when they confront Nyrissa, she demands it be handed over to her at once. If the PCs deny her, or if they dont have Briar with them, she attacks at once.

@UUID[Actor.j7fPCy71EfQL1KmU]{Nyrissa}

Extreme 19

In combat, Nyrissa uses flight to stay at range and relies on her spells and Focus Beauty ability. On the first three rounds of combat, she uses Quickened Casting to cast defensive spells (typically @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.aqRYNoSvxsVfqglH]{freedom of movement}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.j8vIoIEWElvpwkcI]{mirror image}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.uqlxMQQeSGWEVjki]{true seeing}), using her remaining actions to cast offensive spells or avoid melee. She saves @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{wish} to recover from damage or debilitating effects, or to duplicate a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.bay4AfSu2iIozNNW]{banishment} spell heightened to 9th level to force the PCs back to the Material Plane if they reduce her to fewer than 200 HP or otherwise significantly threaten her. Keep in mind that Nyrissa is both very intelligent and has been watching the PCs for most of the campaign, particularly as they explored her House, and as such you should take some time to adjust her tactics to be specifically tailored against the PCs as you see fitalthough the focus of her attacks should usually remain a character who wields Briar against her.

If the PCs have already managed to uproot Thousandbreaths, Nyrissas confidence is shaken and she is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{frightened 1} during her first combat with the PCs; this condition is removed if the PCs retreat from a fight, allowing her confidence to return. The DC to Forgive Foe on Nyrissa if Thousandbreaths is uprooted is reduced to 46.

If Nyrissa is reduced to fewer than 100 hit points, she Switches Fables if she can to recover as best she can before returning to face the PCs again a minute later if they remain in a Fable. If she cant Switch Fables, she instead exits the Fable normally, returning to that Fables linked portal trigger area. If the PCs prevent her from reaching the central 20 feet of a Fable and she has no further avenue of escape, she calls for a truce to speak to the PCs.

In this case, or if the PCs manage a critical success against her with Forgive Foe, or if the PCs manage to defeat her and capture her alive, they can speak to her as detailed at the start of Chapter Eleven.

Concluding the Chapter

With Nyrissas defeat, a great threat to the PCs kingdomindeed, all of the Stolen Landsis removed. If the nymph dies (likely to an unfortunate beheading from a sword forged of her own capacity to love), a strange and violent transformation ripples through Thousandbreaths. If it hasnt yet been uprooted, it is uprooted immediatelyincluding the House at the Edge of Time. The House quickly crumbles and suffers thousands of years of erosion at once as if inflicted by constricting vegetation, rainfall, lightning strikes, and subsidence, effectively transforming into the ruins known today as the Castle of Knives. The Fables vanish, leaving behind area @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{M7d} as a normal room at the top of the tower. If the PCs were in another Fable at this time, they appear in this room. Regardless, any PCs in the House at the Edge of Time as it transposes to the Material Plane and erodes are protected from the swift decay all around them unless they fail a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:40] save, in which case they are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{drained 1} by the event.

During this reversion, Nyrissas body rises up on a pyre of black lightning. As it does, a terrible gale rips through all of Thousandbreaths. The Queens body acts as the center of this vortex and soon vanishes in a black pall of clouds. Within a minute, the unraveling is over. The House finishes its collapse and the surviving denizens of the building and Thousandbreaths flee into the strange new world they find themselves in.

What happens to the PCs at this point depends on Nyrissa's fate, and is detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.fGmovu4cjIsUnACs.JournalEntryPage.dFEosCwJy4YHyty4]{Chapter 11}. While the PCs have defeated Nyrissa, one danger remains: it wont be long before the @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.3pWxyt1JN8VaDS2y]{Lantern King} makes his frustrations known.
Confronting Nyrissa.name: Confronting Nyrissa

Part 3: House at the Edge of Time.text:
The PCs should be 19th level before they enter the House at the Edge of Time.

At Thousandbreaths heart lies a House; yet this is no mortal edifice. Raised from the very fabric of reality in the First World at the height of Nyrissas power before her paramour was exiled and her love was taken from her, this mansion is known as the House at the Edge of Time for its timeless quality. It has existed unchanged for Thousandbreaths long existence, whereas the glades themselves shift and change to match Nyrissas needs and interests. On one side, the House overlooks the panorama of Thousandbreaths, while the other side looks out over time and spacean endless gulf of stars and blackness shifting between mountains that rise and fall as if erosion took but the span of a single breath to reshape the land, giving the impression that the House stands at the literal edge of Time itself.
Part 3: House at the Edge of Time.name: Part 3: House at the Edge of Time

K3. Stables.text:
Six narrow stalls line the far wall of this stable.

Soon after the PCs enter, the unsettling sight of a dead horse hanging its head miserably over a stable door confronts them. Despite appearances, this is no undead horse. Rather, these six stalls each maintain a magical steed that can be keyed to a rider by simply opening the door to a stall and beckoning the undead-looking horse out. Each of these mounts function as a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.WPKJOhEihhcIm2uQ]{phantom steed} spell heightened to 6th level. The duration of the spell begins when a steed is removed from the stall, and a replacement steed appears here 4 hours after the previous one disappears.
K3. Stables.name: K3. Stables

The Calm Before.name: The Calm Before
The Calm Before.text:
The timing of when this chapter begins is left to you to decide. If the PCs kingdom hasnt yet grown to span all four regions of the Stolen Lands, youll want to run a few more years of kingdom growth until their kingdom covers a wide enough area that when @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.vtrUtpKwKZVyLdLD]{Nyrissa} starts her assault, the PCs will be compelled to oppose her. Give them time to explore Candlemere, finish up lingering wilderness encounters, and pursue a few loose ends.

Nyrissas intrusion into the Stolen Lands can be thought of as a levee breaking. At first, the appalling weight of the First World strains at this levee like the weight of a mighty river straining to flood the adjacent kingdom. Early bloom events occur at a trickle as the First World seeps slowly into the region. These trickles quickly become full-fledged breaches as the blooms pour forth, and as these breaches grow, the danger grows as well, eventually culminating in the arrival of a deadly predator from the First Worldthe @UUID[.hWPTtnhym5ogqxSt]{jabberwock}.

You can use the following two quests to get the PCs started on preparing for Nyrissas attack on the Stolen Lands. The Houten Legacy in particular should be presented to the PCs, since obtaining a copy of @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg]{Zuddigers Picnic} before they enter Thousandbreaths can help to foreshadow @UUID[.jPyYVsL4TUqIQ32v]{Part 2} of this chapter.

The Houten Legacy

  • 30 XP

Belinda Houten wants to leave a legacy; a resplendent theater dedicated to her family name. She possesses a book that a fortune-teller told her the leaders of the Stolen Lands would someday need to fulfill their destiny, but she wont part with it until she has her buildings.

Source: Aristocrat Belinda Houten, who can live in any settlement with a Noble Villa.

Completion: Build a Theater and four Monuments in Belindas honor.

Reward: Belinda is as good as her word and presents the PCs with a mint-condition copy of @UUID[Item.3ezSi7MS1XA4RfcC]{Zuddigers Picnic} worth 5,000 gp. This books contents are presented as handouts @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg]{here}; the book's @UUID[JournalEntry.LrDehrS5VtvF7nbg.JournalEntryPage.71I38vDWfJaf8A1g]{last page} presents a map of Thousandbreaths (see also the @UUID[Scene.UBHZsJUUrunIVYXl]{Thousandbreaths} scene).

A Heroic Challenge

  • 30 XP

Hailing from Pitax and long having a reputation as the citys boldest and most successful dragonslayer, Aurex Thewsen is also an abrasive braggart. He recognizes the PCs as heroes but dares them to prove their mettle as dragonslayers and cement their legitimacy as true rulers of the Stolen Lands. Aurex himself has slain several noteworthy dragons in the River Kingdoms, but the legendary black dragon Ilthuliak eluded him. Defeating her would suffice, if the PCs were clever enough to find her and brave enough to confront her.

Source: Aurex Thewsen, Pitaxs greatest dragonslayer!

Completion: Slay @UUID[.C8iJTL8Fl1Vf7OxB]{Ilthuliak} and bring back her head.

Reward: The PCs become famed dragonslayers, their names known throughout the land. The kingdoms maximum Fame or Infamy (as appropriate) increases by 1, and Ilthuliaks remains can be used to build a Monument in a settlement without needing to expend any resources. Aurex agrees to build a Tavern in Pitax and work there as a bartender for one year, telling every patron the story of that the PCs are the greatest dragonslayers in the Stolen Lands.

K20. The Dripping Clock.text:
A large and convoluted water clock built to look like a tree, constructed of darkwood, twisted crystal, and bronze tubes, drips quietly away in this dust-layered chamber. The walls of the room are given over to bookshundreds of them.

The clock continues to tick away the seconds, never losing time as it is inhabited and constantly tended and adjusted by a water mephit named Pludock. While the mephit would never dare to neglect his duty for fear of punishment, hes a chatty creature and can be a useful source of information for the PCs. His initial attitude is indifferent. If made helpful, he happily talks with the PCs. He knows the secret of the healing pool in area @UUID[.vIA2RAVqQpXS80kT]{K14} and the danger of damaging the dancing bear in area @UUID[.QPns9JfSg5Mf6rTK]{K6}; he might be able to inform the PCs of other minor traps or beneficial areas as well. If asked about Nyrissa, he grows silent after saying, Id better not say. If forced into talking, he admits that shes likely hiding out in the @UUID[.Fj2ryHevucvhU4QK]{Fable}a chamber high above that allows her not only to manipulate things in the House but to watch over every room. When he says this, he clamps his hands over his mouth, his eyes bulge as he looks around at the corners of the room... and a moment later, he bursts into an explosion of water, slain by an unhappy Nyrissa via the Fable.

@UUID[Actor.KFf6pJmFmzj7HH9i]{Pludock}

Pludock has no desire for combat, but if hes attacked by the party, he breathes acid to keep the PCs at bay, then flees shrieking through the Houses halls, shrieking and crying in panic the whole time.
K20. The Dripping Clock.name: K20. The Dripping Clock

K14. Hall of Weeping Demons.text:
This room is lined with strange, decaying plants. An empty pool sits in its center, and the walls are decorated with hundreds of small statues of sobbing demons.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.MkkASBpevcHthArx]{K14. Toggle Pool State}}

Toggle the pool and flowers between empty and full.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Search}: Success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check notes that one of the hundreds of sobbing demons in fact appears to be laughing. Removing this demon from the shelf causes the plants in the room to bloom into life and the empty pool to fill with water as the weeping demon statues cry streams of real tears that run down to collect in the center of the room.

The pool takes 1 minute to fill completely, after which success on a DC 36 check to Identify Magic reveals its properties: The water casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.SnaLVgxZ9ryUFmUr]{restoration} heightened to 6th level on anyone who steps into the pool, and also restores 150 HP. Each use causes the pool to shrink in size; there is enough water in the pool for three such uses.

The room recharges when the House resets, as long as Thousandbreaths hasnt been uprootedin this case, the room does not recharge once the pools three uses have been consumed.
K14. Hall of Weeping Demons.name: K14. Hall of Weeping Demons

M3. The Ruined Halls.name: M3. The Ruined Halls
M3. The Ruined Halls.text:
This series of rooms, once Nyrissas private sanctuary, suffered greatly from the nymphs frustrations and wrath after she survived the Eldests attempt to have her killed by the Jabberwock, and as such serves as an exception to the rule elsewhere in the house that its nature has remained unchanged since its construction. She never bothered restoring these rooms and instead converted the suite at area @UUID[.2RWV0uhIckv9e10j]{L8} to serve as her new private quarters, leaving this area in shambles. Today these rooms are a tangle of thick, creeping vines and plants that have grown riotously to a height of two feet throughout the area, making this entire area greater difficult terrain. In addition, a large number of damaged or destroyed statues of all manner of creatures lie strewn about the place; these were left by this areas dangerous guardian.

When Nyrissa first began experimenting with the jabberwocks blood in her efforts to create a lesser version of the creature, one of her first attempts involved infusing creatures with the ichor. All but one of these experiments died, but the survivor, a medusa named Phomandala, transformed into a scaly but quite healthy monster with a pair of sizable cobras amid the smaller tangle of her serpentine hair. Phomandala has lived in these ruined halls ever since, serving as a guardian for the upper floors of the House. Over the years, the infusion of jabberwock blood and her life on the First World have slowly granted magical powers as well, and the medusa is now a powerful sorcerer in her own right. Her insights into the nature of primal magic have been a boon for Nyrissa as she continued to absorb kingdoms, helping her to refine the process of creating Blooms.
