C3. Ruined Manor.text:
Only the facade and part of the entry hall of this once-great manor remains standing, the rest of it appearing to have collapsed into the void below.

Add a few additional bits of description to this ruined manor so that the PCs recognize it as Lady Jamandis manor house; the fact that its incongruously located in what pretends to be the PCs capital is yet another awkward element of the Lantern Kingdoms imperfect attempt to mimic a postapocalyptic Stolen Lands kingdom.

  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]{Fetch Stalkers (2)}
  • @UUID[Item.Z5wiAJg02Ro5aMOu]{Reflected: Ivenzi}
  • @UUID[Item.5sPd7acTmz46i4t2]{Reflected: Ioseph}
  • @UUID[Actor.rkKNyFohD800rxiU]{Illusory Creature}

Encounter

Trivial 20

Another two fetch stalkers wait here, having staged a scene they hope will help the PCs waste some of their resources. The two fetches appear to be friendly NPCsif youre using the Kingmaker Companion Guide, choose some from that book who havent accompanied the PCs; otherwise, these two fetches should appear to be Ioseph Sellemius and Ivenzi, whom the PCs met in Lady Jamandis manor at the start of this campaign.

The two fetches appear to be attending a third figurea very badly wounded Lady Jamandi, who lies beaten and bloodied on a table. The fetches beg the PCs for aid in healing her. In truth, Lady Jamandi is an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.f8SBoXiXQjlCKqly]{illusory creature} cast by one of the two fetches. They hope to trick the PCs into depleting some of their healing reserves on Lady Jamandi, who wakes from the healing after a few rounds. If the PCs dont see through the ruse, the illusory Jamandi urges them to accompany her and her remaining allies south to strike at Vordakai, whom she claims just recently had to retreat after our last fightwe should strike at him before he recovers!

If the PCs fall for the ruse, the fetch stalkers from here and area @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci]{C2} lead the PCs south to area @UUID[.YkyTUz4HPWkDnHOu]{C4}, and once a fight begins there, they aid the PCs for a few rounds before turning on them and siding with the enemy. In any event, the fetch stalkers are quick to switch to combat as soon as they suspect the PCs have seen through their ruse.

Actor

@UUID[Actor.rkKNyFohD800rxiU]{Illusory Creature}

We've included a fake "hazard" that has the appearance of Lady Jamandi, so that you can use it to represent the illusory creature on the map. You may also find it useful for rolling the illusion's damage. Remember to check the text of the Illusory Creature spell if you aren't sure what the illusion is capable of!

Effect

Reflected Soul - @UUID[Item.fXeZQCEmraVYTn7M]{Jamandi Aldori}

By default, the illusory creature token uses Lady Jamandi's ordinary artwork. If you'd like her to match the fetch appearance of Ioseph and Ivenzi in this encounter, you can use the same effects that we've been applying to the Fetch Stalkers thus far to set the illusion's appearance to a Fetch version of the character!
C3. Ruined Manor.name: C3. Ruined Manor

A6. Crumbling Workshop.text:
This large, roofless structure should be described to the PCs to remind them of a guildhall, library, laboratory, or other workshop that they built in their kingdom. Itd be best if the workshop itself was based on one in which one of the PCs spent time crafting magic items or otherwise @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QyzlsLrqM0EEwd7j]{Earning a Living} over the course of the campaign to this point. Within, the roof is missing, but the PCs should find a fair amount of supplies and items that could be used as resourcessee Treasure below.

  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]{Fetch Stalker}
  • @UUID[Item.wFjP2DzJGRhex3rI]{Reflected: Gribbler}
  • @UUID[Actor.vONZlReozVCabXhq]{Collapsing Floor}

Encounter

Trivial 20

While the Lantern King delights in testing the PCs ability as they make their way up to his throne room, he also likes to think of himself as not being unfairas someone who plays by the rules (even if the rules in this case are a collection of often self-contradicting whims). Setting up Werendegar as a greeter in area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]{A3} is one such concession to playing fair, and Gribbler, a fetch stalker who takes the form of a redcap rather than of an NPC known by the PCs, is another.

Gribblers task is to welcome the PCs to the workshop, to inform them that hes here to provide what aid he can, and to show them that the workshops contents are theirs to draw upon as they see fit. Gribbler explains that the PCs are free to spend as long as they wish herebut only as long as it takes for each of them to finish a single task.

At your option, if the PCs attempt to game this system, Gribbler might grow impatient and attack. He does his best to be honest and friendly, and hell even warn the PCs about the unstable flooring to the west if he thinks that aid will help earn the PCs trust. Gribbler is true to his word in helping them with any tasks they perform herehell use the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} reaction as you see fitbut that doesnt mean hes entirely forthright.

The Lantern King has a constant telepathic link with Gribbler, and anything and everything the PCs say or do in his presence is immediately reported via this link. Gribbler tries to cover this up and becomes evasive if asked about his relationship with the Lantern King; if pressed on it, he shrieks in frustration and attacks rather than risk giving up the truth that he has been spying on the PCs.

Hazard: While the westernmost section of this building appears to be solid, if anyone walks on the floor there, it will collapse and fall away.

Macro

@UUID[Macro.fSVpkIa3fyDYXLCg]{A6 - Collapsing Floor}

Plays the sound of splintering wood as the floor collapses, then exposes the broken floorboards and the fall beneath after a brief pause. Run the macro again to restore the floor to its original state.

Treasure: This workshop can provide the PCs with supplies to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.24PSsn1SKpUwYA1X]{retrain}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.rmwa3OyhTZ2i2AHl]{craft} magic items, or pursue one Downtime activity each while trapped in the Lantern Kingdom. The supplies found here are worth 75,000 gp in all; any items or retraining the PCs pursue uses this pool of gp, and once its depleted, the workshop can no longer be used in this fashion. Its possible to transport these resources out of the Lantern Kingdom, but theyre so bulky that it should take dozens of trips.
A6. Crumbling Workshop.name: A6. Crumbling Workshop

B2. Main Hall.text:
A dining table is the focal point in this large, open hall, sitting against the middle of the southern wall and surrounded by a half-dozen comfortable-looking wooden chairs. Doors are present in every direction but north, where an archway allows passage into the bedroom beyond. Shelves and display cabinets sit against the northern wall to either side of the archway.

Elements in this room should evoke memories of living rooms and common areas in the PCs homes.

The eastern double door provides an exit from the @UUID[.Riwc58VZoiQZg1ZG]{Residence} into the @UUID[.lJaJrbm2pkgjuON1]{Nobles} isle.

  • @UUID[Actor.8eTfnYg0xmcgmDVQ]{Irovetti's Fetch}
  • @UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]{Fetch Stalkers (4)}

Encounter

Severe 20

A family of four fetch stalkers dwells here. Each should resemble a family member of a different PCperhaps a parent, a sibling, a cousin, or in the case of a PC who never knew their family, a friend or other NPC theyve grown close to. The fetch stalkers welcome the PCs with a strange sense of delight and cheer, acting as if all of them being together in this strange manner isnt unusual at all. The fetch stalkers seek to have the PCs seated at the table, saying dinner is about to be served as they bustle about.

If the PCs comply, the fetches serve them fine food and drink, and you can play out this strange dinner party as long as you wish with the false family members giving nonsensical answers to the PCs when asked. Unless the PCs attack the fetches (in which case the fey shriek words like betrayers and traitors as they procure long fetch knives to fight back), their fetch family eventually reveals to them that the master of the house is joining them presently. A moment later, Castruccio Irovettis fetch emerges from the private quarters (area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t]{B4}) to attack, accusing the PCs of stealing his home and rolling Intimidation for his initiative. (If the PCs instigated the fight on their own, Irovettis fetch joins the fight on the second round and rolls initiative using Perception instead.)

Irovettis fetch manifests as a larger-than-life version of his previous incarnationa towering, overly muscular creature nearly fourteen feet tall, dressed in rags and adorned with a crown that seems to grow from his skull rather than simply worn atop his head. His fetch weapon appears identical to a flaming version of his rod of razors, but it functions only as a fetch weapon, not the technological item he wielded in life.
B2. Main Hall.name: B2. Main Hall

The Park.name: The Park
The Park.text: This island features only two buildings; most of its expanse is a riotous tangle of wildflowers, trees, brambles, fungi, and the like. If the PCs had a park or similar area in their capital, adjust descriptions here and there to make it apparent this region is based on their park. Alternately, if one of the PCs has particularly fond memories of a wilderness location in the Stolen Lands, features from that location might have been pulled in to this tangle as well. Feel free to adjust the overall size and shape of this island if you need more room to integrate a wilderness location like this, or even to attach a map of such an area, such as the Temple of the Elk, to the region.

C4. Sundered Stables.name: C4. Sundered Stables
C4. Sundered Stables.text:
A sprawling wooden stable sits at the edge of this overgrown island, but its once fine features have been sullied with blood, mud, and filth. The roof remains mostly intact, but here and there portions have fallen away into rubble within.

@UUID[Actor.hLBHFloWuXLjCQYH]{Primal Bandersnatches (2)}

Low 20

While these stables may have been used to house prize horses in the Material Plane version of the building, here it houses two immense monstrositiesprimal bandersnatches. These massive, six-legged, catlike creatures hide amid the rubble and beams near the buildings roof. As soon as the PCs approach within 15 feet of the building, the two emerge to attack, rolling Stealth for initiative. The sound of their eerie roars is certainly enough to draw Vordakai from area @UUID[.FebpS0rXrOExrYgC]{C5}, who joins the fight at the start of the second round.

D1. Snickersnack.name: D1. Snickersnack
D1. Snickersnack.text:
Macro

@UUID[Macro.EP51gGlcBcTJ737u]{D1 - The Rising Rock}

When the Rising Rock sinks back to area @UUID[.DiTR9EpCS1SiF1d5]{C6}, you can use this macro to show or hide the floating island on this scene.

Here, the sprawling tangle of rampant overgrowth rules completely. No sign of civilization is apparent on this isle save for a looming monument glimpsed through trees to the north and brief glimpses of some sort of structure through the overgrowth to the east.

The significant overgrowth on this island outside of the two ruined buildings functions as greater difficult terrain. Worse, the edges of this island consist of mats of deceptive vegetation that hang out over the gulf below. A character who enters any space shared by the islands edge must make a successful @Check[type:reflex|dc:35] save upon entering that space or plunge through the vegetation into a fall, landing a moment later in the space they left before stepping into nothingness.

@UUID[Actor.Y0qsrBFTFMbaiLzr]{Jabberwock}

Severe 20

The most dangerous foe the PCs face in the Park is a jabberwock. The immense Tane stomps and burbles and patrols this entire region; it immediately attacks the PCs as soon as it notices them. As the jabberwock moves, the surrounding vegetation parts for its approach as if fearful of its arrival; as such, the jabberwock ignores the greater difficult terrain caused by this island.

@UUID[Actor.19X82z6eIY0QLZrW]{Jabberwock Pellet}: As soon as the PCs slay the jabberwock, it thrashes and crashes as it expires, coughing up a pulsing mass of tissue as it does so; if the jabberwock was defeated via an effect like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.r7ihOgKv19eJQnik]{disintegrate} or banished to another plane, the mass of tissue drops to the ground in one of the squares the Tane occupied before it was defeated. The tissue rots away quickly, revealing a few notable treasures in its passinga third eye and an orichalcum scroll tube (itself worth 2,500 gp) that contains a single scroll (this scroll contains one of the following 10th-level spells, chosen from a tradition that at least one PC can cast: @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.h8zxY9hTeHtWsBVW]{alter reality}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.YfJTXyVGzLhM6V8U]{miracle}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.MLNeD5sAunV0E23j]{primal phenomenon}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{wish}).

D3. The House Beyond Time.text:
Fragments of a familiar structurethe House at the Edge of Timestand at the edge of this island. Most of the building appears to have crumbled away, but what remains of the partially collapsed ruin is still recognizable as having once been part of Nyrissas home in Thousandbreaths.

All that remains of Nyrissas home is an L-shaped fragment missing most of its roof. Within, among the rubble (which functions only as difficult terrain, rather than the surrounding parks greater difficult terrain), bits and pieces of the finery and decor from the nymph queens home remain, but little of value can be scavenged from the destruction.

@UUID[Actor.keCgklXcy4HZgQIL]{Elite Adamantine Golems (3)}

Moderate 20

Amid the rubble stand what appear to be three 8-foot-tall adamantine statues vaguely similar in appearance to Nyrissa. In truth, these are smaller-than-normal adamantine golems powered by the Lantern Kings own fury. While these golems are only Medium size, their statistics are those of elite adamantine golems, except that their attacks lack the normal 15-foot reach of a typical adamantine golem. Once the golems notice the PCs, fires flare up inside them and they all move to attack, plumes of smoke and flickers of flame churning in their hollow torsos or red-hot eye sockets. The three golems pursue foes relentlessly through the Park; as with the jabberwock, the writhing tangles of vegetation part for them as they advance, allowing the golems to ignore the greater difficult terrain (they do not ignore the difficult terrain inside of this ruined building).

@UUID[Actor.iqMMrq96o3c6D0vs]{Chalice Shard}: Success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40|traits:action:search] check made while @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Searching} the ruins of this structure uncovers a shard of a chalices cupthis is the third and final shard of the Apology, which can be recognized as detailed in area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t]{B4}.
D3. The House Beyond Time.name: D3. The House Beyond Time

A4. The Roof Bridge.name: A4. The Roof Bridge
A4. The Roof Bridge.text:
A gap between two overgrown islands has been bridged here by a building that has partially collapsed into the void. Only the upper walls and wood-shingled roof of the building remains, forming a sort of bridge between the two islands. The steeply angled roofline makes crossing it a daunting task, even if one were to attempt to do so along the narrow roof beam across its center.

The roof bridge is stable, and can support any amount of weight, but it still remains a tricky way to move from the southern islands of the Market to the northern one. As anyone attempts to cross this bridge, loose shingles slip, slippery patches of standing water or runny mold well up from the wood, and tiny vines growing on the building twist and grasp with lives of their own at those who cross. As a result of these conditions, a character can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} across the sloped roofs with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:40|traits:action:climb] check or walk along the narrow beam by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.M76ycLAqHoAgbcej]{Balancing} with a @Check[type:acrobatics|dc:40|traits:action:balance] check. A critical failure results in a fall, after which the character lands on the ground on the original side of the bridge they started from.

  • @UUID[Actor.tjq87ghubOcPAXjj]{Fetch Behemoth}
  • @UUID[Item.qVChn1FaOqDx7JFf]{Reflected: Hargulka}

Hargulka's Fetch

Trivial 20

The roof bridge is the lesser danger facing the PCs here, for a potentially familiar face lurks among the foliage just north of the roof. This is a lumbering fetch behemoth who wears the guise of the troll king Hargulka. He waits until the PCs are split between the two islands, preferably when at least one PC is still navigating the roof bridge, before he emerges from the trees with a roar to attack. He rolls Stealth for initiative, and his bellowing challenge alerts the vilderavns in area @UUID[.UI216yii0AFAECti]{A5} who join the battle at the start of the 3rd round (increasing this from a Trivial 20 encounter to a Severe 20 one).

C6. The Rising Rock.text:
Macro

@UUID[Macro.OpbX4f9Z41S76GOd]{C6 - The Rising Rock}

If your players somehow reach this area while the Rising Rock is in area @UUID[.ub0Oad5bx6zIg5vc]{D1} (for instance, by falling from the Park above), you can use this macro to show or hide the floating island in area C6.

A smaller slab of rock, its surface overgrown with plants, visibly bobs in the air here, tethered to the larger, more stable island to the west via a thick tangle of vines. Now and then, the vines twitch and move, as if they were enjoying the act of clutching this rock, or perhaps straining to keep it in place

This smaller isle can be used to ascend 100 feet to the @UUID[.2mRG6whqxVYaKdTx]{Park} above. To do so, the vines anchoring it to the Nobles must be destroyed. The vines themselves are numerous but individually easy to break. A minute or so of work is all thats needed, after which point this islet rises up to the area indicated on the map by the dotted outline adjacent to area @UUID[.ub0Oad5bx6zIg5vc]{D1}. The islet remains for 1 minute before it sinks back down to this location and the vines reattach it to the Nobles.
C6. The Rising Rock.name: C6. The Rising Rock

B3. Kitchen.name: B3. Kitchen
B3. Kitchen.text:
This fair-sized kitchen and pantry has a large stone washbasin next to a rain barrel, fed from a pipe coming out of the wall. The south wall has a large stone cooking hearth; ashen logs and soot spill from the opening and across the floor. Next to the fireplace rests a stack of neatly chopped firewood. Hooks on the walls hold an assortment of pots, spoons, ladles and other cookware.

The double door to the west provides an exit from the Residence, as do the ones to the east and south.

Treasure: When the Lantern King drew upon dreams and memories harvested from the PCs and their legacy, not everything became weaponized against themthere were some unanticipated side effects, such as those found in this room.

Any PC who enters the kitchen experiences a feeling of protection and safety, be it in the form of warm memories of loving parents, the support of a deity, or simply recollections of old friendships. These feelings automatically draw each PC to an item of food or drink in the kitchen they instinctively recognize as a cherished meal from childhood. Whatever the form of this meal, the PC also understands immediately upon touching the meal that it functions as an @UUID[Actor.k3H5Gr286nd7pXkF.Item.GySfs5UwiADSIFTG]{elixir of rejuvenation}.

The Ravaged Capital.name: The Ravaged Capital
The Ravaged Capital.text:
When the PCs first wake in the Lantern Kingdom, they do so in a region both familiar and horrifically unknown: the heart of their own capital, but after a devastating apocalypse has torn the settlement to shreds. All that remains of the city are five slabs of uprooted terrain that float in the air at different altitudes. Above, as below, the sky and ground have been replaced by what appear to be glowing panes of fiery glass within which these fragments of the PCs capital now lie suspended. After gazing out upon the strange horizon, success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:20] check is all thats required to realize that it all seems to be housed in a single vast lantern, its glass panes inverted so that the flame that glows to provide illumination shines in from beyond. Characters who peer long enough into those distant glass panes may periodically catch glimpses of other entirely unknown worlds, each of which suffers in the fires of their own private apocalypse. These are windows into the other 999 kingdoms that were once contained in the Apology, but there is no way to reach these realities from within the Ravaged Capital itself.

Where Is Nyrissa?

If Nyrissa still lives, she too has been trapped within this demiplane, butunlike the PCs, whom the Lantern King has placed where he can be entertained by themNyrissa is ensconced within a cage at the Lantern Kings side (see @UUID[.BX7f7hUaiYuBNSjn]{The Palace}). As the PCs explore the Lantern Kingdom, they periodically hear Nyrissas voice calling for help as if over a great distance from somewhere far above.

The Lantern Kingdom is a small, finite demiplane encased entirely within a single lantern that hangs in the Lantern Kings throne room in the First World. As the PCs explore the Ravaged Capital, they occasionally catch glimpses beyond the distant glass borders of an immense burning sphere topped by a jagged crown of hornsthe Lantern King watching from beyond as the PCs suffer and toil for his amusement. Divination magic can serve to reveal some of the truths of this realm to the PCs, as can speaking to the few friendly NPCs they encounter along the way. Alternately, a PC can take ten minutes Investigating the environment, after which they can attempt a @Check[type:arcana|dc:40|traits:action:investigate], @Check[type:nature|dc:40|traits:action:investigate], @Check[type:occultism|dc:40|traits:action:investigate], or @Check[type:religion|dc:40|traits:action:investigate] check. Success indicates they recognize theyre within a strange demiplane that seems to exist entirely within a single immense lantern, while a critical success confirms that it is the Lantern King who watches them from the far side of the demiplanes glass borders.

Arrival in the Lantern Kingdom

Whether the Hunting Dream resulted in the Wild Hunt defeating the PCs or in the PCs being victorious, the dreams end is the samethe Apology is shattered and the PCs black out, only to awaken in the Lantern Kingdom. The PCs may initially suspect theyve simply moved from one dream to another, but as strange as the environment seems, it is very real. Success at a @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:nature|dc:40|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} identifies the realm as an unknown demiplane that lies between the First World and the Material Plane. A critical success suggests to the PC the high probability that this demiplane was constructed from metaphysical echoes of the kingdoms once contained within the Apology itself.

If the PCs survived the @UUID[.L8UvMkhoqamn3kBj]{Hunting Dream}, they waken from it refreshed and in perfect health, as if theyd had a full nights rest and had just finished their daily preparations, as they were at the start of the Hunting Dream. The PCs arrive at area @UUID[.bUY4YHhEtaHpQHOX]{A1}.

Features of the Lantern Kingdom

The Lantern Kingdom consists of five separate areas: island-like regions that are each based on a different part of the PCs capital city. The Lantern Kingdom as a whole serves as a sort of obstacle course the PCs must navigate, a testing ground created by the Lantern King for his amusement, with a chance to meet with him being the reward to PCs if they are clever, brave, or stubborn enough to make it to the end. As such, the PCs find that as long as they remain close to the ground on the floating islands within the Lantern Kingdom, they remain relatively safe, but any attempt to circumvent the courseor worse, approach the Kingdoms glass bordersquickly reveals itself to be deadly; see Travel on the next page for details.

The Lantern Kingdom demiplane has the following unusual features.

Size: The demiplane is finite in size. The lantern itself is 5 feet across where it hangs in the Lantern Kings realm on the First World, but it is much larger on the inside where the PCs have become trapped. The islands float near the center of the spherical orb, such that the glass borders are just about a mile from the edges of the islands themselves.

Illumination: The Lantern Kingdom is brightly lit at all times, either by the surrounding glass borders or by glowing motes of light that hover near the ceiling of internal locations. This illumination resists the creation of magical darkness. One minute after a magical darkness effect is created, or at the end of a combat in which such an effect is created (whichever comes first), the Lantern Kingdom attempts to counteract the darkness effect ([[/r 1d20+40]] counteract check). If it fails to counteract the magical darkness, the Lantern Kingdom automatically attempts a new counteract check once every 24 hours (unless, of course, the darkness effect ends before then).

Islands: The islands in the Lantern Kingdom float at different altitudes. The group of islands that constitute the Market (where the PCs first arrive in the Lantern Kingdom) is the lowest, with the Residence, the Nobles, the Park, and the Palace each 100 feet higher than the last. As such, its impossible to see much more than the basic shape of an island above, while one can look down to a birds-eye view of any island that lies below. The islands themselves are stable; though seemingly floating in the air, there is no sensation to those standing on them that they are on anything other than solid ground. In some places, small gaps in the landscape might force harrowing leaps over the void below. While you can build up some of the perceived dangers of doing so, unless the distance being jumped is more than 5 feet across you shouldnt ask for Athletics checks to successfully navigate the gap. Characters who tumble through such a gap fall as detailed under Falling below.

Travel: The streets of the ruined capital that lie upon the Lantern Kingdoms islands are strewn with rubble and overgrown with strange First World plants. All ground travel is difficult terrain (from tangled undergrowth outside of buildings, and from rubble and debris inside of buildings) as a result. There are no restrictions on flight, provided the flying character doesnt stray further than 60 feet from the ground. Any attempt to move further than 60 feet from the ground via flight (be it straight up or out from the edge of an island) results in a painful flash of searing light that inflicts [[/r 10d6[fire]]] damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:40|basic:true] save) to the flying creature and prevents further movement in the prohibited directionthe Lantern King wants his entertainment to travel through the kingdom along the route he chose rather than to skip entire islands by flight. North in the Lantern Kingdom isnt the result of a magnetic pull but the Lantern Kings will.

Planar Travel: Its possible for a PC to escape the Lantern Kingdom via planar travel through effects like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{plane shift} or being sent away by spells like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.bay4AfSu2iIozNNW]{banishment}. Deliberate travel to the Lantern Kingdom is possible via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{plane shift} (provided the PCs can secure the incredibly rare tuning fork for this, which is subject to GM approval) or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.U13bC0tNgrlHoeTK]{gate}, but as long as the Lantern King hasnt been successfully challenged in his @UUID[.BX7f7hUaiYuBNSjn]{throne room}, any PC who escapes the Lantern Kingdom returns the next time they fall asleep or lose consciousness. Regardless of how a PC travels to the Lantern Kingdom, they always appear in area @UUID[.bUY4YHhEtaHpQHOX]{A1}.

Falling: Its possible to fall from the edge of an island, but one who falls never lands where logic would dictate. A character who falls plummets 100 feet and lands on the next lower island at its lowest-numbered encounter area, regardless of where the fall began, and even if that area is inside of a structure. A character who falls from the Market instead falls 200 feet before landing at area A1.

Creatures: Just as the Lantern Kingdoms geography is based on the PCs capital, some of its citizens are warped duplicates of NPCs from homesome appearing as old enemies, and some as friends. For the latter, choose living NPCs who have leadership roles in the PCs kingdom or other trusted allies, excluding any who have accompanied the PCs into the Lantern Kingdom. If youre using the Kingmaker Companion Guide, any of the companions in that book who remained behind on the Material Plane make great choices.

Resting: The Lantern King allows the PCs to rest on any one island once, out of fairness to keep the entertainment going. If the PCs attempt to rest on the same island more than once, theyll be attacked at some point during the rest by a group of four @UUID[Actor.fQ9FuovHuRt6vtcq]{wild hunt scouts} (a Moderate 20 encounter) who haughtily warn the PCs to not dawdleto keep moving or suffer. If the PCs refuse, they must defeat the wild hunt, after which they earn the chance for the additional rest. Each additional rest on that island adds one wild hunt scout to the resulting encounter, to a maximum of a dozen scouts (an Extreme 20 encounter). There are enough constantly blooming fruits and berries among the foliage overgrowing the shattered city, along with small pools of water here and there that refill magically over time, so that PCs who are trapped for many days in the Lantern Kingdom can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.49y9Ec4bDii8pcD3]{Subsist} with a @Check[type:survival|dc:35|traits:action:subsist] check. A character who rolls a critical failure while attempting to Subsist attracts trouble in the form of a group of four Wild Hunt scouts, as detailed above.

A2. Familiar Faces?.name: A2. Familiar Faces?
A2. Familiar Faces?.text:
As the PCs step out of the ruined shop at area A1, describe to them another familiar (but ruined) building here that represents another shop they frequent that, in their actual capital, but is not normally located next door to the first. This should help the PCs (and thus the players) recognize theyre in a warped reality rather than in their actual capital after some sort of unknown apocalypse destroyed it.

@UUID[Actor.nDFogS2qQJomjfmR]{Fetch Stalkers (4)}

Moderate 20

This building is currently occupied by four fetch stalkers created in the images of people the PCs have allied with. They emerge from this shop soon after the PCs arrive in the Lantern Kingdom in area @UUID[.bUY4YHhEtaHpQHOX]{A1}, loudly calling out the PCs names and daring them to step out into the open to face their failures.

These fetches accuse the PCs of leaving them behind while their kingdom fell, and demand retribution in the form of execution. A PC can see through the fetches claims that theyre actual survivors from the PCs fallen kingdom as normal, but even if the fetch stalkers successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ewwCglB7XOPLUz72]{Lie} to the entire party, its likely that the PCs wont trust these figures. The fetches dont waste too much time arguing, and attack soon after they find the PCs.

A7. Ascending Vines.name: A7. Ascending Vines
A7. Ascending Vines.text:
A thick tangle of vines rises upward at a steep angle to attach to a floating block of earth and stone a hundred feet overhead, ending at what appears to be an open doorway in the side of a stone building. Now and then, the vines seem to shiver or twist on their own, and flowers bloom and wilt at an unnerving pace along the length, as if time itself were an untrustworthy constant.

Despite their appearance, these vines can be ascended fairly easily by high-level charactersits only a @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|traits:action:climb] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} them. Characters who do so find themselves entering the @UUID[.Riwc58VZoiQZg1ZG]{Residence} at area @UUID[.V3YlfDlUeyi85SRr]{B1}.

The Hunting Dream.text:
The Lantern Kings reaction to the PCs is coming, and sooner than they can make any significant preparations for. The demigod takes note of Nyrissas defeat the moment it happens, but preparing his reaction takes a short time as he reshapes a portion of his own realm in the First World into a demiplane called the Hunting Dream. When this occurs, the sleeping PC simply fades away from the world, evaporating painlessly from reality only to form in this other one. The process does not cause the sleeping PC to waken, but will surely distress anyone watching the event occur. Its best, as a result, to have this take place when all of the PCs are slumbering, but if that proves difficult to time, you can simply have the Lantern King pull awake PCs from the Material Plane into the Hunting Dream. This transition carries less symbolic effect, but the end resultbecoming trapped in another realmis identical.

The timing of when the Hunting Dream occurs can be tricky; you want it to take place soon after Nyrissas defeat so that the Lantern King doesnt seem lackadaisical in his pursuit of vengeance, but you should also give the PCs time to wrap up any lingering tasks before moving on with this chapter, as once they are drawn into the Hunting Dream they will not be able to return home with easesee Trapped in a Curse in @UUID[.qFFwuhncWJ1UGDnR]{Outcome} for more advice.

The moment of the dreams beginning is impossible for the PCs to pinpoint, as it starts with the PCs exactly as they were when they slept. Describe to the PCs that they wake from sleep to the sound of a hunting horn and the overwhelming feeling that something is coming for them. Regardless of how the PCs react or where they began the dream, the scene quickly changes, with the PCs suddenly finding themselves together, fleeing through a tangled woodland to the sound of pursuit not far behind them.

Scenes

Hunting Dream - @UUID[Scene.cCwPBVl14eGWBigI]{Lower}, @UUID[Scene.q704NGLkgJGPuKWP]{Upper}

A twisted, dreamlike version of the Stag Lord's Fort.

After what seems like an hour of running, the PCs emerge into a stockaded compound. Bodies lie strewn on the ground, and it should only take a few moments for the PCs to recognize the scene: theyve returned to the Stag Lords fort, and the bodies are those of the bandits they defeated, although the body of the Stag Lord himself is strangely absent. At this point, return control of the PCs actions to the players and allow them to explore and move about the fort. While the fort itself remains structurally the same, strange plants now grow within the forts courtyard and cling to its wooden walls, while the sky above has unsettling purple and gray spiral clouds against a bright blue sky. Success on a @Check[type:religion|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check or a @Check[type:first-world-lore|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} is enough to deduce that this place, be it dream or reality, lies somewhere in a living dream lodged between the First World and the Dreamlands.

The nature of the Hunting Dream doesnt impact the PCs in many waystreat it as if they were located in the real ruins of the Stag Lords fort on the Material Plane for the most part. Attempts to leave the area depicted on the map itself, though, automatically fail. A character who tries to teleport away simply reappears in the same spot, while someone who tries to physically walk beyond the borders of the map itself finds themselves being turned around and approaching the fort. Once a character experiences this effect, they can attempt a @Check[type:occultism|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to realize that they are trapped in some form of living dream.

Once the PCs realize theyre trapped in a living dream, theyll also know that while they cannot be truly slain in this place, they also cannot escape until they see the dreams elements out to their conclusion.

  • @UUID[Actor.pZosztihhMtCLinT]{Wild Hunt Monarch}
  • @UUID[Actor.3gtQv6Mkr7CUlG7W]{Wild Hunt Archers (4)}
  • @UUID[Actor.fQ9FuovHuRt6vtcq]{Wild Hunt Scouts (4)}

Encounter

Extreme 20

At about the point the PCs realize theyre all together in the center of the Stag Lords fort (equivalent to area @UUID[JournalEntry.AgbaF8i9XDLEtxqe.JournalEntryPage.Zka68VE6XfJKuHN3]{C5}), theyll also notice that theyre surrounded by strange looking creatures: agents of the wild hunt. These particular wild hunt fey serve the Lantern King, and consist of four wild hunt archers, four wild hunt scouts, and a wild hunt monarch who bears an unsettling resemblance in appearance to the Stag Lord himself, although with tiny motes of electricity dancing along his antlers. The monarchs appearance isnt intended to trick the PCs into thinking that they once again face the Stag Lord himself, though, and it should be obvious to them that the figure who has taken his form is an entirely different creature.

Despite this, the wild hunt monarch introduces himself to the PCs as the true Stag Lordchampion of the Lantern King and arbiter of your fates. He demands the PCs explain why they dared disrupt Nyrissas path to forgiveness, implying that the PCs were in the wrong and were the aggressors rather than the nymph queen herself. He produces the once again full Apology in one hand, holding the artifact aloft as he notes that 999 kingdoms lie within this chalicewho are you to deny it one more? The Stag Lord monarch wishes to hear from the PCs own mouths their justification for disrupting the Lantern Kings entertainmentgive each player a chance to argue their case or attempt to contradict the Stag Lord monarchs claims while the other wild hunt fey look on, periodically jeering or mocking the PCs in their attempts to escape the Stag Lords judgments.

Once the Stag Lord monarch grows tired with the PCs, or once the PCs themselves grow too aggressive or violent, he shakes his head in sadness and declares that their lives are forfeit to the Lantern King in payment for meddling in affairs beyond their ken. At this point, he raises the Apology to his lips, drinks deep of the sand within, and orders an attack on the PCs (assuming the PCs havent yet instigated hostilities themselves).

Note that this is an extreme encounter for a group of 20th-level PCs, and as such its very likely that some or all of the characters will perish in the resulting fight. Fortunately, the nature of the Hunting Dream is such that they begin this combat at full health, as if theyd rested well and just finished performing their daily preparations. Give the players time to prepare for the combat before rolling initiative. Once the fighting starts, the battle itself plays out normally, but PCs who are slain in this encounter arent actually killedsee Dream Defeat or Dream Victory in @UUID[.qFFwuhncWJ1UGDnR]{Outcome}.

D4. Palace Approach.text: Once the PCs have all three shards of the Apology, they can readily see how the pieces of the vessel fit back together and reassemble it. If the reassembled @UUID[Item.NpsSQTqOdKsqfwCD]{Apology} is brought to this location, the ground shakes and trembles as the world the Lantern King has made bursts into wisps of translucent shadow, forming and racing like a raging torrent back into the Apology. Again the world starts to shift, slowly as if it straining to decide which direction to go. A mass of animated vines and rubble suddenly surges forward from this spot, rising through the mists to form a winding spiral ramp that leads upward to the final isle above: the Palace.
D4. Palace Approach.name: D4. Palace Approach

B1. Storeroom.name: B1. Storeroom
B1. Storeroom.text:
Shelves along the walls of this storeroom are filled with all matter of strange, eclectic objects, all caked with a thick layer of dust. A door stands in both the east and west wall; to the north, a partially collapsed wall looms over the strange vista of this weird realm above a cascading tangle of vines that leads downward.

Each PC enters this room from the door to the west and immediately experiences a strange sense of dj vu: the room feels familiar in a way that evokes their own childhood home. For one PC it might be the scent of a parents cooking lingering in the air. For another it might be a familiar carving they left on a beam as a child. For a third it could be the way they accidentally bump their head on an annoying overhanging beam, just like theyd done countless times before as they entered the room through the doorway. Any PC who looks through the shelves immediately recognizes several objects from their home, many of which they may have thought were lost forever. These objects are mundane in nature, and a closer examination along with success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:40] check is enough to note strange disconnects between the object and memory, as if the item were reconstructed by someone operating from a detailed description but who never actually saw the original.

D2. Monument.text:
A towering but badly eroded monument stands atop a rectangular base here, towering above the surrounding trees. Just beyond the monument to the north, a stump of land extends toward the regions highest island floating above. Atop this last island stands a familiar-looking structure.

Adjust the monuments description to match the largest or most notable monument in the PCs kingdomif none exist, it is instead a monument to the kingdoms ruler. The familiar-looking structure on the upper island is recognizable as the PCs capital building, be it a castle, a palace, or whatever, save that it seems to be in a crumbling state of disrepair with tangles of ivy growing along its walls.

@UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]{Werendegar}

Low 20

Unless the PCs defeated him earlier, Werendegar retreats to this location after speaking to them in area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]{A3}. He waits patiently, seated atop the monuments stone base, biding his time with a drink and a book (success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:25] check reveals that the book is Zuddigers Picnic). Once Werendegar spots the PCs, he tosses the drink and book asidethey promptly vanish in puffs of smokeand he calls out to the characters asking if theyve gathered up the Apology. If not, he shakes his head in disappointment and waves them off to finish the task.

If theyve gathered all three shards, he claps in delight and hops down from the monument, beckoning for the PCs to follow him north to area @UUID[.8Y896ivCvpkJrJFI]{D4}. If the PCs attack him, he flees via @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{dimension door} to the Palaces throne room, leaving the PCs to find their own way forward.
D2. Monument.name: D2. Monument

The Nobles.name: The Nobles
The Nobles.text:
Reaching the Nobles island is a simple matter of exiting the Residence through any of its doors or windows. When the PCs do so, they emerge from area @UUID[.nUE3P7NYaSoVmjqb]{C1}.

This island is based on whichever part of the PCs capital is inhabited by the most nobles and aristocrats. The open area between the ruined manors to the north and south is strewn with bodies and bears obvious signs of recent combat. The bodies resemble allies, friends, and recognizable citizens from the PCs capital, but theyre little more than decoration; success at a @Check[type:nature|dc:35] check confirms that the corpses are in fact cleverly cultivated plants that have been grown into shapes resembling bodies.

The Lantern King set this area up to create a mock clash between an ally and an enemy of the PCs: Lady Jamandi and Vordakai. In fact, both are fetches who seek to toy with the PCs before killing them off.

C5. Destroyed Mansion.name: C5. Destroyed Mansion
C5. Destroyed Mansion.text:
Only a fragment of one wing survives of what may have once been a glorious, sprawling mansion. Its southwestern face slumps in rubble over the void, while the facade that remains is riddled with holes and splattered with gore.

Feel free to add additional elements to the above description to make the PCs recognize this ruined mansion as a location close to them, be it the sprawling manor of an NPC ally or one of their own residences found within their capital.

  • @UUID[Actor.6zWcjvPya0wWDZv2]{Risen Fetch}
  • @UUID[Item.34iTVVQtmrLdBFhf]{Reflected: Vordakai}

Vordakai's Fetch

Moderate 20

A single deadly occupant lies in wait in this destroyed mansion: a risen fetch based on the cyclops wizard Vordakai. As with all risen fetches, this creature appears as Vordakai did in life, not as he did in undeathhis eye remains intact and his body is hearty and healthy in appearance, yet the PCs should be able to recognize him with ease. Unlike most of the other fetches encountered in the Lantern Kingdom, Vordakais fetch has no agenda of trickery; he waits here patiently, hoping the fetches to the east will successfully lead the PCs toward him so that a glorious betrayal will occur. If the PCs instead confront him first, he does his best to use flashy, impossible-to-ignore spell effects and works his way east to draw in the fetches from areas @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci]{C2} and @UUID[.OUC9y0vcIOsbhHE8]{C3}.

Treasure: Vordakais fetch carries a shard of the Apology in a pocket of his robes; when hes slain and his remains decay away, this fractured portion of the @UUID[Item.ilzaIlAlHGZ80a1u]{chalices cup} remains behind. As with the previous shard, this shard is Bulk 1; it can be recognized in the same way as the shard in area @UUID[.X0vksZ0FRqhhN90t]{B4}.

Part 1: A Broken Apology.name: Part 1: A Broken Apology
Part 1: A Broken Apology.text:
The PCs should be 20th level before facing the results of the broken Apology.

Kingdom in the Background

As the campaign nears its conclusion, the PCs kingdom has become a powerful political force in the River Kingdoms, but it still faces one final danger: the Lantern Kings petulance. The kingdoms presence in this last chapter is mostly reflected in the what if realm presented by the Lantern King, but you should adjust the encounter descriptions as needed to match the sort of kingdom youve described the PCs building during the Adventure Path.

While the PCs have defeated the threat Nyrissa posed to their kingdom, her death or redemption creates an unexpected complication, for the Lantern King has waited with growing impatience for the final kingdom to be absorbed into the Apology. With Nyrissa slain or forgiven, this seems unlikely, and its only a matter of time before the Lantern King shatters the Apology and unleashes his wrathful curse on those responsible for disrupting his entertainment: the PCs.

Part 2: The Lantern Kingdom.name: Part 2: The Lantern Kingdom
Part 2: The Lantern Kingdom.text:
The PCs should be 20th level before they are swept into the Lantern Kingdom.

When the Hunting Dream concludes and the Apology is destroyed, an apocalyptic reality is created: the Lantern Kingdom. Its into this devastated what-if? reality that the PCs awaken from the Hunting Dream, trapped in a realm that imagines what their kingdom would be like after its destruction at the burning touch of an enraged Lantern King.

A1. A Familiar Place.text:
When the PCs arrive in the Lantern Kingdom, they do so here. As you present the readaloud text below, you should adjust it as needed to make it apparent that the shop into which they appear is one that they frequent in their capitalif not a place the PCs helped to build, then certainly one that they often visit.

This ruined shop instills a vague sense of deja-vu, while the vista looking out from a mostly collapsed wall is entirely new: a gulf of swirling clouds in which fragments of a familiar city float on rocky islets overgrown with a tangle of alien plant life. Some of these isles are only a few feet across, connected to others by tangles of vines, while one much larger island looms in the sky a hundred feet above in the other direction. Here, glimpses of a ruined, overgrown city are visible, as is a rising bridge of thorny vines that winds up from this island grouping to the one above. In the distance, what appear to be vast shimmering fields of glass look out over a void of scintillating light in which drift glimpses of a vast, drifting, burning sphere surrounded by clouds of runesa sphere that gives you the unmistakable sensation that it is watching.

Add as many other elements as you wish to make it apparent to the PCs that they have appeared not only in a familiar, but ruined store, but within the shattered remains of their own capital. No recognizable NPCs, living or dead, are apparent, and the longer the PCs remain in this realm, the more they should notice strange errors or inconsistencies with what should otherwise be familiar places, as if this shattered city were a duplicate created by someone not wholly familiar with the source. Strange spellings for street names, slightly different images on building signs, and fragmentary statues depicting villains the PCs have previously clashed with are great examples of such off-kilter elements.

Success on a @Check[type:nature|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:religion|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check identifies the vast burning sphere that seems to be observing the PCs as the Lantern King himself.
A1. A Familiar Place.name: A1. A Familiar Place

A5. Fragmented Inn.text:
This building is similar to the one at area @UUID[.JBlLiVTqW3eDUPch]{A3}, save that it appears as an inn the PCs frequented or built in their capital; inside, all that exists is the inns foyer, with other doors that once provided access to additional rooms now simply providing exits or entrances to the inn itself.

@UUID[Actor.UXXEOnvp2MDaS9Sc]{Vilderavn Heralds (3)}

Moderate 20

The Lantern King is served by many fey, but he particularly favors vilderavn heralds as his agents in the Stolen Landsthe PCs may have encountered one of them before as a random encounter in Thousand Voices. The three heralds posted here in this fragmented inn, though, are instead failures who are serving out penance as guards. The Lantern King has ordered them to slay the PCs if they attempt to reach this part of the Market, and he has promised all three heralds that theyll be allowed to return to their duties elsewhere if they succeed. As such, the vilderavns are eager to earn their freedom, and they fight to the death as soon as they notice the PCs (likely as a result of hearing a roar from the fetch behemoth at area @UUID[.ocC3GJNcUQrLCTdO]{A4}).
A5. Fragmented Inn.name: A5. Fragmented Inn

A3. Strange Tavern.text:
This small building appears to be in better condition than the others in the Market. The building itself should be based on a tavern from the PCs capital, although strangely reduced in size so as to accommodate only the main room. Doors or halls that, in the real world, lead to other parts of the tavern should simply provide alternate exits and entrances to this main chamber.

@UUID[Actor.qLfHY6uNUQ99NZei]{Werendegar}

Low 19

Only one being occupies this tavernone of the Lantern Kings loyal agents, the gimmerling Werendegar. Among other things, Werendegar (who introduces himself simply by the name Weren) has been responsible for moving Briar to new hiding places each time Nyrissa absorbs a kingdom and moves on to a new world. Now that this task is no longer needed due to the PCs actions, the Lantern King has given Werendegar a new job: welcoming the PCs to the Lantern Kingdom. The gimmerling does his best to hide his frustration at this babysitting task.

As soon as the PCs defeat the fetches at area @UUID[.0XhNnb1JktH9BMlX]{A2}, Werendegar makes himself known by stepping out of the tavern where he has been relaxing. He appears to the PCs in his true form, that of a handsome but clawed and sharp-toothed half-elven man. He greets the PCs by name, then welcomes them to the Lantern Kingdom and notes that they may have questionsand hes eager to give them answers.

Werendegars purpose here is to encourage the PCs to make their way to the @UUID[.BX7f7hUaiYuBNSjn]{throne room} to present their case to the Lantern King himselfshould they be allowed to live and return home? Werendegar further explains to the PCs that in order to earn this audience with the Lantern King, they must first provide him entertainment in the form of their struggles to reach him. They must prove themselves as true adventurers worth his time by navigating their shattered city and triumphing over enemies they thought defeated (this is a reference to several fetches that present to the PCs in familiar forms). He also informs the PCs that when they broke the Apology (if needed, hell clarify that hes talking about the chalice that was shattered in the @UUID[.L8UvMkhoqamn3kBj]{Hunting Dream}), they insulted the Lantern King. He tells the PCs that the Apology was offered to Nyrissa out of the Lantern Kings inestimable mercy, and that if the PCs wish to leave the Lantern Kingdom, they must rebuild the Apology by recovering its three shards, which have been scattered throughout your broken home (he indicates the shattered capital all around him at this point).

Once the PCs have all three shards of the Apology and make their way to the throne room, Werendegar promises that the Lantern King will make time to hear their pleas for mercy. He provides honest answers for any questions the PCs have about the nature of the Lantern Kingdom. Questions about the Lantern King or himself, though, Werendegar answers more obliquely, implying that the PCs should save those questions for the Lantern King. He wont offer any other unsolicited advice.

Once Werendegar grows bored or annoyed with the PCs, or as soon as he has been attacked, he smirks and says, see you soon! before he fleesusing @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.wfleiawxsfhpRRwf]{disappearance} and/or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{dimension door} to retreat to area @UUID[.yzcTP7RoOiPK5dOT]{D2} to await the PCs there.
A3. Strange Tavern.name: A3. Strange Tavern

C1. Dilapidated Home.text:
Regardless of the method the PCs use to exit the Residence, they do so as if stepping through a partially ruined doorframe on the west face of what appears to be a partially collapsed house. Even a cursory inspection of this house reveals that it seems to be a ruined version of a childhood home, appearing differently to each viewer. A character who enters this house at any point finds themselves returning to area @UUID[.NrwIOizVhZGB2DUu]{B2} in the Residence.

Unless the PCs take pains to remain stealthy when they arrive, theyll be spotted by allies to the north who quickly call out their names and wave them over toward areas @UUID[.iOkmSEBKFJwLY1ci]{C2} and @UUID[.OUC9y0vcIOsbhHE8]{C3}.
C1. Dilapidated Home.name: C1. Dilapidated Home

TL4. Explorers Grave.text:
• hidden

A long-dead Taldan explorer lies partially buried in a cleft here. Success at a @Check[type:perception|dc:30] check made as part of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QIrJJ1pl4H6DctaQ]{Reconnoitering} the hex allows a PC to discover the body.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.pNQJ9PTOEHxEZCgp]{Sturdy Steel Shield}: Most of the corpses gear has rotted or rusted away, but his moderate sturdy steel shield, decorated with the coat of arms of a long-defunct Taldan noble family, remains usable.
TL4. Explorers Grave.name: TL4. Explorers Grave

HT10. Chuul Lair.text:
• standard

A rocky cave lies within a steep hillside by the swamps shore, nearly hidden by high rushes and cattails.

@UUID[Actor.aD76W2uEQhFFUrom]{4 Chuuls}

Moderate 10

This cave is the den of four chuuls. One of the creatures hides within the cave to the north, while the other three lurk in the water to the south, ready to ambush and surround any creatures venturing near their home. At night, they all reside in the cave, the walls of which are decorated with crude but detailed paintings of chuuls eating humans, created from the smeared leavings of their victims blood.

The chuuls try to flank opponents whenever possible, and fight to the death.

@UUID[Actor.unAuNe4wlGfw8lmB]{Chuul Trophies}: The chuuls compulsively store trophies theyve collected from past victims, including a +1 quarterstaff shod with silver at either end and decorated with carvings of predatory birds worth 180 gp, a pair of boots of bounding, a coral holy symbol of Gozreh worth 50 gp, a leaf-shaped mithral brooch worth 100 gp, and an iron medallion talisman.
HT10. Chuul Lair.name: HT10. Chuul Lair

HT1. Wyvernstone Bridge.name: HT1. Wyvernstone Bridge
HT1. Wyvernstone Bridge.text:
• landmark
  • resource

A stone bridge spans a gorge here, through which the East Sellen River flows. This engineering marvel, built nearly 200 years ago just after Choral the Conqueror united Brevoy, offers an easy route over the wide river just before its southern flow empties into the Hooktongue Slough. Although the roads that once extended from the bridge are long gone, the bridge itself remains intact.

TL5. Aurumvorax Den.name: TL5. Aurumvorax Den
TL5. Aurumvorax Den.text:
• Standard

A set of burrows honeycombs a granite hillside here, pocking the hillside with dozens of small openings. These mark the entrances to a tangled warren of tunnels serving as the lair for a half-dozen particularly hardy aurumvoraxes. This extended family of golden guardians wandered into these lands from Numeria years ago, and their swiftly growing offspring have started to spread throughout the region ever since.

@UUID[Actor.zjPdqdQGNjO3Kto7]{6 aurumvoraxes}

Severe 12

The aurumvoraxes are very territorial, and if they notice any sign of intrusion into the area, they come raging out of their burrows to attack. Theyll pursue trespassers for miles before giving up the chase, and they fight to the death.

The aurumvorax warren is a tight fit for Medium creatures, who must Squeeze to explore its deepest reaches. The actual den is located at the center of the tangle of tunnels; exploring the warren and finding the den requires a successful DC 30 Survival check or @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check made as part of a 4-hour Investigate activity.

@UUID[Actor.nHAJpXQSsIiBWHoO]{Adventurers' Remains}: The central den contains numerous skeletons and treasures that have survived the aurumvoraxes tendency to gnaw on things that are shiny. This includes 3,360 sp, a silver-and-ivory scepter worth 250 gp, a copper necklace set with pearls worth 80 gp, a golden lions wondrous figurine, a +1 flaming kukri, and a wand of levitate (3rd).

Zone 11: Drelev.text:
Northwest of the marshy expanse of Hooktongue Slough, the landscape dries into grassy plains dotted here and there with small sunken areas of standing water and thick vegetation. This region has recently been claimed by one of the more successful settlers from Rostland, Hannis Drelev. Most of Hanniss efforts have been put into the creation of a fort and supporting town on Lake Hooktongues only stretch of solid shoreline, and as such, the grasslands to the west remain mostly wilderness.

Ankou: An encounter with one of these dangerous fey may seem like chance to the PCs initially, but in fact, any ankou encountered in the wild is an agent sent by Nyrissa herself to attack the PCs, trying to test their mettle. Whether or not an ankou can be captured or convinced to reveal more information about the mysterious fey queen is left to you to decide. Ankous have little interest in common folk, and thus only make their presence known to more powerful characters such as the PCs.

Hill Giants: These giants have been driven south out of the Glenebon Uplands or the Tiger Lords region by aggressive barbarians, monsters, or just boredom. Theyve found that, while life in the soggy grasslands is safer overall, the lack of comforting hilly horizons has left them edgy and jumpy. The giants are eager to attack the PCs and take their things, but as soon as half of them are defeated, the remaining giants spirits break and they try to make peace with the PCs. Whether or not hill giants are a good idea to befriend is left to you to determine.
Zone 11: Drelev.name: Zone 11: Drelev

HT5. Haunted Fen.text:
• standard

The entire north shore of Lake Hooktongue, ranging from the boggard ambush site down to Fort Drelev, has a reputation for being haunted, but this particular stretch of boggy lakeshore is the most notorious part, known locally as the Haunted Fen. As the PCs first enter this hex, anyone who succeeds at a @Check[type:swamp-lore|dc:20|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or a @Check[type:nature|dc:25|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:society|dc:25|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.1OagaWtBpVXExToo]{Recall Knowledge} recalls legends that fishers and boaters who stray too near the shoreline in this area often hear voices calling out to them. None dispute the fact that trappers who venture into this area seem to go missing more often than not. There have been an unusual number of bodies found here missing eyes and fingers, as if both were chewed away by something that deliberately left the rest of the body untouched. This has only increased the regions notoriety. On a critical success on the check, a character notes that these eerie clues suggest the predation of a dangerous creature known as an ahuizotl.

@UUID[Actor.v2cJC9tdjRHexMwa]{Irahkatu}

Severe 10

Indeed, the source of the stories about the Haunted Fen is a particularly powerful ahuizotl named Irahkatu, a cunning and cruel predator with a particularly prodigious appetite. If he realizes his domain has been intruded upon, Irahkatu stalks the PCs, waiting for them to be distracted or for night to fall before ambushing them. If it looks like the PCs are going to leave the hex before nightfall, Irahkatu uses Voice Imitation to try to lure them back, then ambushes the smallest PC. Once combat begins, Irahkatu fights to the death, pursuing foes as far as the edges of this hex if necessary.

@UUID[Actor.mQzm1sSSP3vuEcld]{Boggard Skull}, @UUID[Actor.4JnpmIQ0Ddh6Jz8V]{Dwarf Skull}, @UUID[Actor.BCKTPBv37fxczP7f]{Human Skull}: Once Irahkatu has been defeated, a successful @Check[type:survival|dc:28|traits:action:track] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EA5vuSgJfiHH7plD]{Track} or a @Check[type:perception|dc:30] check made as part of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QIrJJ1pl4H6DctaQ]{Reconnoiter} activity can reveal to the PCs a mound of hidden vegetation and mud that the ahuizotl used as a nest. Irahkatu has used the skulls of many of its victims to decorate the walls inside his lair, and three of these skulls are adorned with valuables: one boggard skull wears a silver circlet set with moonstones worth 300 gp, a dwarf skull has seven gold teeth in its jaws worth a total of 70 gp, and a human skull wears a mask of the banshee.
HT5. Haunted Fen.name: HT5. Haunted Fen

HT9. The Swamp Scar.text:
• landmark

An immense mound of fallen trees and logs lie in a jagged line here, forming a swath of decaying plant matter created by various river currents over the course of decades. Nearly 500 feet long and 40 feet high, this swath is known locally as the Swamp Scar. The mound of vegetation is riddled with burrows and nooks, and its within these hollows that the Scars most dangerous denizen dwells.

Creatures

  • @UUID[Actor.ZbgFOoDCOXqhJWhz]{Ngara}
  • @UUID[Actor.W2gd0emEVbD8EGmf]{2 Marsh Giants}

Encounter

Severe 10

A powerful spirit naga named Ngara has dwelt in the Swamp Scar for years. As unsuspecting humanoids stumble into the area, she slithers out to enchant them and make them her minions via inveigle. Those who resist are killed and eaten, but those who succumb become the nagas agents, prowling the swamp and surrounding lands in a constant search for new victims to bring to Ngara to serve as meals. She keeps a pair of inveigled marsh giants as guardians here, but her most significant minion is the boggard priest-king @UUID[Actor.sedubjznhIbVfCkD]{Sepoko} (as described @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{here}), whom she allows to run the village of @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{Mbotuu} as her proxy. The naga would love to add the PCs to her little army of hunters and gatherers, but if shes unable to control them, shes just as happy to kill and eat themnot necessarily in that order.

@UUID[Actor.1zNC0kqNI0TJjMFR]{Vines with Rings}: While Ngara has little interest in material wealth (to her, the greatest treasures are mind-controlled minions), she does have a fondness for rings. With no fingers to wear them, shes taken to using mage hand and unseen servant to use roots and vines to dangle her ring collection from the tangles above her lairs entrance. This collection consists 15 nonmagical rings of various values (worth 500 gp total), along with a ring of the ram and a ring of wizardry I.
HT9. The Swamp Scar.name: HT9. The Swamp Scar

TL2. Giants Cave.name: TL2. Giants Cave
TL2. Giants Cave.text:
• Resource
  • Standard

Several wagons, one entirely overturned and all in various stages of destruction, lie scattered around the entrance of a large cave at the base of a barren hillside.

@UUID[Actor.aqW5sp9HPgZgpXxs]{3 Hill Giants}

Severe 12

While the Tiger Lords intrusion forced out many hill giants, a stubborn and powerful family remains entrenched here. These three have ignored offers of allegiance with Armags army in favor of waylaying travelers along the border between the River Kingdoms and Brevoy. The shattered wagons are the remains of their latest conquest, and theyre currently arguing loudly in their cave over the best way to split their ill-gotten gains; they suffer a 2 circumstance penalty to Perception checks as a result. Emboldened by recent victories, the giants give no thought to strategy or tactics, and fight boldly to the death.

@UUID[Actor.fnL2uAsaCpYDwTJt]{Giant's Treasure}: The giants treasure consists of 700 sp, 208 gp, a suit of +1 resilient half-plate, a spyglass, a greater juggernaut mutagen, a potion of flying, and a +2 striking dwarven waraxe.

Resource: Among the spoils the giants have gathered from hunters, poachers, pilgrims, explorers, and merchants are several wagonloads of tools and building materials. The tools grant the kingdom 4 bonus Resource Dice on the next Kingdom turn. In addition, once the giants are defeated or driven off, this hex functions as a Refuge once Claimed.

HT11. Lily Patch.text:
• resource
  • standard

@UUID[Actor.myNEeBzXVmWbHk2X]

SIMPLE HAZARD 12

The azure lily is a relatively notorious carnivorous plant known to grow in Hooktongue Sloughand its also one of the rarest. Its unusual to find more than one of these dangerous plants growing in any part the swamp, and theyre unheard of beyond its borders. By remarkable chance, a grove of azure lilies has bloomed on a low hummock here, appearing as a thick tangle of tough scrub with blue flowers. An azure lilys pollen is rather toxic, with a single lily producing enough pollen to drive those exposed to it into a frenzy. The plants feed on the blood spilled by creatures fighting in their midst but generate only enough pollen to do so once a month. If the PCs merely Travel through this hex and succeed at a @Check[type:flat|dc:11], they miss this dangerous hazard entirely, while a failure leads to [[/gmroll 1d4]] PCs being exposed to the pollen burst. If the PCs @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QIrJJ1pl4H6DctaQ]{Reconnoiter} the hex, they automatically encounter the hazard, with the entire party being exposed to the pollen burst.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.MvMa010Je10GN5dx]{Azure lily pollen:} Azure lily pollen, if harvested without triggering the plant, can be refined into a potent toxin. If the PCs manage to disable this hazard, they can gather enough of the pollen to craft up to five doses of azure lily pollen (detailed on page 584). If the PCs trigger the hazard, succeeding at a @Check[type:nature|dc:33] or @Check[type:survival|dc:33] check after the hazard is defeated gathers only enough for a single dose of azure lily pollen.

Resource: The act of harvesting and preparing azure lily pollen into a poison is a complex process that takes weeks and generally yields only a few doses each month, at best. If the PCs Claim this hex, and if their kingdom has Master rank in Agriculture, they can harvest the pollen via the following Region downtime activity during Kingdom turns.

Harvest Azure Lily Pollen

  • Downtime
  • Region

Requirement Master rank in Agriculture

You or a small group of trained herbalists or naturalists work to harvest and process azure lily pollen in hopes of creating a few doses of the poison. Attempt a @Check[type:agriculture|dc:30|roller:party] check. You must then wait 1 Kingdom turn before attempting this activity again, to give the lilies time to recover.

Critical Success You create 2 doses of @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.gVqrLr3ccIp640UT]{azure lily pollen}.

Success You create 1 dose of @UUID[JournalEntry.kmzkHnl9Xd62T5mx.JournalEntryPage.gVqrLr3ccIp640UT]{azure lily pollen} but must also attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. On a failure, some of the poison makes its way into criminal hands; increase Crime by 1.

Failure You fail to harvest any azure lily pollen, in part because many of the resources make their way into the kingdoms criminal underworld. Increase Crime by 1.

Critical Failure Not only do you fail to harvest any pollen, and not only do resources make their way into the hands of criminals, but whispers and rumors that you allowed this to happen on purpose spread through the kingdom. Increase Unrest by [[/gmroll 1d4]], Corruption by 1, and Crime by 2.
HT11. Lily Patch.name: HT11. Lily Patch

HT12. Tok-Nikrat.text:
• standard

The swamp vegetation recedes here, forming a 100-foot-wide ring of open water surrounding a heavily wooded island 200 feet in diameter. The water is 50 feet deep on average.

Though bog striders are normally solitary creatures, a dozen of them have established something akin to a community in the center of this island. Their leader, an aging veteran named Tok-Tekt, wages a war of attrition against the boggards of the swamp. A boggard raiding party from Mbotuu recently captured his son Ka-Kekt, and the last time the bog strider leader attempted a rescue, the boggards slew three of his people. As a result, Tok-Tekt doesnt expect to see his son again and has all but buried him.

@UUID[Actor.SG8fOxo4SS7bXpav]{12 Bog Striders}

Trivial 10

The bog striders themselves are an insular people who do not seek contact with the landwalker races, but if the PCs rescue Ka-Kekt and escort him here (or simply travel here after rescuing him and letting him make his own way home), theyll be welcomed as friends. If the PCs approach the bog strider enclave before saving Ka-Kekt, and the residents notice their approach, the bog striders greet the party with angry shrill chirpings from the edge of their island; if the PCs attack, the bog striders fight to the death to defend their home. If, on the other hand, the PCs attempt to establish a more peaceful meeting with the insectile people, theyll need to adjust the bog striders initial hostility to a friendly attitude, at which point Tok-Tekt asks them to save his son.

Save the Bog Strider

  • 30 XP
  • 30 Kingdom XP

Tok-Tekts son, Ka-Kekt, is held prisoner in the boggard village of Mbotuu, and must be rescued.

Source: Either Ka-Kekt (@UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.KFbcGdRfmP5z9fns]{area G4}) or Tok-Tekt (area HT12)

Completion: Release Ka-Kekt from his prison hut at area G4. The bog strider is resourceful and knows the swamp, so the PCs dont need to escort him home, but theyll need to return to Tok-Nikrat to fully complete the quest.

Reward: In thanks for saving his son, Tok-Tekt names the landwalker PCs bog friends. The bog striders have no material wealth to share, but Tok-Tekt and his kin are quite knowledgeable about Hooktongue Slough and can inform the PCs of every encounter area in the zone. The PCs can automatically integrate Tok-Nikrat into their kingdom if they Claim this Hex.

Resource: Tok-Nikrat is a very small Freehold. If its brought into the PCs kingdom, they automatically gain a village settlement that contains a single lot of Tenements. All four of its Urban Grid borders are Water borders.
HT12. Tok-Nikrat.name: HT12. Tok-Nikrat

DR1. Speartooths Den.text:
• hidden

A narrow valley filled with thorny plants lies nestled here between two sharp-sloped hills. A successful DC 30 Nature or Perception check or a DC 25 Plains Lore check made while the group is Reconnoitering this hex provides the PCs with evidence that a huge feline predator dwells in the area. Once the big cats tracks are found, a PC can attempt a DC 30 Survival check to Track the predator into a narrow tunnel through a particularly dense patch of thorns.

An immense smilodon dwells in this valley. The creature is quite old, notoriously cantankerous, covered in scars, and bears fangs nearly 2 feet long. The Tiger Lords call this beast Speartooth and revere him almost as a god; they often leave kills in this area to appease the beast. The denizens of Fort Drelev have come to fear Speartooth as well, for the smilodon has not only eluded all attempts by Drelevs forces to capture or kill it, but has also killed no fewer than two dozen of their guards. A notorious man-eater, Speartooths legend is quickly growing throughout the Stolen Lands.

@UUID[Actor.JWyIU1ea3MfPgVJq]{Speartooth}

Severe 11

Roll a @Check[type:flat|dc:11] when the PCs first visit Speartooths lair; on a success, Speartooth is present and rolls Stealth for initiative. If its not around, the saber-toothed tiger returns in [[/gmroll 1d4]] hours, dragging a dead horse in its jaws. If it encounters intruders in its lair, it furiously attacks, focusing on the largest foe first; Speartooth fights to the death to defend its territory.

@UUID[Actor.otUPbqsqiI50I7vM]{Hannis' Remnants}: Among the 24 corpses of the Fort Drelev guards killed by Speartooth lie several ruined weapons and pieces of punctured armor. Of more interest is the body of an infamous hunter Hannis hired from Pitax to take down Speartooththis dead hunters +1 striking shock composite longbow and two remaining viper arrows didnt help when Speartooth pounced on him in his camp and mauled him to death.

Wanted: Speartooth

  • 30 XP

The saber-toothed tiger Speartooth has long plagued the hills west of Hooktongue. They say its killed and eaten over a hundred people! So far, no ones managed to bring the beast down.

Source: Wanted poster (this poster starts to appear once the PCs reach 11th level)

Completion: Find Speartooth, kill it, and deliver its 22-inch-long fangs to the captain of the guard in any settlement in the PCs kingdom.

Reward: The bounty for Speartooth is 2,000 gp.
DR1. Speartooths Den.name: DR1. Speartooths Den

HT6. Mbotuu.text:
• landmark
  • resource

This is the largest boggard settlement in Hooktongue Slough; its explored in detail in @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{Mbotuu}.

Resource: The village of Mbotuu is a Freehold. If it is brought into the PCs kingdom, they automatically gain a village settlement that contains the following two free structures: Barracks and Tenements. One of its Urban Grid borders is a Water border.
HT6. Mbotuu.name: HT6. Mbotuu

Zone 10: Hooktongue.text:
Most of this region consists of the sprawling swamplands of Hooktongue Slough, other than a few hexes to the northeast that are soggy and damp but have relatively solid footing. The swamp itself functions as greater difficult terrain. The large number of rivers and creeks in the swamp allow for the use of small watercrafts such as rafts or rowboats, and if the party is equipped with these vehicles and at least one of the group is an expert in Fishing, River, Sailor, or Swamp Lore, the party can treat these hexes as merely difficult terrain when exploring them.
