Noblesse Oblige.name: Noblesse Oblige
Noblesse Oblige.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial
  • Settlement

Location A settlement that includes at least one mansion or noble villa. If there are no settlements in the kingdom with these structures, this event doesnt occur.

Event A noble family or wealthy benefactor offers to build an improvement to beautify the settlement.

Kingdom Skill Arts

Leader Viceroy

  • Critical Success The nobles build a monument and a park in lots of the players choice at no expense to the kingdom (the Build Structure activity is not required).

  • Success The nobles pay the RP and Commodity cost of either a monument or a park, provided the party uses the Civic activity granted by this settlement in the next Kingdom turn to Build the Structure. The Build Structure check automatically succeeds.

  • Failure Although the nobles had good intentions, bickering among individual aristocrats ultimately prevents the project from ever taking place.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the bickering persists. Gain 1 Unrest and attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]] flat check. On a failure, your kingdom suffers a Feud event on the next turns Event phase (in addition to any other event).

Monster Activity.name: Monster Activity
Monster Activity.text:
Event +0

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Hex

Location A claimed hex chosen by the GM that isnt in the influence of a settlement

Event A monster, or even an entire group of monsters attacks the kingdom! Determine the encounter by rolling on the random encounter table for the Stolen Lands Zone that is the same level as the kingdoms level (see the Stolen Lands Zones table on page 45). If the kingdom is 20th level, roll on the Branthlend Mountains table (page 117) and apply the elite adjustments (Pathfinder Bestiary 6) to the creatures.

Kingdom Skill Defense

Leader Ruler

  • Critical Success The monsters are slain or driven off without harm to your kingdom. Even better, an unexpected claim of treasure gained from the monster lair grants [[/r 1d4 #Luxuries Gained]] Luxuries and 2 bonus Resource Dice on the next turn.

  • Success The monsters attack some of your citizens but are driven off before they do too much damage. The threat persists, and while fear continues to slowly spread, your kingdom suffers no physical damage at this time. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The monsters rampage terrorizes the countryside and results in frightening rumors even in the heart of the kingdoms safest cities. The closest Farmland or Work Site to the monsters hex is destroyed. Gain [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest and 1 Decay.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the monsters assaults spread into the settlement closest to the monsters hex, spreading the danger they represent more and more through your kingdom. If any of your settlements borders arent protected by water or a wall, or if the monster can fly or swim (as appropriate) across any of your protective borders, the monster enters the settlement and one structure chosen by the players is reduced to rubble. Gain [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest and 2 Decay. Otherwise, the monsters ability to harm the settlement is hampered by your defenses. Gain 1 Unrest and one of the settlements walls is destroyed; uncheck it on your Urban Grid.

Resolution This event continues until you achieve a critical success on the check or until the PCs step in to track down and defeat the monster(s) themselves.

Visiting Celebrity.text:
Event +1

  • Beneficial
  • Settlement

LocationA randomly determined settlement

Event A celebrity from another nation or even a distant land visits one of your settlements, causing a sudden influx of notoriety, visitors, and lavish spending. The GM determines the nature of the visiting celebrity.

Kingdom Skill Arts

Leader Emissary

  • Critical Success The visit is a rousing success. Not only are your citizens delighted by the visitor, but the visitor is quite taken with your kingdom and leaves you with a parting gift. Choose two of the following: gain 4 bonus Resource Dice next turn, gain [[/r 1d6 #Luxuries Gained]] Luxury commodities, or reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Reduction]].

  • Success The visit is a success, and the celebrity enjoys their time in your kingdom. Choose one of the parting gifts from those listed in the critical success result.

  • Failure The visitor has an agreeable if pedestrian visit. Reduce Unrest by 1.

  • Critical Failure The visitor leaves unimpressed and spreads reports of their unpleasant visit abroad. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]]. The next time your kingdom has a Visiting Celebrity, increase that events level modifier by 2.

Diplomatic Overture.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial

Event Another nation or group sends an ambassador to your kingdom. The group sending the overture is randomly selected from the Negotiation DCs sidebar on page 519. If the kingdom has established diplomatic relations with that group, the event proceeds with the Statecraft check below. If the kingdom has not yet established diplomatic relations with the group, this event instead gives the kingdom the opportunity to immediately use the Send Diplomatic Envoy Leadership activity.

Kingdom Skill Statecraft

Leader Emissary

  • Critical Success The diplomatic meeting is incredibly successful, and you can choose two of the following benefits: gain 5 Commodities of your choice, gain an additional 2 Resource Dice at the start of your next turn, or automatically establish a trade agreement with the group.

  • Success As success, but choose only one benefit.

  • Failure Your meeting is cordial but unproductive.

  • Critical Failure Your diplomatic meeting goes poorly. Unless you bribe the group with either 5 Commodities of your choice or 10 RP, they break off diplomatic relations with you. Reestablishing diplomatic relations can be attempted via future Send Diplomatic Envoy activities in the usual manner, but with a 2 circumstance penalty.

Sensational Crime.name: Sensational Crime
Sensational Crime.text:
Event +1

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location A randomly determined settlement in the kingdom

Event A notorious serial killer, deadly arsonist, flamboyant jewel thief, or otherwise sensational criminal plagues your kingdom.

Kingdom Skill Intrigue

Leader Warden

  • Critical Success The criminal has been caught and the one-person crime wave ends. Reduce Crime by 2, and reduce one other Ruin of your choice by 2. In addition, if you achieve this level of success on the turn this event begins, the criminal was caught in the act of perpetrating their first crime but prevented from completing it; in this case, you discourage future criminalsreduce Crime by 1.

  • Success You foil the criminals current plans and perhaps arrest some accomplices, but the mastermind gets away to plot future crimes. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The criminal succeeds in their crime and escapes justice. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] and Crime by 1.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the criminal also makes fools out of law enforcement, frames an innocent for the crime, or taunts the authorities for their failure. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Increase]], Crime by 2, and one other Ruin of your choice by 2.

Resolution This continuous event ends when you achieve a critical success on the check. Alternately, the GM could create a short adventure to allow the PCs to step in, track down, and confront the criminal to end the event.

Political Calm.text:
Event -1

  • Beneficial

Event A sudden absence of political machinations and distracting intrigue coincides with a rise in public approval for its leaders.

Kingdom Skill Politics

Leader Ruler

  • Critical Success You capitalize upon the public approval with efficiency and speed. Reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Reduction]] or reduce one Ruin of your choice by 1. Gain a +2 status bonus to all checks made to resolve events during your next Kingdom turn.

  • Success Loyalty is up across the board. Reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Reduction]].

  • Failure The calm is a refreshing change, but people sense it cannot last. Reduce Unrest by 1.

  • Critical Failure Failure The calm simply hides deeper plotting simmering in the shadows. Increase one Ruin by 1.
Political Calm.name: Political Calm

Expansion Demand.text:
Event +0

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous

Event The citizens of your kingdom want expansion! If you successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.kingmaker-features.Item.cvOXpo1Sy8nfXfPO]{Claimed a Hex} this turn, the result of your check for this event is improved one degree.

Kingdom Skill Exploration

Leader Warden

  • Critical Success Your citizens are pleased with the growth of the kingdom.

  • Success You satisfy the citizens demands for growth, but if you dont successfully Claim a Hex during your next Kingdom turn, increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure Your citizens remain unhappy with your kingdoms growth. Increase Unrest by 1. If you dont successfully Claim a hex during your next Kingdom turn, increase Unrest by 1 again.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but increase the Unrest by 2.

Resolution Achieve either a success or critical success at this event.
Expansion Demand.name: Expansion Demand

Kingdom Events.name: Kingdom Events
Kingdom Events.text:
As the PCs kingdom grows, all manner of unusual or irregular events will affect its fortunes and guide its growth. There are two categories of kingdom events: story events that occur as a result of the campaign plotline and random events.

Story events are resolved when they occur, as detailed in the earlier chapters of this Adventure Path and often include greater details for how the PCs can take part in resolving the event. These events take place during regular play even though they draw upon kingdom statistics. Theyre usually resolved during downtime.

Random events are resolved entirely by the kingdom itself and take place within the @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.haAwaaMEbW4BWAuK]{Event phase} of a Kingdom turn. A flat check at the start of this phase determines whether a random event occurs, although you could roll this check in advance for any number of Kingdom turns or even just choose which events are going to take place for a span of time. Determining the events that will play out in advance gives you the ability to build narratives during play to foreshadow upcoming events (so that when they occur, they arent completely unexpected) and might inspire interesting ways to combine events with the ongoing campaigns story.

Resolving Kingdom Events

All kingdom events resolve in downtime, although for some story events, there may be periods of exploration or encounter mode before or after an events resolution. Some kingdom events grant boons or benefits, while others can harm a kingdom by costing resources, increasing Unrest or Ruin, penalizing activities, or damaging structures. In many cases, the PCs will be able to attempt Kingdom skill checks to bolster benefits or minimize disasters.

Its possible to have more than one kingdom event occur during a Kingdom turn. In this case, the players decide the order of the events.

Kingdom Event DCs

A kingdom events DC is always the kingdoms Control DC modified by the events level modifier.

Event DC = Control DC + events level modifier

Kingdom Event Descriptions

Kingdom events are described in the following format.

Event Name

Event Modifier

The kingdoms event modifier is the value you apply to the kingdoms level to determine the events level, for the purposes of determining XP rewards (so if a 1st-level kingdom is experiencing a +1 event, that events level is 2). Each kingdom event has a list of traits that convey its properties at a glance. Beneficial events provide boons and benefits to the kingdom. Dangerous events threaten the kingdom. Continuous events play out during multiple consecutive Event phases until the event has been resolved (see the events Resolution entry). Hex events take place in a specific hex in the kingdom, while Settlement events take place in a specific settlementskill checks to resolve these events receive item bonuses only from structures that influence that hex (in the case of a hex event) or that are part of that settlement (in the case of a settlement event). Hex and Settlement events effects may be enhanced or diminished if the site has (or lacks) specific features.

Location This entry explains how to determine where a hex or settlement event takes place; the entry is omitted from kingdom-wide events.

Event The events effect on the kingdom is described here, along with any skill checks that can be attempted to affect the event.

Kingdom Skill This lists the Kingdom skill thats used to determine the outcome of the event, along with any situational modifiers; Leader PC leaders are particularly helpful in resolving events. If the leadership role listed here is occupied by a PC who is not incurring a vacancy penalty, the check made to determine the events outcome gains a +1 circumstance bonus; this bonus increases to +2 once a kingdom reaches 9th level, and to +3 at 15th level. (The General leadership role never appears in this context, as the General focuses their specific influence on Warfare related activities; see @UUID[JournalEntry.TBY1Ir2GtQJqW8VD]{Appendix 3}.)

  • Event Outcomes The possible outcomes of the skill check made to deal with the event are presented here.

Resolution This entry explains how a continuous event can be resolved.

Special This lists any special conditions that alter the event.

Discovery.name: Discovery
Discovery.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial

Event Scholars unearth a bit of ancient lore or devise important new research of their own.

Kingdom Skill Scholarship

Leader Counselor

  • Critical Success Your discovery brings glory and a boon to your resources! At the start of your next Kingdom turn, gain 1 Fame or Infamy point (as appropriate) and gain 6 bonus Resource Dice. Your people are amazed. Reduce Unrest by 2.

  • Success Your discovery is a helpful (but not overly amazing) boon to your kingdoms resources. On your next turn, gain 3 bonus Resource Dice.

  • Failure Your discovery is of some academic interest but ultimately of limited use. Gain 1 bonus Resource Die at the start of your next turn.

  • Critical Failure Your discovery turns out to be a dead end and a wasteful boondoggle. Reduce your total Resource Dice by 2 next turn.

Drug Den.text:
Event +1

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location The largest settlement in the kingdom; the GM secretly selects one of the Residential lots to house a drug den.

Event One of the Residential lots in your settlement has become an illicit hive for trading harmful and addictive drugs, and as long as it continues to operate, it could bring ruin to your entire kingdom.

Kingdom Skill Intrigue

Leader Counselor

  • Critical Success You uncover and stop the drug ring before it causes a lot of damage, bringing counseling to those who may need it.

  • Success You work to minimize the damage done by the illicit drug trade, but the activity continues. Gain 1 Unrest.

  • Failure Drug dealers continue to spread their influence. Addiction increases and harms productivity, and drug-related crime grows. Increase Unrest, Crime, and Decay by 1 each.

  • Critical Failure Your attempt is a total failure. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]]{1d4} and increase Crime and Decay (one score by 1, the other score by 2). In addition, the Residential lot that the drug den was located in is reduced to Rubble. The drug den then moves to another lot chosen by the GM (see Location, above).

Resolution A critical success on the check ends this continuous event. Optionally, the GM can instead build a short adventure for the PCs to infiltrate the drug den and defeat the criminals in encounter mode.
Drug Den.name: Drug Den

Pilgrimage.name: Pilgrimage
Pilgrimage.text:
Event +1

  • Beneficial

Event A large number of pilgrims flock to your settlements to celebrate their high holy days or to bask in your kingdoms faith. If your kingdom does not have at least one shrine, temple, or cathedral, this event does not occur.

Kingdom Skill Folklore

Leader Magister

  • Critical Success Pilgrims visit all of your settlements to engage in acts of worship. Not only do they provide their own food and supplies, but they also bring gifts to your shrines, temples, and cathedrals. Gain [[/r 1d6 #Luxuries Gained]] Luxuries, reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Reduction]], and reduce one Ruin of your choice by 1.

  • Success The pilgrims celebrate their holy days at your settlements, and their good cheer and attitudes prove infectious. Reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Reduction]].

  • Failure As success, but the pilgrims put a strain on your kingdoms resources. Increase Consumption by [[/r 1d4 #Consumption Increase]] on the next turn.

  • Critical Failure The pilgrims hold their festivals, but their devout displays by a few strident zealots who stay behind stir up controversy with locals of other faiths. Increase Corruption by 1 and increase Consumption by [[/r 1d4 #Consumption Increase]] on the next turn.

Outstanding Success.name: Outstanding Success
Outstanding Success.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial

Event One of your kingdoms citizens brings glory to the kingdom, be it through an artistic masterpiece, an architectural marvel, a grand voyage of discovery, a landmark academic treatise, a new magical theory, or a similar discovery, as decided upon by the party.

Kingdom Skill Arts

Leader Counselor

  • Critical Success The citizens success is truly legendary. Gain 3 bonus Resource Dice on your next turn.

  • Success This success brings fame and fortune to your kingdom. Gain 1 bonus Resource Die on your next turn.

  • Failure The success inspires imitators and rapidly loses its specialness, but you suffer no jealousy-driven backlash.

  • Critical Failure Scandal! Either the artists sinister motives are exposed by their sudden fame, competitors work to undermine them, or the public simply refuses to accept the success. Increase Unrest by 1 and Corruption by 1.

Archaeological Find.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial
  • Hex

Location A claimed hex of the GMs choosing but not in the influence of a settlement

Event You hear that a well-preserved ruin in a remote reach of your kingdom may contain historical artifacts connected to people who lived in your land long ago. You can send a team of archaeologists to investigate.

Kingdom Skill Exploration

Leader Viceroy

  • Critical Success The site proves to be an ancient Kellid settlement that greatly predates the Taldan expansion into the region. Your people are delighted by the discovery. Reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Reduction]], and until the end of your next Kingdom turn, all Culture- and Economy-based skill checks gain a +2 circumstance bonus. If any of your settlements has a Museum, you put archaeological findings from this hex on display to the further delight of your citizens. Reduce Unrest by an additional 1.

  • Success The site proves to be remains of an old Taldan camp from the Second Army of Exploration. The discovery is interesting but not particularly surprising. Reduce Unrest by 2.

  • Failure The site proves to be the remains of a relatively recent village abandoned during a previous attempt to settle the Stolen Lands. Nothing particularly interesting is discovered.

  • Critical Failure You never hear from your archaeologists again. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] and Decay by 1. You can try to investigate this site again as a Region activity during the Activity phase of any Kingdom turn by attempting another Exploration check, but as the investigation has proven dangerous, the DC increases by 2.
Archaeological Find.name: Archaeological Find

Food Shortage.text:
Event +1

  • Dangerous

Event Spoilage, treachery, or bad luck has caused a food shortage this turn.

Kingdom Skill Agriculture

Leader Treasurer

  • Critical Success Through careful rationing, you manage to get through the shortage without harm.

  • Success Your shortages are manageable, with some workers going hungry. Your kingdoms Consumption is increased by 1 at the start of the next turn. Attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:6]. On a failure, this event reoccurs next turn (in addition to any other event that would occur).

  • Failure The shortages are severe. Your kingdoms Consumption is increased by 1 per settlement at the start of the next turn. Attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:16]. On a failure, this event reoccurs next turn (in addition to any other event that would occur).

  • Critical Failure The shortages are catastrophic. Increase Unrest by 2 and Strife by 1, and your kingdoms Consumption is increased by 1 per settlement at the start of the next turn. This event reoccurs next turn (in addition to any other event that would occur).
Food Shortage.name: Food Shortage

Festive Invitation.name: Festive Invitation
Festive Invitation.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial

Event Your kingdoms leaders are invited to a festival in a region in which the kingdom has established diplomatic relations. The GM chooses an existing diplomatic ally to send the invitation and should customize the details of that event to match that ally; if your kingdom has no diplomatic relations, this event has no effect. When your leaders attend the festival, you can bring up to 4 Resource Dice as gifts to the festival; reduce the number of Resource Dice you roll on the next Kingdom turn by this amount.

Kingdom Skill Arts

Leader Ruler

  • Critical Success You entertain and delight your host and bolster your alliance with their people, and they gratefully reciprocate your gifts. For each Resource Die you brought as a gift, choose a type of Commodity. Then roll the die; you gain that amount of that Commodity. Attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. If you are successful, your ally extends a Diplomatic Overture or a Visiting Celebrity event (equal chance of either) during the Event phase of your next Kingdom turn (in addition to any other event that would occur).

  • Success The festival is a delight. If you brought Resource Dice as gifts, choose a Commodity. You gain an amount of that Commodity equal to the number of Resource Dice you brought as gifts.

  • Failure The festival was entertaining enough, but if you brought Resource Dice as gifts, theyre not reciprocated.

  • Critical Failure One of your leaders committed a faux pas during the festival, and the celebration ends prematurely. Attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. If you fail, your host cuts ties with your kingdom; gain 1 Unrest. (In the future, you may attempt to reestablish diplomatic relations in the usual way).

Plague.text:
Event +1

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location The largest settlement in the kingdom

Event A deadly sickness strikes one of your settlements. You take a 2 status penalty to all Civic activities made in a settlement suffering from a plague unless the settlement has a sewer system.

Kingdom Skill Defense

Leader Ruler

  • Critical Success You halt the spread of the plague and are able to cure it, but even so, the plagues effects reduce your Resource Dice on the next turn by 2.

  • Success The plague continues! Gain [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest and increase one of your Ruins by 1.

  • Failure The plague spreads and claims more victims. Gain [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest and increase all of your Ruins by 1.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the plague spreads to the nearest unaffected settlement in your kingdom. Treat additional plagues in different settlements as separate continuous Plague events.

Resolution This Plague event ends if you achieve a critical success on the check or after you achieve a total of 4 successes with the Provide Care activity (a critical success with Provide Care counts as 2 successes in this case).

Special If the plague strikes a settlement that has no dumps, filth in the streets allows the disease to spread more easily. You take a 4 item penalty to checks to resolve this event. On the other hand, if a plague-stricken settlement has a sewer system, the increased sanitation provides a +2 item bonus to checks to resolve this event.
Plague.name: Plague

Vandals.name: Vandals
Vandals.text:
Event +1

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location A randomly determined settlement

Event Vandals, troublemakers, and dissidents destroy property in your settlement.

Kingdom Skill Industry

Leader Warden

  • Critical Success You root out the vandals and stop them from causing any damage.

  • Success The vandals are caught in the act of damaging an area in your settlement. The event ends, but on the next turn, the damage done reduces your Resource Dice by 2.

  • Failure The vandals damage and deface several minor structures in the settlement and remain uncaught for now. Fortunately, the damage done can be easily repaired, but you start the next turn with 4 fewer Resource Dice.

  • Critical Failure The vandals also manage to reduce one structure (chosen by the players) to rubble. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] and reduce your Resource Dice next turn by 4.

Resolution This event ends when you succeed at the check.

Natural Disaster.name: Natural Disaster
Natural Disaster.text:
Event +2

  • Dangerous

Event A natural cataclysm such as a wildfire, devastating weather, earthquake, or flood (as determined by the GM) devastates your kingdom. While in a worst-case scenario the disasters immediate and most destructive effects affect a single settlement, many of its effects are larger in scope and can affect the entire kingdom.

Kingdom Skill Wilderness

Leader Magister

  • Critical Success You prepared well for the disaster. While disruptive, the damage is minimized.

  • Success Your quick response keeps your people safe and allows you to recover quickly. During the next turn, reduce your Resource Dice total by 4.

  • Failure The disaster causes severe damage. Choose one claimed hex in which you have a Farmland or Work Site; that feature is destroyed. Gain 1 Decay and [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest. During the next turn, reduce your Resource Dice total by 6.

  • Critical Failure Multiple hexes are totally devastated. Choose [[/r 1d4 #Hexes Devastated]] claimed hexes in which you have Farmlands or Work Sites; those features are destroyed. Gain 1 Decay for each hex affected, and gain [[/r 2d6 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest. In addition, one settlement of your choice is particularly hard hit; that settlement immediately suffers the effects of a @UUID[.ug1AYlKJKtSUeLYH]{Local Disaster}. During the next turn, reduce your Resource Dice total by 8.

Urban Outbreak.name: Urban Outbreak
Urban Outbreak.text:
Event +2

  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location The settlement the PCs are currently located in, or the closest settlement to the PCs location if theyre not in a settlement.

Event A monster blooms from a citizen in the city itself and runs rampage through the streets! The type of monster should be chosen by the GM; its level should equal the partys level + 2 (a Moderate threat encounter). The PCs can choose to resolve this event with a Kingdom skill check, or they can travel to the settlement the monster is rampaging in to challenge it in encounter mode. If they dont defeat the monster by the end of the next day, treat this event as having a Critical Failure result.

Kingdom Skill Defense

Leader Warden

  • Critical Success The monster is defeated before any more lives are lost.

  • Success The monster is defeated but slew a citizen. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The monster slays several citizens before it is defeated. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] and Decay by 1.

  • Critical Failure The monster continues to rampage unopposed. This event becomes Continuous and occurs every day until the monster is defeated; additional Cult events still occur as normal. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Increase]] and Decay by 2.

Assassination Attempt.name: Assassination Attempt
Assassination Attempt.text:
Event +1

  • dangerous

Event One of your leaders or prominent citizens is targeted by assassins. The GM determines who hired these assassins, then attempts a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. On a success, the target is an NPC assigned to a leadership role. On a failure (or if the PCs have no NPC leaders), the target is a notable NPC in the kingdom, preferably one with whom the PCs have established a friendly relationship.

Kingdom Skill Intrigue

Leader Warden

  • Critical Success The assassins are caught, driven off, or otherwise thwarted without ever endangering their targets. The targeted NPC may not even realize they were in danger, but criminal elements in your nation take notice. Reduce Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Reduction]] and reduce one Ruin of your choice by 1.

  • Success The assassins reach their target but are driven off or defeated before the NPC is harmed.

  • Failure The assassins reach their target and manage to harm but not kill the target before they are driven off or defeated. Gain [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest, and if the NPC was a leader, they are removed from that leadership role until the end of the next Kingdom turn.

  • Critical Failure The assassins slay the NPC and escape. If the NPC was a leader, that leadership role is now vacant. Gain [[/r 2d4 #Unrest Increase]] Unrest and [[/r 1d4 #Decay Increase]] points to Decay.

Special If this event occurs while the kingdom is at war, increase the events level modifier to +3.

Crop Failure.text:
Event +0

  • Dangerous
  • Hex

Location A Farmland hex of the GMs choice. If there are no Farmlands in the kingdom, this event has no effect.

Event Pests, blight, or bad weather damage the harvest.

Kingdom Skill Agriculture

Leader Treasurer

  • Critical Success You contain the damage from the crop failure without it impacting your kingdoms resources.

  • Success You contain the crop failure, but not before it impacts your kingdom. Increase your kingdoms Consumption by 1 during the next Kingdom turn.

  • Failure The crop failure wipes out entire fields. Increase your kingdoms Consumption by [[/r 1d4+1 #Consumption Increase]]{1d4+1} during the next Kingdom turn.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the crop failure is so devastating that the Farmland is destroyed.
Crop Failure.name: Crop Failure

Building Demand.text:
Event -1

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location The largest settlement in the nation

Event The citizens of the affected settlement demand that a particular structure be either built or demolished (equal chance of either). If the citizens demand a new structure, the GM chooses one as close to the kingdoms level as possible, preferably one that decreases Unrest when built. If the citizens demand a structure be demolished, the GM chooses one that best fits the storyline of the campaign, preferably one whose item bonus or other benefits have been rendered obsolete by newer structures. If you are willing to commit each upcoming Civic activity granted by this settlement to attempting the requested Build Structure or Demolish activity until they succeed, you do not attempt the check.

Kingdom Skill Politics

Leader Viceroy

  • Critical Success You persuade the citizens to give up their demands.

  • Success You quell the citizens demands for now, but they are not happy about your refusal to comply. Gain 1 Unrest.

  • Failure The citizens continue their demands and some refuse to work in protest. Gain 1 Unrest and roll 2 fewer Resource dice at the start of your next turn.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but violence during the protests also increases Decay by 1.

Resolution You can end this continuous event by critically succeeding or succeeding at the check or successfully building or demolishing the requested structure.
Building Demand.name: Building Demand

Sacrifices.name: Sacrifices
Sacrifices.text:
Event +2

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Hex

Location A claimed hex in the area of influence of a settlement secretly chosen by the GM

Event A cabal of cultists begin snatching citizens and preparing them for sacrifice to their vile god. The cultists maintain a hidden base of operations somewhere near one of the kingdoms settlements.

Kingdom Skill Exploration

Leader Emissary

  • Critical Success The cultists are defeated, and many of your captured citizens are rescued.

  • Success The cult continues to function, but you have managed to determine which hex their base of operations is located in. The DC to defeat the Sacrifices event is reduced by 4 in subsequent turns. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Failure The cultists prey on travelers, hunters, trappers, and anyone else who strays too far from civilization. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d4 #Unrest Increase]] and one Ruin of your choice by 1.

  • Critical Failure As failure, but the cultists start snatching victims from your settlements. If youve already determined where theyve based their operations, they successfully relocate to a new secret hex as chosen by the GM, and the DC to defeat the cultists returns to normal. Increase Unrest by [[/r 1d6 #Unrest Increase]] and two Ruins of your choice by 2.

Resloution A critical success ends this continuous event. The GM can instead build a short adventure for the PCs to track down and defeat the sinister cultists in encounter mode, provided the PCs know where to go to confront the cultists!

Feud.name: Feud
Feud.text:
Event +0

  • Continuous
  • Dangerous
  • Settlement

Location Two settlements of the GMs choice. If the kingdom doesnt have at least two settlements, then this event has no effect.

Event A rivalry between influential groups (nobles, guilds, politicians, etc.) from two different settlements has escalated and may soon turn violent.

Kingdom Skill Politics

Leader Counselor

  • Critical Success You mediate the rivals differences and not only get them to drop their feud, but also broker an alliance between the two. The feud ends, and the rivals are particularly productive during the next turn. Gain 2 bonus Resource Dice at the beginning of the next Kingdom turn.

  • Success You get the rivals to back down, though their mutual dislike simmers behind the scenes. The feud continues into the next turn.

  • Failure You fail to quiet the rivals and they continue duels, rumormongering, intrigue, and strife. The conflict prevents you from recruiting armies in the two affected settlements until the next Kingdom turn. Increase Unrest by 1.

  • Critical Failure The rivals ignore royal commands and disrupt both settlements with their private war. The ongoing feud prevents you from recruiting armies in the two affected settlements until the feud ends. In addition, skirmishing increases Unrest by 2 and one Ruin of your choice by 1; these increases are doubled to 4 Unrest and 2 Ruin if you critically failed this check last turn.

Resolution The feud ends when you achieve a critical success on the check. If this continuous event has occurred for at least 3 consecutive Kingdom turns, you may choose to resolve it at the end of a Kingdom turn by spending 4 Resource Dice of RP to pay off the feuding factions.

Food Surplus.name: Food Surplus
Food Surplus.text:
Event +0

  • Beneficial

Event Local crops thrive, hunters do very well, or livestock numbers are greater than expected. If this event occurs, it immediately ends any ongoing food shortage event.

Kingdom Skill Agriculture

Leader Treasurer

  • Critical Success Your bumper crops include wild harvests that allow you to skip the entire Pay Consumption step of the Upkeep phase of your next Kingdom turn. Gain [[/r 1d6 #Food Commodities Gained]]{1d6} Food Commodities.

  • Success Your excess crops lead to increased supplies. Treat your Consumption during the next Kingdom turn as 2 lower than its actual score and gain [[/r 1d6 #Food Commodities Gained]]{1d6} Food Commodities.

  • Failure The food surplus isnt as huge as youd expected. Treat your Consumption during the next turn as 1 lower than its actual score.

  • Critical Failure What you thought was an excess of food is infested with spoilage, ergot, or other contamination. Increase Unrest by 1 and one Ruin of your choice by 1.

A7. Alcoves of the Watchers.text:
Three alcoves, each holding a humanoid form wrapped tightly in spiderwebs, stand on the east wall of this room. Deep grooves and scratches in the walls and floor hint at a vicious fight here a long time ago.

A trio of morrigna psychopomps accompanied the Pharasmins into the dungeon to aid in creating the Spiral Seal, only to be betrayed by Korog after he discovered the techniques to become a graveknight. Knowing the morrignas wouldnt approve of his blasphemous plan, he tricked them into entering a sort of torpor in this room, cocooned by spiderwebs yet prepared to break free at a moments notice to intercept intruders. He then forbade his followers from ever disturbing them.

@UUID[Actor.DPEmRRXYevk3ADqW]{Morrigna Psychopomps (3)}

Moderate 16

The three morrignasHastania, Oreshki, and Vatinitelhave remained in their torpor for so long that theyve lost track of time, but as soon as anyone enters this room, they emerge from their wrappings at once. The morrignas assume the PCs are cultists if none of them obviously appear to be followers of Pharasma, and they neither ask for nor offer any mercy as they attack on sight.

If the PCs include an obvious follower of Pharasma, or manage to convince the psychopomps theyre servants of Pharasma or opponents of the cult via a @Check[type:deception|dc:39] or @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:39] check or a @Check[type:pharasma-lore|dc:34] or @Check[type:religion|dc:34] check to stay the psychopomps attack (this is an action with the Auditory, Concentrate, and Linguistic traits), the morrignas are more circumspect. They ask what brings the PCs to the site of an important barrier between the forces of Yog-Sothoth and devotees of Pharasma. They only allow the PCs to pass if they demonstrate, as a group, that they are persuasive and respectful. Doing so requires a PC to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.DCb62iCBrJXy0Ik6]{Request} safe passage with a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:39|traits:action:request] check. If at least one PC succeeds at this check and no PC critically fails it, the morrignas let them come and go from this room as they pleaseotherwise they stand firm in their roles as guardians. They wont attack the PCs unless they attempt to force their way forward to area @UUID[.a6CPQ3ZvcruRxClE]{A8}. If the PCs approached from that area, any attempt to convince the psychopomps that theyre not cultists suffers a 2 circumstance penalty.

The morrignas consider any mention of Pharasmin graveknights to be a trick; they assume the Kellids that accompanied them here are long dead and wouldnt stoop to a blasphemy like undeath. Success at a @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:37] check is necessary to convince them of the truth; in this case, the morrignas investigate in person and either fight against the graveknights or instruct the PCs on how to dispose of their armor to prevent the graveknights from reforming. If the PCs cant convince the morrignas that theyre telling the truth, the psychopomps assume the accusations of undeath are a blasphemous ruse and attack out of indignation.

XP Award: If the PCs convince the morrignas to let them pass or recruit their aid against the undead Pharasmins, award the PCs XP as though they had defeated the morrignas in combat.
A7. Alcoves of the Watchers.name: A7. Alcoves of the Watchers

B12. Black Sand Cavern.text:
The door leading into this room from area @UUID[.Y0yPoSJNmiTvJA53]{B2} is covered with a large drift of rubble; opening it from that side requires a successful @Check[type:athletics|dc:36] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Force it Open}.

This natural cavern is heaped with drifts of rubble and gravel. A track through the rubble connects a curved hallway entering the room from the north to another curved hallway entering from the east.

This natural cavern was here when Foras and the Thresholders made the spiral, and they used the chamber as a place to dump a lot of the loose stone from building the spiral itself, filling in much of what was once a larger pit to the south.

@UUID[Actor.hD8Su0awrJYwmDXh]{Elite Quelaunts (3)}

Severe 16

A trio of alien entitiesquelauntshas dwelt in this cavern since long before the Thresholders arrived. The quelaunts initially attacked the Thresholders, but they broke off hostilities as they recognized certain familiar qualities in the cults leader. Since then, the three quelaunts have remained here feeding on the ambient emotions of the place. They find the frustrations, hopes, and disappointments of creatures who do not age to be quite delicious, but they wont skip the opportunity to feed on more traditional emotions the PCs may bring with them. The quelaunts fight to the death.
B12. Black Sand Cavern.name: B12. Black Sand Cavern

B2. Chamber of the Worm.name: B2. Chamber of the Worm
B2. Chamber of the Worm.text:
This enormous room contains heaps of glittering stones, each the size of a fist, all haphazardly piled along the west and south walls. A narrow, curved track on the floor leads from the curved hall to the north into the curved hall to the east. In the northeast corner of the room, a terrace-like set of tall stairs leads up to a narrow stone door.

@UUID[Actor.pT5hfxcsG7eV5oxh]{Niodrhast}

Severe 16

This room serves as the home for an eldritch envoy from the Darklandsa neothelid named Niodrhast. Before the Spiral Seal, Niodrhast came and went via teleportation, and served the Thresholders as a sort of supply route for strange components or other needs. The neothelid went into hibernation soon after the Spiral Seal locked it in place; it wakens from its torpor slowly now that the seal has been broken. It attacks any intruders into this realm at once, but if the PCs are forced to retreat and return, theyll find Niodrhast has vacated the area, having returned to Denebrum to catch up on the centuries it missed.

@UUID[Actor.GroRcpNkb9F8sVJT]{Concealed Talisman}: One of the quartz gems on the floor has a dispelling sliver talisman lodged within it. This treasure is well concealed among the heaps of valueless quartz, however, and a PC who @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Searches} the piles must succeed at a @Check[type:perception|dc:36|traits:action:search] check to locate it.

B3. Rune-Scribed Room.text:
The walls, floors, and ceiling of this room are inscribed with thousands of tiny runes, each glittering with a pale, cold light like that of a distant star. A staircase ascends to the southeast, and a door stands in the northwest corner. A curved hall exits to the west and another exits to the north. By the runes worn away between those two halls, its clear that a significant amount of foot traffic has come and gone between them.

The runes here arent magical except for their glow, but they represent thousands of different components of the eldritch worship of Yog-Sothoth. Each rune represents a deeper concept that requires decades of study to understand. The cultists pass into this room as part of their ritual journey along the spiral, choosing a single different rune to stare at and meditate upon each time they come through here.

The door to the northeast leads to a short hallway culminating in a door to area @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9]{B13}, a room with a similar meditative purpose. Cutting from one of these rooms to the other can be disruptive to meditations, so just inside the hallway near each door, a small metal bell has been rigged to ring when the opposite door is opened, alerting occupants that someone is coming through the hallway. The mechanism that triggers the bells can be spotted before a door is opened with success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:35] check, after which its an easy @Check[type:thievery|dc:25|traits:action:disable-device] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable} the bell.

The staircase leads up to area @UUID[.YDka3Bsn8Byl9TIL]{A17}.
B3. Rune-Scribed Room.name: B3. Rune-Scribed Room

B11. Lower Bunk Room.name: B11. Lower Bunk Room
B11. Lower Bunk Room.text:
Sleeping niches are carved into the walls of this room at varying levels. A thin mist fills this room.

This bunk room is similar to area @UUID[.iGCiO2WLCCxc103m]{A16}, but this room has niches carved into the walls rather than slabs protruding from them. The same type of worn leather pallet lies in each niche.

  • @UUID[Actor.3kyS4KzEmG8Eyl4N]{Hermeticist}
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Disciples (4)}

Encounter

Severe 16

A stern hermeticist named Surebna and four disciples are currently resting here, although they are quick to leap into action upon any sign of trouble. This room is too small for all these combatants to effectively fight at once, so the disciples work to push foes into area @UUID[.0kSqo5oKQtD59pcX]{B10} where they have more room to move around. The four disciples fight to the death, but Surebna has a bit more self-preservation: he retreats to area @UUID[.Lax7DSMrgnvjmcyh]{B12} if reduced to fewer than 40 Hit Points, hoping to rouse the guardians there against intruders.

A2. Hall of the Oathkeepers.text:
This large hall has doors to the west, southwest, and south. Also to the west, a steep staircase ascends and curves out of sight. Several pillars, each carved to resemble a tentacle reaching from the floor to the ceiling, surround the room and give an ominous sense of being caged by a monstrous beast.

The door leading south opens on a hall wholly blocked by rubble from an ancient collapse that occurred during the initial invasion of the dungeon by the Pharasmins. Several days of work with the proper tools (or much more quickly at the GMs discretion with the right magic) could restore this hallway to area @UUID[.1KntnnZpwVknGZcI]{A14}.

Four of the Pharasmins who chose to abandon their faith in order to stand forever against the cult remain here as graveknights. The armor they wear bears Pharasmas religious symbola spiraling cometbut the symbol itself appears smeared with fresh blood that constantly wells up and drips to the floor only to have those spatters fade away. Success on a @Check[type:religion|dc:10|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check is all thats needed to identify Pharasmas symbol, but a critical success reveals that the blood dripping from it indicates very specific blasphemies against Pharasmathe creatures that wear this armor no longer serve her.

@UUID[Actor.P1kWLRlEPTcZ3uzD]{Kellid Graveknights (4)}

Moderate 16

The graveknights dont expect intruders to come down the stairs, as they believe the Spiral Seal is still in place. So long as the PCs havent loudly announced their presence, these graveknights have a 2 penalty to their initiative rolls. Once they notice the PCs, they attack at once. They fight until destroyed, but dont pursue anyone who flees up the stairs.

@UUID[Actor.SczNWshNbtqGubKO]{Hidden Niche}: The pillars around the room, if @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.TiNDYUGlMmxzxBYU]{Searched}, have small niches that slide open when pressed. Most of these niches contain only dust, but success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:30|traits:action:search] check reveals that one of them holds a +3 greater striking kukri stashed here long ago by a cultist.
A2. Hall of the Oathkeepers.name: A2. Hall of the Oathkeepers

A9. Scriptorium.text:
Several niches line the walls of this room. A few angled stone slabs near the walls have the appearance of writing desks. Between two doors leading south, the wall is a large slate board bearing several esoteric diagrams in chalk. Another door leads to the northeast.

Foras believed that copying and recopying abstruse texts and astronomical observations was the best way to drill fundamental occult concepts into new cult members, and this scriptorium was used for this purpose. The numerous copies tediously created here would have been immensely valuable to scholars across Avistan, but the cult never promulgated them and instead stored them in the cubbies here before starting their drudgery again. Unfortunately, these works have mostly been reduced to dust except for the final work: the Helix Theorem ritual presented on the slate board. This huge diagram shows certain cosmological conjunctions that trace an immense spiral in the heavens. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[type:occultism|dc:35|traits:action:recall-knowledge] or @Check[type:religion|dc:25|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check not only identifies this spiral as the symbol of Yog-Sothoth, but also notes that it curves in an opposite way from the spiral comet religious symbol of Pharasma. The Helix Theorem, presented in the symbols and notes in Aklo accompanying the diagram, describes closing a symbolic gate nine times along the spiral, from the center of the spiral outward. Although the Helix Theorem is described here, it isnt presented with sufficient detail for the PCs to actually perform the ritual. This is the PCs first clue about how to permanently end the threat posed by Candlemeres lowest level.

@UUID[Actor.4VOuZ8WNZvkyZoGv]{Scriptorium Cubby}: A cubby contains the only other items of value that havent degraded, including a well-preserved scroll of summon entity (8th) on a thin sheet of brass, a stone tablet carved with runes and markings that function as a scroll of weird, and a mysterious looking tome that crumbles away if touchedthis dust functions as a single dose of kings sleep poison.
A9. Scriptorium.name: A9. Scriptorium

B9. Storage Room.name: B9. Storage Room
B9. Storage Room.text: This room contains supplies the cultists either havent gotten around to fixing or only use for special occasions. They include stone chairs, broken alchemical equipment, moldy leather, and dull weapons. A single skeleton is hidden behind some of the furniture here; this cultist irritated the others so badly that, in defiance of Forass orders, they killed him and stashed his body here.

A3. Amphitheater.text:
This large, oblong room resembles an amphitheater. Three enormous ledges, each five feet wide and five feet high, descend in concentric ovals to a stony floor fifteen feet below. Two doors leave this room at the highest levelone at each endand two more doors exit from the floor level.

The cultists sometimes used this room for meetings, or to force creatures to battle to the death on the floor below the ledges. The ledges were once connected by wooden stairs that long ago rotted and fell into dust, so ascending or descending now requires scrambling up and down blocks of stone (@Check[type:athletics|dc:20|traits:action:climb] Athletics check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb}).
A3. Amphitheater.name: A3. Amphitheater

B10. Mortification Room.name: B10. Mortification Room
B10. Mortification Room.text:
Racks around this room contain scourges, wide-bladed knives, and sickles. All are crusted with blood, which pools on the floor beneath them. A door leads west, and a curving hall cuts through this room from east to south.

The cultists engage in ritual mortification of the flesh as they travel through this room in their devotional journey. This isnt a requirement of Yog-Sothoth but a requirement of Foras himself: the sadistic cult leader likes to think of his cultists regularly flaying themselves out of dedication to his twisted leadership alone. To encourage compliance with a step that the cultists all know isnt doctrinally required, Foras placed a magical alarm in this room. Whenever any creature enters this room and hasnt inflicted at least 1 Hit Point of damage on itself with a melee weapon (whether one of the weapons here or a weapon brought into this room) within 1 minute, chimes ring in areas @UUID[.e2mBA5PYWVyrn3Cz]{B11} and @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14}. These chimes also ring if a creature leaves the room without injury before 1 minute has elapsed, preventing anyone from simply hurrying through this room without performing the requisite self-mortification.

If the chimes ring, the cultists in area @UUID[.e2mBA5PYWVyrn3Cz]{B11} realize that someone hasnt performed the appropriate ritual step and they eagerly pile out of the room to capture the shirker. Once they realize the alarm was due to an intruder rather than to someone failing to fulfill the ritual obligation, they attack. Foras hears the chime in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14}, but he has faith that his cultists will catch the wrongdoer on his behalf, so he doesnt respond personally.

Success on a @Check[type:perception|dc:36] check is enough to notice the subtle magical energies infusing this room that comprise the alarm, and any spell that pinpoints magical auras reveals the alarm automatically. Once its revealed, it can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disabled} with a @Check[type:thievery|dc:35] (legendary) check or by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{dispel magic} (9th level, counteract DC 36).

@UUID[Actor.CZz82l5EK3D5CQJj]{Orichalcum Sickle}: The daggers, scourges, and sickles in this room dont have any particular value, with the exception of a high-grade orichalcum sickle engraved with prayers to Yog-Sothoth.

A11. Laboratory.name: A11. Laboratory
A11. Laboratory.text:
The north end of this long room is bisected by a thin wall. On the west side of it, a series of tables bear a dizzying collection of laboratory equipment made of metal and crystal. On the east, a staircase descends steeply to a landing and bends out of sight.

The cultists constructed this laboratory to perform experiments on base chemicals to unlock insights into the building blocks of reality. Their successes in this endeavor were few, and as a result of their propensity for occasional explosive errors, Foras insisted this lab remain far from the principal chambers controlled by the Thresholders.

The stairs descend 100 feet to area @UUID[.XYXHryE1sVjrLhUw]{B1}.

@UUID[Actor.3kyS4KzEmG8Eyl4N]{Thresholder Hermeticists (2)}

Moderate 16

Two Thresholders work here. Having shed their former Hallit identities for the mystic names of Illocor and Kromori, these two hermeticists seek a method by which they can break matter into its fundamental components to study how reality itself is built and might be subverted to serve Yog-Sothoths will. They havent been able to capture living creatures from the surface in so long that theyre desperate for new flesh and attack the PCs immediately in the hopes of capturing them and testing some of their more painful theories. Neither wants to admit defeat in front of the other and they both fight bravely; however, as soon as one of the pair falls, the other flees through area @UUID[.LMK85wyOetfgkrBR]{A10} to join the cultists in the echo laboratory (area @UUID[.JkCGsov5rkWudJ1D]{A12}) and warn them of intruders.

@UUID[Actor.f1FHpv5zqr1EkUBN]{Laboratory Supplies}: Anyone trained or better in Crafting realizes that the materials on the lab tables to the north of the room are all well-used. Despite this general lack of materials, however, the setup functions as expanded alchemists tools and includes a greater salamander elixir and a dose of hemlock poison.

Returning to Candlemere.text:
Its likely that the PCs have already explored the uppermost level below Candlemere. This basements threats are geared toward a 4th-level party (see @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.FCJOgl9jjFQ02ecR]{Candlemere Island} in Chapter 2 for details), but the Spiral Seal of Pharasma in area @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.IxWkClGQf2NWEnQL]{F6} of that level is powerful enough to block access beyond to 4th-level characters. While the encounters in this chapter are aimed at 16th-level PCs, the timing at which the characters return to Candlemere to explore its secrets is left open. The dungeons below Candlemere are in large part optional in the grand scheme of Kingmakers plot, so if the PCs manage to reach 18th level without exploring the dungeons presented here, they can proceed directly to @UUID[JournalEntry.geHtEMsUzqsld8cx]{Chapter 10}.

Yet while the encounters in this chapter are largely apart from the campaigns primary plot, PCs who explore this dungeon and defeat the cult that dwells within will gain a significant advantage once they reach Nyrissas stronghold at the end of the next chapter. Her fortress, the House at the Edge of Time, has a unique relationship with time itself, and if the PCs defeat Foras and master the strange rite that awaits them below Candlemere, their ability to endure the warped temporal effects within the House at the Edge of Time will increase significantly.

Researching the Spiral Seal

The PCs can begin researching the Spiral Seal as soon as they discover it, but initial attempts to do so may well meet with frustrating dead ends as lore about the Seal is difficult to find. Once they recover King Irovettis notes on the Spiral Seal, though, theyll gain a much-needed boost to their research. If the PCs dont discover these notes, and/or they dont seem interested in returning to Candlemere (perhaps even as a result of having forgotten about the mysterious chambers below the tower on the isle), you could reintroduce the topic by having them hear rumors of an increasing number of lights swirling in the air above the ruins (these are more will-o-wisps being drawn to the region as the power of the cults rituals grows deep below ground), or even be asked by a trusted NPC to investigate rumors of strange sounds or magical manifestations witnessed on the island lately.

In any event, the PCs can investigate the Spiral Seal using the Research rules as detailed on pages 154155 of the Pathfinder Gamemastery Guide. If the PCs have access to Irovettis notes, they gain a +4 item bonus on all @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.t5nBkpjroaq7QBGK]{Research} checks made to research the Spiral Seal.

Spiral Seal Research

Library 16

  • Occult

Regional Libraries Investigations pursued at a library in the PCs kingdom, or one in a neighboring city like Restov or Pitax; Maximum RP 5

Research Checks @Check[type:library-lore|dc:33|traits:action:research] or @Check[type:pharasma-lore|dc:33|traits:action:research], @Check[type:occultism|dc:37|traits:action:research], @Check[type:religion|dc:35|traits:action:research]

2 Research Points The PCs find that the Spiral Seal was created several thousand years ago by worshippers of Pharasma, and that it was intended to both physically and dimensionally seal off whatever chambers existed below. Further, the PCs learn that when creating the seal, some of the Pharasmins had to be in those chambers, resulting in them being trapped within.

5 Research Points The PCs determine that it might be possible to break the Spiral Seal open with physical damage, or even to remove it with dispel magic, but that these attempts can cause some sort of magical backlash. Alternately, they can attempt to remove the seal using Occultism or Religion checks, as detailed in Breaking the Spiral Seal below.

Breaking the Spiral Seal

The Spiral Seal itself isnt technically a hazard, since it doesnt trigger like a trap or have any ability to affect the PCs unless they botch an attempt to remove it, but the methods for breaking the Spiral Seal follow those for dealing with a trap closely enough that it is presented below in the hazard format. (Since its not particularly hidden, and since it only reacts under certain circumstances, the Spiral Seal has no Stealth entry.)

Once the Spiral Seal is removed, the ten-foot-diameter section of stone onto which it was inscribed vanishes, revealing a hole in the ground that drops 100 feet down into area @UUID[.eOBzWEaBZoUn6YqW]{A1} below. The walls of this shaft can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climbed} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:30|traits:action:climb] checkthe cultists used magical flight or teleport to make the trip.

@UUID[Actor.E70Drr6CmSaJQ01v]{Spiral Seal}

SIMPLE Hazard 16

A spiral shape suggesting the curling religious symbol of Pharasma is carved into the stone floor.

Reward: Grant the PCs 60 XP for breaking the Spiral Seal.
Returning to Candlemere.name: Returning to Candlemere

B1. Washing Station.name: B1. Washing Station
B1. Washing Station.text:
A long trough of clear water lies along the length of the western wall of this room. A narrow, curved alcove extends a few feet into the north wall before ending at a star-shaped symbol. A hall opposite it curves away to the southeast. Stairs ascend steeply to the east.

This chamber is the first of many shrines the cultists regularly use to venerate Yog-Sothoth. Here, at the beginning of the journey along the spiral, the cultists wash their garments and their bodies in icy cold water that is continually cleaned and chilled by a minor magical effect. Cleanliness isnt particularly important to Yog-Sothothwho has little care about flesh at all, whether dirty or cleanbut the cultists use the cold water scrub to focus their minds on the upcoming portions of the ritual.

The stairs lead up to area @UUID[.mAfM5ivkrUtpWxzO]{A11}.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.EwgTZBWsc8qKaViP]{Investigation}: Success on a @Check[type:religion|dc:35] check is enough to note that the star-shaped symbol on the alcove wall symbolizes the Outer God Azathoth, seething chaos at the center of reality. This symbol serves as the starting point of the ritual spiral that curves throughout this lower level, as the cultists seek to replicate and expand upon this terrifying event.

Part 2: The Depth of Fear.name: Part 2: The Depth of Fear
Part 2: The Depth of Fear.text:
The PCs should be 16th level before they attempt to explore the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth. Note that the encounters in this chapter are particularly dangerous, and the PCs are likely to reach 17th level before completing this part. If youre using milestones for leveling up, consider letting the PCs level up to 17th level the first time they retreat to rest and recover during this chapter rather than waiting for them to defeat Foras at the end.

The deepest levels below Candlemere present a harrowing challenge for a high-level party. While the events that play out in this long-sealed dungeon have very little direct impact on the story of Kingmaker, the potent treasures awaiting discovery within the Spiral will certainly aid the PCs in defending their realm from Nyrissa in the next chapter.

A10. Muttering Cavern.name: A10. Muttering Cavern
A10. Muttering Cavern.text:
This enormous natural cavern is lit by phosphorescent fungus. Several stalagmites, some as high as fifteen feet, sprout from the cavern floor, each mirrored above by a companion stalactite. As a result, the cavern has the unsettling appearance of a half-closed mouth filled with needle-sharp teeth. Twenty feet above the floor, a wide ledge rings the cavern, although much of the ledge along the north side of the cavern has crumbled away. Four doors lead out from this ledge, although only the easternmost and westernmost are still connected by the ledge ringing the cavern to the souththe two other doors open onto rough platforms that no longer connect to the ledge.

The walls of this cavern can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climbed} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:25|traits:action:climb] check. Its a 20-foot drop from the ledge to the cave floor below, and another 30 feet up to the ceiling from the ledge. The doors from areas @UUID[.a6CPQ3ZvcruRxClE]{A8} and @UUID[.qTHenGfk0sDOKexj]{A9} open onto isolated ledges, leaving nowhere to go but down to the cavern floor. The ledge connecting areas @UUID[.mAfM5ivkrUtpWxzO]{A11} and @UUID[.JkCGsov5rkWudJ1D]{A12} is slick but relatively safe, although its well within reach of the creature inhabiting the cavern.

@UUID[Actor.Q3EaaLLx5kDXb5vQ]{Shoggoth}

Moderate 16

The cultists discovered this natural cavern while building their lair, along with its horrific occupanta shoggoth. By sealing the numerous narrow fissures through which the shoggoth entered this chamber from the Darklands below, centuries before even the Thresholders arrived in the area, they trapped the monster within. The cultists once kept it sated with offerings of prisoners when they needed to navigate this room, but when the Spiral Seal descended, the shoggoth went into an eons-long hibernation. Now that the seal is broken, the shoggoth has wakened, hungry and eager. Its cacophonous cries of tekeli-li, tekeli-li! echo through the cave as soon as the PCs enter. It fights until destroyed and pursues PCs relentlessly, its amorphous body allowing it to move through five-foot-wide spaces as difficult terrain. A brave or desperate party can potentially use the shoggoth as a weapon against other creatures in the dungeon, as it does not discriminate between targets that could serve as potential nourishment.

@UUID[Actor.CtTAtUPAZCAAS8wn]{Stalagmite Pedestal}: The cultists sheared off the top of a stalagmite growing near the ledge by the entrance to area A11. They keep a small box containing twisted scraps of cloth on this pedestal; these improvised earplugs provide a +1 item bonus to saves against auditory effects, such as the shoggoths Maddening Cacophony. Beneath the well-used earplugs is a vial containing a greater bravos brew.

B7. Overgrown Shed.text:
This small stone shed was already part of this cavern when the cultists constructed the Candlemere dungeons millennia ago. Even then, it was already impossibly old, its stone riddled with the vegetation that grew up around it and its stone corners crumbled and rounded with age. The stone door leading into the shed sits slightly off its rusted pivot pin and requires a @Check[type:athletics|dc:36|traits:action:force-open] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SjmKHgI7a5Z9JzBx]{Force Open}.

@UUID[Actor.uQbzVX7DWDbxLONd]{Paranoia Well}

Simple Hazard 19

The interior of the shed is dark and featureless. It is also totally devoid of any plant life that grows with such profusion outside of ita side effect of the fact that the sheds interior is infused with destructive emotional energy, for this location in the spiral has become a sort of supernatural sump for the excess of awfulness shed over the past thousands of years by the trapped, ageless cultists.

@UUID[Actor.eOC3K7034tHb9Zxt]{Discarded Rags}: Even a cursory examination of the sheds interior reveals a small pile of rags and scraps, as if a destitute person left their tattered clothes in the corner before vanishing. Among these mysterious rags is a dread blindfold.
B7. Overgrown Shed.name: B7. Overgrown Shed

The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth.name: The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth
The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth.text:
Candlemeres lowest dungeon consists of several rooms built around an enormous spiral engineered by Foras to catch and focus Yog-Sothoths gaze, and it is where the Thresholders focus their most important efforts to draw Yog-Sothoth into the Material Plane. In the center of the spiral is a ritual chamber where the cult leader, Foras, works tirelessly at his rituals.

But Foras and his cultists arent alone in their endeavor. In the months before the clash with the Pharasmins, Foras reached out to the windswept plateau of Leng, for allies. A group of powerful denizens of Leng answered by sending a delegation of inhuman envoys to aid them, only to become trapped in the dungeon when the Spiral Seal cut off dimensional travel. In that time, the denizens have managed to breach the Spiral Seal only a few times to conjure potent agents from the depths of time itself, but even these powerful hounds of Tindalos found themselves unable to exit the dungeon as long as the Spiral Seal remained.

Fortunately for the cultists, the denizens of Leng are inhumanly patient, and they have been content to merely wait out the Spiral Seal. Theyve taken over the eastern rooms in the lower dungeon, and the cultists are happy to let them have those rooms while they continue to pursue their own goals.

The Helix Theorem

Although the PCs can prevent the Thresholders from finishing their patient endeavor in engineering Yog-Sothoths arrival on Golarion by simply killing them all and destroying their work, the very structure of the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth will continue to draw the Outer Gods gaze as long as it remains. Merely knocking over a few walls or blocking a few passages cant undo the mystical effect the Spiral has imbued the region with; it has existed for so long that its shape is burned into the fabric of reality and the risk of catching Yog-Sothoths attention will remain until someone takes specific action to reverse this condition. A PC who has explored the Spiral and succeeds at a @Check[type:occultism|dc:35] or @Check[type:yog-sothoth-lore|dc:33] check realizes the metaphysical danger the lower dungeon poses.

To render the Spiral of Yog-Sothoth entirely harmless, the PCs must discover and perform a mystic rite called the Helix Theorem. The PCs can first learn about this ritual by examining the slate board in area @UUID[.qTHenGfk0sDOKexj]{A9}, with further information awaiting discovery in area @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9]{B13}. In brief, the ritual requires closing a miniature gate icon nine times: once each in areas @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14}, @UUID[.HXLgL6p5oCes0uP9]{B13}, @UUID[.Lax7DSMrgnvjmcyh]{B12}, @UUID[.0kSqo5oKQtD59pcX]{B10}, @UUID[.Zh2VM1v7YxAL43Qu]{B8}, @UUID[.RVeE7HUPof17hEZy]{B4}, @UUID[.nsM73V8Ra1IvLs24]{B3}, @UUID[.Y0yPoSJNmiTvJA53]{B2}, and @UUID[.XYXHryE1sVjrLhUw]{B1}, in that order. Each time the gate is closed as part of the correct sequence, the icon itself glows with a soothing pale blue light until it is opened again (likely to perform the next closing). If the gate is closed out of sequence, the pale blue light flashes brightly before extinguishing, and the process must be started from the beginning.

The tiny gate must be a specially prepared icon representing the cosmic seal that serves as a boundary between Yog-Sothoth and the Material Plane. The miniature gate in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14} works well for this purpose, although the PCs can prepare their own icon with success on a @Check[type:crafting|dc:38] check. Each time the gate is shut in one of these rooms, the PC performing the ritual must succeed at a @Check[type:occultism|dc:36] check. Other PCs can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} this check as usual by intoning chants or simply helping to carry the gate. If any of these Occultism checks is failed, the PCs must start again in area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14}. At the conclusion of the ritual, the miniature gate must be placedstill closedin the alcove in area @UUID[.XYXHryE1sVjrLhUw]{B1} at the very end of the spiral. When the Helix Theorem is successfully performed, the rooms in the lower dungeon twist and flex, shifting through the earth until they all exist along a straight line, rather than a curving spiral. This movement is unnerving but harmless to those in the rooms. The rooms thereafter cant capture Yog-Sothoths attention or open the way for Yog-Sothoth to enter the Material Plane.

While this certainly prevents a potential disaster from destroying the PCs kingdom, performing the Helix Theorem here has an unanticipated side effect that the PCs wont realize until some time laterby performing this rite, they inadvertently bolster their own presence in the flow of time. Any PC who was present below Candlemere when the Helix Theorem is performed gain additional protections once they reach Nyrissas @UUID[JournalEntry.GciDhpLFRov9s5Fm.JournalEntryPage.R1rWIW926cn6NfhY]{House at the Edge of Time}.

If the PCs dont realize the danger posed by the Spiral or fail to perform the Helix Theorem, the long-term effects are up to the GM. Eventually, the Spiral draws other prospective cultists into the chambers; these cultists arrive singly or in small groups but quickly join together to continue the work the Thresholders began. These new cultists might be more powerful or more numerous than those the PCs previously destroyed. The spiral may even draw Yog-Sothoths dire gaze, causing spheres of eldritch power to erupt in the region and then begin to pull this part of the Material Plane out of phase with the rest of reality, exacerbating the dangers of the blooms that afflict the PCs kingdom at the start of Sound of a Thousand Screams.

Reward: If the PCs successfully complete the Helix Theorem ritual, award them 120 XP.

The Contested Level.name: The Contested Level
The Contested Level.text:
Korogs Heresies

Its worth keeping in mind that the choice the ancient Pharasmins made to become eternal undead servants was prompted not by religious fervor but by a mix of ego, shame, and self-righteousness. Korog knew that the Spiral Seal would keep the cultists entombed, but rather than have faith in that magic or in the worshippers of Pharasma who remained on guard in the outer world, he ordered his followers to turn their backs on their beliefs to embrace undeath. As the PCs discover the undead Pharasmins and learn more about the nature of their decision, allow them to attempt a DC 30 Religion or DC 25 Pharasma Lore check to understand that Korogs choice to become undead was blasphemous. A PC who uses this information against the undead Pharasmins gains a +2 circumstance bonus on Intimidation checks to Demoralize the undead and to the DCs of any emotion-based effects used against the undead, at the GMs discretion.

The chambers of Candlemeres upper dungeon are the site of a centuries-long stalemate between the Thresholders and the Pharasmins who wish to keep the cultists imprisoned. There were once three passages connecting the areas controlled by the Pharasmins (areas @UUID[.eOBzWEaBZoUn6YqW]{A1}@UUID[.a6CPQ3ZvcruRxClE]{A8}) and the cultists (areas @UUID[.qTHenGfk0sDOKexj]{A9}@UUID[.YDka3Bsn8Byl9TIL]{A17}), but one of these passages has collapsed, one is defended by a banshee loyal to neither side, and the other bears a trap the Pharasmins put in place long ago.

Dungeon Features

While the Spiral Seal is in place, the entirety of the Candlemere dungeon is shrouded in a powerful magical aura that prevents almost all travel in and out of the dungeon by any means, especially via teleportation effects, but also including any attempt to tunnel physically out of the complex (the one exception involves entry via dreams, but even then only one way; see @UUID[.1Rmw90xtZtr9juLf]{Part 2} for more information). Once the Spiral Seal is removed, these limitations vanish, but, apart from the stone disappearing and thus granting the PCs access to the chambers below, there are no physical or spiritual cues that anything has changed. Unless the occupants witness the PCs using previously impossible actions, itll likely be months or even years before they discover that the Seal has been lifted, as centuries of waiting have lulled them into lassitude. Once they do notice, they may (at the GMs discretion) begin tentative explorations into the world beyond.

Both levels of the Candlemere dungeon are carved from natural stone. Smaller stones the size of bricks are cunningly fit together to smooth out the walls and floors, while the ceilings are bare stone; only a few indicated areas are natural caverns. The paper-thin gaps between these smaller stones emit a pale glow that suffuses the dungeon with light from the walls and floor. This light has no apparent source; if the bricks are pulled out to expose the natural stone, the glow ceases. Natural caverns are dark. Unless indicated otherwise, halls throughout the dungeon are 10 feet high, while chambers are 20 feet high. The doors are all made of heavy stone that grind closed when not held open, but none bear locks or bars.

If the PCs havent disabled the Dread Aura that infuses Candlemere (see @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.XbG1SuNFeOJbNo96]{E3. Tower} in Chapter 2 for details), those effects continue to persist down into these dungeons.

A16. Upper Bunk Room.text:
Ten stone slabs each large enough to hold a reclining human line the walls of this room, stacked in pairs like bunk beds. A tattered leather mat lies upon each.

The cultists sleep in this room from time to time, although most hermeticists and mystics are too involved in their current projects to come back here to sleep.

@UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Thresholder Disciples (4)}

Moderate 16

A total of four Thresholder Disciples are in this room at any time, taking their turn to doze or simply meditate. These disciples switch out for those in other areas of the dungeon from time to time, although they have long ago lost any sense of a normal day-night cycle and rest for any period between a few hours and a few weeks. If alerted to danger, these disciples are quick to spring into action. They pursue foes throughout the dungeon, offer no quarter, and fight until slain.
A16. Upper Bunk Room.name: A16. Upper Bunk Room

A4. Speakers Chamber.text:
This room has a few benches and a stone table along the north wall. An alcove to the south has a few rusted iron rings hanging from the ceiling. The rings bear tatters and scraps of a curtain that once concealed the alcove.

In important lectures or debates, the principal speaker used this room to prepare. The short hall to the amphitheater (area @UUID[.O4UraK4jlexn6aWR]{A3}) allowed such speakers to compose themselves before making an appropriately dramatic entrance. There are a few metal writing tools on the stone desk, but no evidence of what would have been written here other than the words He Knows the Gate scratched on the desk in Aklo.

The once-curtained-off alcove was used for resting or meditation, but the current occupants havent needed the privacy and tore down most of the curtain. The alcove contains a stack of metal folios carved with various disconnected pieces of occult lore written in a combination of Aklo and Necril. The books at the top walk through the steps required to transform a human warrior into a graveknight; it was these books that gave Korog the idea to use undeath to extend the Pharasmins role as guardians indefinitely. In a fit of shame, Korog destroyed portions of these texts; while a @Check[type:religion|dc:30|traits:action:recall-knowledge] check is enough to piece their original purpose together, the method itself cannot be learned from these fragments.

  • @UUID[Actor.vrZrha0Gz14Zd4tA]{Korog}
  • @UUID[Actor.P1kWLRlEPTcZ3uzD]{Graveknights (2)}

Encounter

Moderate 16

Korog, the chief graveknight and younger brother of the Thresholders leader, spends much of his time here. Once a powerfully built Kellid chieftain, he retains his imposing build even as a skeleton as a result of his armor. This full plate armora true rarity among the Kellids back in Korogs dayis black iron marked with rusted, bloody symbols of Pharasma. While the armor looks ancient and in poor condition, the supernatural effects of his presence as a graveknight keeps the armor functioning perfectly. Korog always preferred fighting to talking, which made him an impetuous chief, and he never got over the shock and shame of learning that his brother was the leader of the vile kidnappers and cultists hiding in Candlemere.

Korog sometimes checks in on the guards in area @UUID[.WjdBYJuLwqVXxUnS]{A2}, but these patrols rarely take him long. He has two loyal guards with him at all times in the event the Thresholders try to breach the defenses. If they spot intruders, the graveknights draw their weapons and attack.
