Korog insists (in Hallit) that the trespassers depart if they value their lives, warning that their bumbling intrusion might unleash ageless evils and powerful cultists into the world again. These graveknights all fight until destroyed. If Korogs armor restores him, he does his best to ascertain the status of the Thresholders and return to his principal task of keeping them contained. Korog lacks the magic to restore the Spiral Seal, but he might work to physically block the passages out by collapsing the stone construction. These efforts will likely take him several weeks, but if the PCs depart Candlemere and return after a long period of time, they might have to bypass one of Korogs makeshift barriers.

@UUID[Actor.kC1Jxltg5nJP2BGf]{Enchanted Curtain}: One larger fragment of the curtain is imbued with a minor preservative magic running through a silver thread sewn into the curtain. In the center of the fragment, the silver thread creates script that functions as a scroll of heroism (9th)although the magic has been tainted. When this spell is cast, it functions normally, but once its duration ends, it leaves the target feeling like the magic has attracted somethings attention. The feeling of paranoia resulting from this weird sensation leaves the creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{stupefied 1}.
A4. Speakers Chamber.name: A4. Speakers Chamber

A8. Trapped Hall.text:
This long, L-shaped hall is lined with carvings that depict large globes as delicate as soap bubbles at varying heights, as though floating down the hall on a nonexistent breeze.

These images are not nearly as fanciful as they appear. They depict Yog-Sothoth in one of the forms it assumes in the mortal world: a collection of incandescent spheres. The cultists instilled an enchantment here to cause some of the orbs to glimmer with malevolent magical light whenever anyone walked down the hall, but the Pharasmins recognized this latent magical energy and reworked it into a deadly trap designed to catch unsuspecting cultists. The cultists havent been back this way, so the trap still remains.

@UUID[Actor.ce5vC049lfuXnPSy]{Orb Blast Trap}

COMPLEX Hazard 18

Anyone walking past the midpoint of this hallway sees five of the orbs shimmer with color, quickly flickering through a wide range of unsettling and strangely nauseating hues. As soon as a second creature passes this midpoint, blasts of force launch from the orbs.

@UUID[Macro.hUQJmq6RoKv8zxgG]{A8. Activate Orb Blast Trap}

This macro will toggle the lights between their multicolor and single color versions.
A8. Trapped Hall.name: A8. Trapped Hall

Part 1: Threshold of Dread.text:
The PCs should be 16th level before they attempt to explore the contested level below Candlemere.

Kingdom in the Background

The PCs adventures under Candlemere are focused entirely within two self-contained dungeon levels, so there is nothing new to track with their kingdom as this chapters encounters play out.

As detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.FCJOgl9jjFQ02ecR]{Part 7} of Chapter 2, a misanthropic cultist named @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.qw1zIddVk8oKZps7]{Foras} built a complex for his cult of Yog-Sothoth worshippers, the Thresholders, under the island of Candlemere (Area @UUID[JournalEntry.5QajqjVS7Dm8u7hi.JournalEntryPage.fraqnPjBmnq2ToHs]{KL4}). When the cult was confronted by worshippers of Pharasma eons ago, a desperate fight took place. With the aid of their own great hero Korog, Forass younger brother, the Pharasmins achieved initial success quickly in their attempt to defeat the Thresholders. Foras hadnt shared his powers with everyone in the cult of Yog-Sothoth, so the unenlightened acolytes at the Thresholders lowest ranks couldnt stand against the zealous onslaught of the furious Pharasmins. Soon, the entire tower of Candlemere was taken, and the Pharasmins used it as a base of operations while they turned their attentions to the chambers below.

In the basement, the Pharasmins advance was thwarted, for they hadnt realized how powerful Forass inner circle of mystics and disciples were. After several failed attempts to progress into the chambers deep below Candlemeres basement, Korog made the difficult choice to seal the cultists within rather than risk defeat at his older brothers hands. The Pharasmins made a desperate push with their bravest fightersincluding Korogalong with several allied psychopomps. As the Pharasmins penetrated the upper dungeon level, those behind them sealed the entrance to the dungeons shut with a magical ward on a stone plug. The Thresholders werent defeated, but they could menace the surface no longer.

But the Thresholders had ensured their immortality, and they could afford to simply wait out the Pharasmins that had established a beachhead in the upper dungeon. The Pharasmins trapped within the dungeon made a difficult (and, in their beliefs, blasphemous) choice to ensure their continued ability to hold the cultists at bay. Using forbidden lore gleaned from collections of tomes theyd seized in their final push, Korog convinced his fellow Pharasmins to undertake a ritual to end their lives and rise as eternal graveknights so they could stand between the Thresholders and the surface forever.

Korog knew he had to keep this secret from the psychopomps who had accompanied the Pharasminsthe grim and resolute monitors would consider embracing undeath to be treachery of the highest order. Korog therefore tricked the psychopomps into entering a stasis which has, by now, stretched into millennia.

The divisions between the dungeon chambers held by Korog and the Pharasmins and those held by the Thresholders are now well defined, and both are laden with traps and guardians. While this standoff has remained for thousands of years, the cultists have not been idle; they have continued their pursuit of esoteric rituals and are preparing to open a metaphysical portal to pull Yog-Sothoth into the Material Plane. This ritual isnt close to completion, and as such the PCs have plenty of time to learn how to enter the dungeon and dispatch its ageless denizensbut if Foras and his cultists arent stopped, Yog-Sothoths arrival will not only free the cult back into the world, but will bring horror to the entire River Kingdoms as well.
Part 1: Threshold of Dread.name: Part 1: Threshold of Dread

B13. Acolyte Alcoves.name: B13. Acolyte Alcoves
B13. Acolyte Alcoves.text:
This room is brightly lit, and its light is evident from down the curved hall leading to it.

Two large, rounded alcoves stand next to each other at the south end of this room. Both blaze with light emanating from several unnerving pinpoints that shift and move around. Just visible in the glare from the alcoves is a door leading east. The curving hall cuts through the northwest corner of this chamber.

This chamber provides a vision of the stars closest to Yog-Sothoths gate. By carefully interpreting the psychic emanations from the Outer God, the cultists believe that they have managed to reconstruct the stellar location of the cosmic gate barring it from the Material Plane. Here, the cultists must meditate upon the lights to find esoteric patterns that might aid in opening the gate further. Staring directly into the light is painful after a long period of time for those who still have eyes, but the cultists feel no such pain now that theyve moved on to the benefits of unseen sight.

@UUID[Actor.htHgsx1COWOfhE3D]{Thresholder Mystics} (2)

Severe 16

Two mystics named Tolas and Noliskur are currently here. They each have a lightweight brass tablet and a stylus to record observations they make as they work backward through the Helix Theorem, calculating how to reverse the theorem to strengthen, rather than weaken, Yog-Sothoths gaze into Candlemere.

If the mystics have reason to expect anyone intruding on their mediations, they prepare to chastise whomever arrives. If they identify the PCs as intruders from the surface, the mystics do their best to dispatch them as quickly as possible.

Treasure: The brass tablets the mystics carry provide a great deal of specific detail about the Helix Theorem. Although its clear from their notes that the cultists were trying to discover a way to reverse the theorem, its useful for the PCs to see the detailed ritual notes about unshackling Yog-Sothoths attention from Candlemere. By reviewing the mystics tablets, the PCs can learn all the necessary steps for performing the Helix Theorem ritual (see @UUID[.ZPtDIkEsiwPp3Gem]{The Spiral of Yog-Sothoth}).

A13. Star Sphere.text:
An archway in the northeast corner of this room opens into a fifteen-foot-diameter spherical hollow. The interior of the sphere glows with tiny points of light that almost look like a representation of a stellar map or constellation chart. Doors lead out to the east, west, and south.

The sphere is a celestial globe showing the position of the stars in relation to the surface of Golarion as pinpricks of magical light. As the Thresholders didnt want to rely on astronomical observations made from the Candlemere tower, they installed this globe as a reference point. When they were cut off from the surface, the Thresholders initially relied extensively on this globe, but after long centuries theyve all memorized this information and dont need to check on it much any longer. This room is therefore frequently empty except when cultists are traveling between areas.

The door to the west opens upon a shallow alcove, the far wall of which bears a large, purple glyph that resembles several interlocking bubbles. This glyph can be used to trigger a one-way passage into area @UUID[.x1akHRTqD7eClobm]{A5}. When the proper combination of bubbles on the runes are pressed (which requires success on a @Check[type:occultism|dc:35] or @Check[type:arcana|dc:37] check to determine), the stone of the wall shifts to the consistency of thick mud for 1 minute, allowing a creature to push through the wall into area @UUID[.x1akHRTqD7eClobm]{A5} as if moving through difficult terrain. Creatures cannot pass through it in the opposite direction.

The cultists assume that the Pharasmins are in control of the Void Pit in area A5, but if they learn otherwise, they might use this route to expand their influence into the northern parts of the dungeon.

@UUID[Actor.8gAoSgBJN8QqzP1R]{Frozen Moment Trap}

SIMPLE Hazard 17

Anyone who touches the glyph in any way other than by using the proper combination triggers a trap that encases the target in a timeless eternity.
A13. Star Sphere.name: A13. Star Sphere

A6. Hall of the Relinquished.text:
This angled room has several wall carvings depicting a variety of people in unpleasant situations: folks being crushed under stones, prisoners locked behind spiked iron grates, kneeling people weeping beside dead trees, and so on. The carvings arent uniform and appear to have been made over many years by many different hands.

The cultists made the carvings here, each designed to depict something they left behind in their old lives to dedicate themselves wholly to Yog-Sothoth. Each cultist was required to add something to this room upon becoming one of the Thresholders. As most cultists wereand remainmean-spirited people, the carvings here are an inventory of petty jealousies, perceived wrongs, and persecution complexes.

A cunning and powerful elven mercenary named Kyetriel joined the Pharasmins in their push to stop the Thresholders. Kyetriel met her end here when the cultists sprung a magical trap to damage her soul and poison her flesh. Kyetriel died, but the trap and her feelings of betrayal and agony anchored her soul here. Kyetriel rose as a powerful banshee, and she torments anyone who enters this room. The cultists know to stay out of the room for fear of Kyetriels dread keening, and the Pharasmins consider Kyetriel to be a useful deterrent to prevent the cultists from coming this way.

@UUID[Actor.cNfBKVn2d1T3VKUu]{Kyetriel}

Moderate 16

Kyetriel attacks any living creatures that enter this room, opening with her Wail and then relying on her melee Strikes. Although shes normally bound to this room and cant leave it, if she affects an opponent with her Terrifying Touch, she can enter any room that character enters so long as it remains frightened. This means Kyetriel can follow PCs she injures, perhaps all the way to the surface to escape Candlemere at last.

@UUID[Actor.O5qJyB5L6AdvP7WN]{Kyetriel's Remains}: Kyetriels corpse remains in this room, desiccated and still wearing the equipment she used in life, including a suit of +1 resilient elven chain, a +2 keen striking elven curve blade, and a greater cloak of elvenkind.
A6. Hall of the Relinquished.name: A6. Hall of the Relinquished

Concluding the Chapter.name: Concluding the Chapter
Concluding the Chapter.text:
After the PCs have defeated Foras and the cultists, their plan to open the gate to attract Yog-Sothoth no longer threatens the region. Any Leng envoys who still live decide to retreat to Leng for the time being, although theyre certain to spend their time in that distant plane advancing plots that spell ill for Golarion. If the PCs retain any of their strange rubies, they might become the focus of these plots.

The chambers below Candlemere remain, and the passage of time swiftly expunges any lingering influence the cult may have once had in the region. Any of the undead Pharasmins who were bound to the upper halls of the dungeon finally collapse to dust, their souls moving on for judgment. If in your campaign, one of the PCs or a significant NPC is a worshipper of Pharasma, you could use this development as an opportunity for the party to perform an absolution for these ancient worshipers of Pharasmaa @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Dbd5W6G8U2vzWolN]{consecrate} ritual or the like will certainly suffice for this. To the Lady of Graves herself, the passage of time is largely irrelevant, and while these doomed Pharasmins abandoned their lives, souls, and faith in order to stand against the cult, the amount of time their souls remained in stasis in their undead shells did not concern herjudgment comes to all in time. But this doesnt mean she wont appreciate the PCs actions in defeating Foras and his cult.

As such, even if the PCs dont perform absolution rites for the graveknights, the Lady of Graves makes sure to reward the PCs for their acts. She grants a moderate boon to every character as soon as the cult is defeated, granting them greater mastery over the energies of life and death. To the characters, this boon manifests as a potent dream the next time they sleep, wherein they see themselves standing before Pharasmas throne not as souls but as living creatures. With a mercurial smile, Pharasma traces the spiral of her symbol on the PCs brow with her fingertip, and when that character wakes they gain the full benefits of her divine intercession.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.boons-and-curses.Item.xrSgGobm5QtTcABQ]{Pharasma's Moderate Boon} causes a characters Strikes to deal 1 positive damage to undead. Any of the characters spells that deal positive damage to undead gain a +1 status bonus to damage per spell level, and spells that heal the living gain a +1 status bonus to the Hit Points restored per level. In addition, these PCs will find that as they age, they remain fit and hale and healthyold age will hold no decline for them. These particular benefits are unlikely to be realized in most Kingmaker campaigns, of course, but mentioning this to the PCs when they finish the Adventure Path can be an additional emotional reward for a job well done. Of course, when the heroes time comes, they still pass on to the River of SoulsPharasmas boon does not offer immortality, only a slight reprieve of the aches and pains along the way.

On the other hand, if the PCs didnt complete the Helix Theorem, they might face further dangers from the ominous spiral beneath the Stolen Lands, and in time, another cult may arrive to take advantage of the sites eldritch nature. The eyes of Yog-Sothoth are many, and cultists of the Lurker at the Threshold continually strive to open the gate for their dread god. If the PCs arent quite high enough level to withstand the dangers that theyll face as Kingmakers endgame begins in the next chapter, consider having them face additional perils as Yog-Sothoths influence spreads throughout their kingdom, be it in the form of additional dangerous Kingdom events or in the shape of new adventures of your own design.

B5. The Howling Room.name: B5. The Howling Room
B5. The Howling Room.text:
The noise of howling wind is obvious to any hearing creature from the stairs leading down into this chamber.

A few stone biers are the only furnishings in this room. An alcove to the southeast emits a constant howl of wind that blows around the room. The wind isnt particularly strong, but gouges on the walls indicate that it must have been blowing ceaselessly for many years. A staircase ascending from the south wall is the rooms only exit.

The alcove emits a constant howling wind that is magically contained to this room. The wind originates from hundreds of tiny holes at the rear of the alcove, but its source is a distant nameless world where ceaseless storms howl. The cultists sometimes meditated in this room, listening for insights into creation from the ceaseless wind.

The wind imposes a 2 circumstance penalty on auditory Perception checks and on attack rolls for ranged physical attacks, such as arrows. Unprotected flames in the room are instantly blown out. The room is difficult terrain for creatures that are Flying.

  • @UUID[Actor.bwEYizrdHs8lmvxE]{Leng Envoy}
  • @UUID[Actor.sw32QdZlsWnmWaVY]{Mastiff of Tindalos}

Encounter

Severe 16

As the Leng envoys found this room reminded them of their windswept home, Foras graciously allowed them to use it as their private chamber. One envoy is currently here while the other is being interviewed by cultists in area @UUID[.Zh2VM1v7YxAL43Qu]{B8}.

That single Leng envoy and a mastiff of Tindalos are enjoying the blowing wind. They realize that anyone they dont recognize must be an enemy of the cult, and they hope to curry favor with Foras by eliminating them quickly. The Leng envoy fights to the death, but the mastiff of Tindalos, recognizing that the Spiral Seal is no more since the PCs obviously made it inside, flees via Angled Entry if reduced to fewer than 30 HP.

A15. Hall of Aberrant Reflections.name: A15. Hall of Aberrant Reflections
A15. Hall of Aberrant Reflections.text:
Steel mirrors line the east wall of this long hall, extending from floor to ceiling. A corridor leads north, and two doors exit to the west. Two stone benches stand in the room, positioned so that anyone sitting upon them can face their reflections. Neither the benches nor the doors are reflected in the mirrors opposite them.

Each of the mirrors here are magically warped, like subtle fun house mirrors. Instead of reflected creatures seeming distended or compressed, however, they appear slightly alien: wider eyes with fang-filled mouths, elongated heads that pulse with dark veins, or hateful sneers below dead-white eyes. To keep anyone meditating on these magical images from being distracted, the mirrors are enchanted so the doors across from them dont appear in the reflectionsthey just appear to be blank walls instead. The same is true for any unattended objects in the room, like the benches; they arent reflected in the mirrors at all. These minor magical properties can be discovered with a DC 30 check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.eReSHVEPCsdkSL4G]{Identify Magic}.

Any significant noise in this room brings the disciples resting in area @UUID[.iGCiO2WLCCxc103m]{A16} to investigate.

A17. Visitor Lounge.text:
This large room has a vaulted ceiling that rises thirty feet high. The arched ceiling resembles a wide-open sky, complete with ominous gray storm clouds and subdued sunlight that shines fitfully down to the floor below in softly shifting beams. Several low stone benches with curved backs provide comfortable and intimate seating. A narrow staircase leads down to the south.

On the rare occasions when the cultists hosted visitors, they wanted to ensure their guests comfort so that they could more easily sway or deceive them. This rooms ceiling had an illusion placed to accurately reflect the sky above Candlemere, but it long ago froze in the current view of a pending rainstorm. Anyone watching the ceiling sees it shudder and loop after a few minutes to repeat the same movements over and over.

The door to the west leads to a short hall with a glyph much like that in area @UUID[.4OF1uIWyLXO4VSKk]{A13}. This controls a one-way door leading to area @UUID[.JkCGsov5rkWudJ1D]{A12}, but unlike the door in area A13, the cultists still use it quite often.

The stairs here descend 100 feet to area @UUID[.nsM73V8Ra1IvLs24]{B3}.

@UUID[Actor.8gAoSgBJN8QqzP1R]{Frozen Moment Trap}

SIMPLE Hazard 17

As with the trap in area @UUID[.4OF1uIWyLXO4VSKk]{A13}, misusing the glyph controlling the one-way door triggers a trap to freeze the target in time. However, since this trap has been used so often over the millennia, its slightly easier to identify the correct orbs to push. The traps Stealth DC is therefore a slightly lower DC 38.
A17. Visitor Lounge.name: A17. Visitor Lounge

B6. Garden.text:
This enormous natural cavern is nearly a hundred feet long and sixty feet wide. It is overgrown with a profusion of fungi and strange ferns that grow to an immense size despite the lack of natural light. The floor of the chamber is unpleasantly spongy and gives off a putrid smell. A small stone shed stands at the south end of the cavern, nearly overgrown with vegetation.

The cultists discovered this enormous cavern while constructing the lower dungeon and use it to grow fungi, herbs, and insects the hermeticists use in their experiments. Otherwise, the cultists leave the area alonethey dont need to eat and therefore dont require sustenance themselves.

@UUID[Actor.sw32QdZlsWnmWaVY]{Mastiffs of Tindalos (4)}

Severe 16

The Leng envoys asked for this room for their mastiffs, and Foras was glad to provide it to the otherworldly visitors. The mastiffs eagerly attack any intruders, fighting to the death.
B6. Garden.name: B6. Garden

A12. Echo Laboratory.text:
This large, square room has hemispherical alcoves in the north and south walls. The stone around these, as well as the ground between them, is scored with tiny grooves and ripples.

The alcoves in this room are very carefully engineered to reflect sound and bounce it between them repeatedly. Sonic damage created in this room inflicts an additional 1 sonic damage per die rolled as the amplifications empower it.

  • @UUID[Actor.htHgsx1COWOfhE3D]{Thresholder Mystic}
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Thresholder Disciple}

Encounter

Moderate 16

A pair of Thresholdersa contemplative mystic named Balarom and a thickset disciple named Berinthuswork in this room not to amplify noise, but to dampen it. These cultists are attempting to mimic the soundless void of deep space, in the hopes that utter silence can help draw Yog-Sothoths attention. When the PCs arrive, the mystic has already cast a 4th-level @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.gIdDLrbswTV3OBJy]{silence} spell onto the disciple to aid their experimentation, and the disciple uses this to her advantage to rush at any spellcasters. Both of these cultists fight to the death.

Effect

@UUID[Item.NgQlipyK82LwoV16]{Silence}

A 10ft aura has been applied to the Disciple in this room in order to track the area of the Silence spell.

@UUID[Actor.PLmzQ8rhTc4WxiFz]{Echo Laboratory Chime}: One of the chimes on the rack is a critical component of the experiments here; it is a hollow metal wand of widening sound burst (7th level).
A12. Echo Laboratory.name: A12. Echo Laboratory

B8. Lecture Room.name: B8. Lecture Room
B8. Lecture Room.text:
This L-shaped room has the curved hallway arcing through its center. A raised platform stands at each end of the room, and a few heavy stone stools are clustered around the platform to the east. A door stands in the west wall.

This is the primary meeting place for the Thresholders, and its where Foras gathers them together to make pronouncements, issue changes in the devotion rituals, or publicly punish wrongdoers.

  • @UUID[Actor.bwEYizrdHs8lmvxE]{Leng Envoy}
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Disciples (2)}

Encounter

Severe 16

The current occupants are a Leng envoy and two disciples named Brulen and Ferandir. The disciples have been tasked with finding out more from the Leng envoy about how to open wide the cosmic gate to let Yog-Sothoth through. The disciples worry that because the envoy is just so much smarter and more devout than they are, their relative ignorance will lead to punishment. Brulen and Ferandir each keep trying to show that they understand more of what the envoy is saying than the other, when in fact neither has any idea. They find the whole interview particularly frustrating, and the envoy, who enjoys tormenting the disciples with their ignorance, has no intention of letting the interview end anytime soon.

If this group becomes aware of intruders, the envoy simply sits back and opines in Aklo, Now you can show me what you know. Happy to be doing something theyre good at, the disciples rush into combat. The envoy hangs back, supporting the disciples with its spells if it seems like it wont put itself in any danger by doing so.

The envoy ceases hostilities if the disciples are defeated, offering to answer any questions the PCs have. Instead of providing detailed answers, however, it provides only basic facts that it assumes the PCs already know, such as the tenets of the cult and the powers that different types of cultists can bring to bear. The envoy freely admits that aiding the cultists in bringing Yog-Sothoth through the mystical gate to rend this world suits its own purposes, although the envoys themselves arent particularly devoted to Yog-Sothoth. The envoy might let slip some information that fills in gaps in the PCs knowledge, such as that Foras is the leader of the cult, that he works at the center of the spiral, or even that a rite called the Helix Theorem can turn Yog-Sothoths attention away from Candlemere. During the course of the interrogation, the envoy gives up its strangely flawless Leng rubies, surrendering them as spoils of war or even hinting that they hold magical power. If the envoy can convince the PCs to demand the rubies instead of merely accepting them, all the better. The envoy then tries to use @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9BnhadUO8FMLmeZ3]{mind probe} on a PC with one of the rubies and learn more about them. Ultimately, the envoy plans to betray the PCs, but if it can do so when theyve let their guard down, that works just as well. Once it springs this trap, the envoy fights until destroyed.

A1. The Landings.name: A1. The Landings
A1. The Landings.text: Removing the Spiral Seal in area @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.IxWkClGQf2NWEnQL]{F6} of @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.FCJOgl9jjFQ02ecR]{Chapter 2} reveals a circular shaft descending 100 feet to a stone landing in the shape of a crescent moon. Stairs from this landing lead down to another just like it, and stairs from that landing lead to area @UUID[.WjdBYJuLwqVXxUnS]{A2}. The air in this area blows steadily upward and brings the scent of dust and rot, like some massive creature exhaling its fetid breath.

A14. The Bending Way.name: A14. The Bending Way
A14. The Bending Way.text:
This hall makes several tight turns, obscuring most of it from view behind walls decorated with spiral symbols. The north end of the hall contains a few tables loaded with loose stone and a variety of bowls, jars, and measuring scales.

This long room was once used for meditation, to show cultists that a twisting way to truth is sometimes the only way to find it. When the Pharasmins attacked and destroyed the shortest passage to the entry hall (area @UUID[.WjdBYJuLwqVXxUnS]{A2}), the Thresholders were more easily confined to the southern half of the dungeon. The cultists realize there is a potential tactical advantage to gain from reopening this passage, but they also understand that keeping the rubble as-is affords perhaps an even greater protection from their enemies. As such, progress toward restoring the passageway has never gone much farther than argument-laced discussions.

  • @UUID[Actor.3kyS4KzEmG8Eyl4N]{Hermeticist}
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Disciples (2)}

Encounter

Moderate 16

The hermeticist and disciples working here are quick to attack any intruders. They communicate with each other in eerie whispers as they fight, out of habit. These foes fight to the death.

@UUID[Actor.0HCblqxsLXpcEJse]{Hermeticist's Worktable}: The hermeticists worktable contains expanded alchemists tools and a major serene mutagen.

B14. Ritual Chamber.text:
The large chamber has two parts. The narrower room to the east is square and has a few tables and workbenches around it. The spherical room to the west is studded with pinprick lights like distant stars. Chalk lines connect many of these stars together in constellations that defy ordinary geometry. Dividing the two halves of this room is an archway etched with eldritch symbols that glow with a cold light and emit a low moan, like wind blowing past the threshold of a partially opened door.

This two-part chamber is where the cult leader Foras has worked so tirelessly to bring Yog-Sothoth into the Material Plane to lay waste to it. Foras believes that, in doing so, he alone will be the chosen and only survivor that the terrible Yog-Sothoth will spare. The workbenches all contain various occult devices, small models, and slate boards containing astrological calculations. The chalk marks in the spherical area at the heart of the spiral are also his, but they are creations of his own wicked mind and dont follow any usual astronomical logic. Its impossible to tell from these materials how close Foras is to success, but the cold wind blowing from the rune indicates that Yog-Sothoths presence is indeed near.

  • @UUID[Actor.2mkfF43tP8IGVfBz]{Foras}
  • @UUID[Actor.z1Hk6z6RU4sF9aJU]{Disciples (4)}

Encounter

Severe 17

Foras is here, accompanied by four disciples who take measurements, transcribe notes, and otherwise assist Foras in his abstruse labor.

When confronted with intruders, Forass first action is to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.1dsahW4g1ggXtypx]{time stop}, then he moves into an advantageous tactical position behind his disciples to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.uEyfLoFQsRKBRIcB]{scintillating pattern}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.FmNDwqMEjeTEGPrY]{unfathomable song}, or other useful spells to impede the PCs. When time starts again, he Sustains these Spells or casts others to keep the PCs off balance. He doesnt mind catching his disciples in the area of his spells if it means hindering the PCs as well. As he fights, Foras shrieks about how his efforts to call Yog-Sothoth cannot be stopped and that the cosmic gate will soon open wide. Foras and his disciples fight to the death; if hes reduced to fewer than 20 hit points and no disciples yet live, Foras destroys his @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.6m9niDjhA6tBfp5x]{staff of power} to unleash a blast of energy.

@UUID[Actor.mxGasmiHaza9lkME]{Ritual Supplies}: One of the items on the worktable is a very realistic miniature gate with symbols like those found in this room. No larger than a human hand, the gate has a stone door that swings open and closed. This icon is worth 10 gp for its craftsmanship, but the PCs are likely to find it particularly useful if theyve learned about the Helix Theorem. The other materials on the worktable are mostly valueless tinkerings, despite the many long years that went into their creation. However, a vial containing a major cognitive mutagen lies amid the jumble.
B14. Ritual Chamber.name: B14. Ritual Chamber

A5. The Void Pit.name: A5. The Void Pit
A5. The Void Pit.text:
The corners of this simple square room look partially melted, giving the stone chamber a soft, rounded look. A small hole in the floor leads down to darkness, its edges caked with ice and flickering faint light shining from somewhere within. The rooms only door stands in the northeast wall.

The cultists once performed experiments and sacrifices requiring the void of deep space, so they created the Void Pit in this room to serve as a conduit for these rituals. Once the Spiral Seal was in place, the Void Pit became inert; this, plus the fact that it lies in an area held by the Pharasmins, has kept the cultists from attempting to retake the room.

@UUID[Actor.ZEpByav3dMCyvJJu]{Void Pit}

SIMPLE HAZARD 20

When the PCs remove the Spiral Seal, the Void Pit reactivates. The hole in the floor is a stone-lined well only 3 feet wide. The pits walls are slick with ice and can be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climbed} with a @Check[type:athletics|dc:35|traits:action:climb] check, but within it is supernaturally colda character takes [[/r 8d6[cold]]] damage (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:40|basic:true] save) at the start of any turn they begin in the pit. Theres no bottom to the pitafter dropping ten feet, it opens into the black void of outer space, and anyone who looks down into it views the night sky below. A faintly shimmering magical barrier at the bottom keeps air from leaking out into space. This barrier also stops anything thrown or dropped into the pit from being pulled through, but determined creatures can push through the barrierdoing so feels like pushing through a layer of thick tar as the sheet spreads around the creature and closes immediately behind them.

The Void Pit is a potentially dangerous hazard, but its also relatively safe as long as the PCs dont force their way through the barrier beyond. If it remains active, the Void Pit makes a great location to dispose of the gate icon (see area @UUID[.gzexduw0lqmG4q5r]{B14}), or any other dangerous item the PCs might wish to dispose of, for once an object is pulled through here into the depths of space, its lost for good, barring powerful magic to locate and retrieve it (a spell like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{wish} would work).

B4. Cold Praise.text:
This long room has two curving hallways exiting from the north and south walls of its western end and two steep stairways descending from the north and south walls of its eastern end. At the east end of the room, a rounded alcove shows ever-shifting shapes in a vibrant blue color.

The shapes in the east alcove are words in Aklo, constantly shifting and changing to form praises to Yog-Sothoth and aphorisms about the Outer Gods eventual return when the stars are right and the cosmic gate is opened. Anyone who enters this room must read aloud from the script or face a debilitating magical trap. The visitors from Leng who occupy areas @UUID[.oIZS4kHetJvOBuNq]{B5}@UUID[.YM5DVrfs7Hyb4fOJ]{B6} to the east dont bother on the occasions they pass through here since theyre immune to cold.

@UUID[Actor.oqlZNnsV8XMGn7JN]{Praise of Yog-Sothoth}

Severe 16

Any creature who spends more than 1 round in this room and doesnt read aloud one of the phrases in Aklo writhing above the alcove causes the trap to trigger.
B4. Cold Praise.name: B4. Cold Praise

KL5. The Mud Bowl.text:
• STANDARD

A wide pool of bubbling mud sits in a defile between the hills here. Large mounds of fungus and mushrooms thrive on the mud bowls banks, and in the noxious air, several of the fungi grow to heights of ten feet or more.

The mud is heated by geothermal activity, and although its not hot enough to cause damage, it does count as difficult terrain to those who wade through it. In addition, when a breathing creature enters the mud, they must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:17] save to avoid becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{sickened} 1, after which theyre temporarily immune to the noxious fumes for 24 hours regardless of their level of success on the saving throw. These vapors are an inhaled poison.

@UUID[Actor.yBglC9GBy6p1x87t]{Tendriculos}

Severe 6

Creature: One particularly huge mound of fungus and rank vegetation near the north shore of the mud bowl might be mistaken for a small hillock or moss-covered boulder but is in fact a carnivorous plant known as a tendriculos. The immense monster stands more than 20 feet high when it lurches into actionsomething it does as soon as it senses the approach of any living prey. The tendriculos attacks with its fibrous, vine-like tentacles or its immense maw, a tendril-rimmed hole capable of distending wide enough to swallow a human whole.

Treasure: The area immediately around the tendriculoss den supports a total of 18 full-grown black rattlecap mushrooms. These 8-inch-tall mushrooms have hollow caps filled with tiny hard balls of spores that, when shaken, make an unusual rattling sound. Each round of combat with the tendriculos that occurs within 20 feet of its starting point, [[/gmroll 1d4 - 1]] of these mushrooms are crushed into useless paste; those that survive can be harvested for the Old Beldame (as detailed in area @UUID[.kB6Hr2406re5HjuL]{TW7}).
KL5. The Mud Bowl.name: KL5. The Mud Bowl

TW6. The Hateful Hermit.name: TW6. The Hateful Hermit
TW6. The Hateful Hermit.text:
• STANDARD

Creatures

  • @UUID[Actor.k9eR5UwCSrfpPPAv]{Hateful Hermit}
  • @UUID[Actor.wqPYzMNgYvrO6oEP]{Puma}

Encounter

Severe 3

Creatures: The younger brother of the hermit Bokken (area @UUID[.NSCPFMAAUkbqCpsv]{RL2}) makes his home in this area in a huge, hollow oak tree. Even more reclusive than his brother, this misanthrope long ago forgot his own name and has grown progressively crueler and more dangerous over the years. He spends his time muttering to himself or talking to the pet puma he caught and trained years ago, which he calls simply Cat. When his cruel urges becomes too strong to ignore, the hateful hermit waylays one of the southern Greenbelts infrequent travelers, as he finds that the act of murder calms his nerves for a time. But they always come backboth the nerves and those pesky travelerswith each victim sating his need for violence less and less effectively.

It has been weeks since his last murder, and as a result, the hateful hermit is in a bad temper and eagerly looking for a fresh victim to sate his growing bloodlust. Unless the PCs are being particularly stealthy, the hermit quickly notices them and decides to waylay them. He prefers to attack with surprise, so if he cant set up a good ambush, he poses as a friendly, harmless druid seeking balance and peace in nature while he waits for the right moment to stab one of the PCs in the back. If reduced to 10 Hit Points or less, the hermit tries to flee and later plot his revengeeven going as far as to infiltrate the PCs growing city to strike back at them. Cat fights at the hermits side until reduced to fewer than 15 Hit Points, at which point the pumas training breaks and it flees into the wilds, abandoning the hateful hermit.

@UUID[Actor.8iftTBjFgjK3A3mm]{Hollow Oak Tree Treasure}: The hollow oak tree contains next to nothing of value: a few pieces of crude furniture, a wooden bowl and spoon, and a pile of dried leaves for a bed. The hateful hermit keeps his few treasures in a chest tucked into in a hole under his bed of leaves, which can be discovered by succeeding at a @Check[type:perception|dc:15] check. The chest contains a lesser healing potion, an invisibility potion, 64 cp, and a tarnished silver locket holding a faded portrait of a young woman (worth 5 gp) wrapped in a piece of cloth. This locket depicts the hermit and Bokkens long-dead motherBokken will pay up to 10 gp (or 100 gp in potions) for its return. The cloth itself is a faded map of the region that might just point the way toward a great treasure (see the Tomb Treasure section below).

Tomb Treasure

  • 30 XP

The PCs gain an intriguing treasure map. A few minutes spent deciphering the scrawls and faded shapes on this map are enough to recognize that the map seems to point the way to a hidden burial cairn somewhere between the Gudrin and Shrike rivers, due east of the northern shores of the Tuskwater. A magic flaming weapon is said to be hidden within this tomb, although the map vaguely warns of traps and an undead guardian who stole out of the tomb once before to reclaim the magic weapon. Following this map leads the PCs directly to the Lonely Barrow (area @UUID[.0KcdmwGleIUTokCO]{TW5}).

Source: Treasure map found in the hateful hermits den; alternately, you can allow the PCs to find the treasure map as part of any treasure stash in Kingmaker

Completion: The PCs find the Lonely Barrow, defeat its guardian, and claim its treasure.

Reward: Adjust the type of weapon this treasure map promises to match the favored weapon of one of the PCs who doesnt currently have a magic weaponthe reward for this quest is that weapons recovery (see @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.QNGzI3iMW6A7J7n7]{C4. The Warriors Tomb}).

TW2. Endangered Expedition.name: TW2. Endangered Expedition
TW2. Endangered Expedition.text:
• STANDARD

This encounter can only occur once the PCs have defeated @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.70FiR5COVuuS28ZD]{the Stag Lord}. At your discretion, you can move the location of this encounter to any river hex the PCs havent traveled through yet.

The sound of unintelligible cursing echoes through the woods. Just visible through the trees, a small wagon sits mired in the middle of a swiftly flowing river as the waters threaten to overlap its sides. Two ponies hitched to the wagon flounder and thrash in the swirling waters, close to panicking. Two more wagons sit safely on the far bank.

  • @UUID[Actor.KqWZZBucIAA1MzjF]{Jubilost Narthropple}
  • @UUID[Actor.cECpsCyJHXcQFMq2]{9 Gnome Explorers}

Creatures

Moderate 5

A group of gnome explorers has been surveying and mapping the Stolen Lands, looking for evidence of First World influences in the region. Theyve chosen this site as a good place for their base camp, but while they were setting up their tents, a band of kobolds attacked the group. The gnomes managed to drive the kobolds off, but not before the kobolds caused a lot of damage and panicked two ponies that were still hitched to the gnomes supply wagon. The horses rushed into the water, and the wagon swiftly became lodged in the muddy river bed. The gnomes have been unable to get the wagon unstuck and now stand helplessly on the shore, watching as the powerful current threatens to wash the wagon, its cargo, and the ponies downstream.

The expedition is made up of nine gnome explorers under the leadership of the flamboyant Jubilost Narthropple, a wealthy gnome explorer, mapmaker, and raconteur. Narthropple stands atop a small hillock next to the river, his eye blackened, glasses missing and helmet askew from the fight with the kobolds, shouting out conflicting orders and growing more furious (and scared) with each passing round the wagon is in danger. While Jubilost is much too proud to ask the PCs for help, the other gnomes are not, and they call out for aid as soon as they see the PCs, as long as the PCs dont immediately appear to be bandits or worse.

If the PCs wish to help the gnomes, they have 6 rounds to act before the wagon is lost. Anyone helping must first @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.c8TGiZ48ygoSPofx]{Swim} (requiring a successful @Check[type:athletics|dc:15|traits:action:swim] check) to the stranded wagon, which is 15 feet offshore. Before it can be moved, the ponies must be unhitched and led to safety. Their harness has Hardness 4 and 16 HP (8 BT); its a two-action @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pvQ5rY2zrtPI614F]{Interact} activity to unhitch one pony. A PC can then attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.q9nbyIF0PEBqMtYe]{Command an Animal} (@Check[type:nature|dc:18] check) to send one of the distressed ponies to shore (anyone with the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.classfeatures.Item.d5BFFHXFJYKs5LXr]{Wild Empathy} ability can instead use Diplomacy to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.DCb62iCBrJXy0Ik6]{Request} that the pony move to shore). Once the ponies have been unhitched, a PC can push the wagon 5 feet toward the shore with a successful @Check[type:athletics|dc:20|traits:action:shove] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove} (up to four others can Aid on this check). If the PCs save the wagon and ponies, the gnomes cheer and invite the PCs to have a meal with them.

Narthropple has drawn up quite a collection of maps of the southern Greenbelt during his quest for encroaching energies and influences from the First World. The maps show the location of every Landmark site in zones 15, and they can contain up to five other encounter sites (Standard or Hidden) that you wish to direct the party toward. Jubilosts maps do not show the location of the Beasts lair (area @UUID[.89NaJI7jtOsnTr9K]{SH4}) or the site of the troll lair (area @UUID[.JA4V2iDJug2ZAaRo]{NM7}).

Jubilosts maps could be very useful to the PCs, but the eccentric gnome refuses to part with them unless he is first made helpful through Diplomacy; Jubilost is initially indifferent to the PCs, and making him helpful requires a successful @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:20] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.OX4fy22hQgUHDr0q]{Make an Impression}. He considers his maps important secrets, so it further requires a successful @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:24] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.DCb62iCBrJXy0Ik6]{Request} access to them, at which point he agrees to sell his maps for 10 gp per encounter site marked on the maps. If the PCs saved his wagon and ponies, he sells his maps for half that price. Alternately, if the PCs have discovered Hidden sites not on Jubilosts maps during their explorations, they can trade knowledge of those locations on a one-for-one basis for the locations of sites known to the gnome.

Companion: If youre using the Kingmaker Companion Guide, Jubilost Narthropple could become one of the PCs loyal companions; see that book for details on how to incorporate the explorer into your campaign.

Treasure: The expeditions wagons contain 200 gp worth of miscellaneous supplies and trade goods. Under no circumstances will Jubilost willingly give any of them away, although he may agree to sell some mundane supplies to the PCs at a 10-percent markup.

Reward: If the PCs help the expedition and acquire Jubilosts maps, grant them 30 XP.

Zone 1: Rostland Hinterlands.text:
This grassland wilderness sits just outside the border of Brevoy. While not technically part of the nation, its proximity to Brevoy and relative lack of valuable resources means that banditry is relatively light. South Rostland Road was built ages ago by eager engineers, but money eventually ran out, leaving the road to slowly degrade into little more than a glorified trail. To the north of area RL1, the road eventually loops back to Brevoy on a long, winding route until it reaches the east bank of the East Sellen River about 40 miles north of Wyvernstone Bridge (area @UUID[JournalEntry.GRbTr3VTyhezOEhW.JournalEntryPage.bG1yUiHIe8jQodWn]{HT1}).

Bandits: These bandits are not affiliated with @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.70FiR5COVuuS28ZD]{the Stag Lord}, but they have heard of him and hope to rob the PCs and use the wealth they steal to buy their way into his band.

Hunter: Encounters with a hunter use the stats for a @UUID[Actor.X1cSs1jhTtx1zTI4]{poacher}, but these hunters are neutral and relatively law-abiding. They can be an excellent source of rumors for the PCs, or can warn them about nearby dangers (such as the threat of crossing into a more dangerous zone). At your discretion, some hunter encounters can be with poachers who attack the PCs rather than risk having someone tell the authorities about their activities.

TW7. The Old Beldame.text:
• Resource
  • Standard

A dilapidated mud hut squats atop a small hummock in the middle of a fetid marsh, a thin tendril of bluish smoke trickling through a gaping hole in its moss-covered roof. A wooden fence surrounding the perimeter of the mound is festooned with crude fetishes crafted out of sticks, feathers, and animal bones. A lone crow caws noisily from the top of a nearby cypress tree.

Creatures

  • @UUID[Actor.sMCEMlNngFINMX8y]{Elga Verniex}
  • @UUID[Actor.EOiOqs1vHCxZAj3T]{Scarecrow}

Encounter

Severe 3

Creature: A small swamp on the west bank of the Tuskwater is the domain of a mysterious woman named Elga Verniex, known to travelers as the Old Beldame. As the PCs nation grows, many of their subjects begin to trade tales about her. Rumors spread that the old woman is a hag, and locals begin calling her the Swamp Witch, claiming (falsely) that she sold her soul to a demon or devil for malign powers. In reality, Elga Verniex isnt a witch at all, just a bitter old woman who likes her privacy, though her magical powers are legitimate.

Elga doesnt take kindly to visitors, and to help ensure her privacy, she has animated a pumpkin-headed scarecrow to guard her hut and drive away unwanted guests. Those who regularly come to her for assistance have long since learned to announce their presence before opening her gate.

The Old Beldames hut is a simple, one-room affair; its about 20 feet in diameter with a dirt floor and a thatched roof. The rafters are hung with dried herbs and swamp weeds, and a bubbling cauldron (containing nothing more sinister than a weak vegetable broth) hangs over a firepit in the center of the room. The region around the hut is an 80-foot-diameter area of solid ground, thick with bog grass and dotted with small, cattail-clogged pools. This area is surrounded by a waist-high wooden fence, in which a single gate hangs askew. A fist-sized, rusted iron bell hangs from a hairy length of rope tied to a crooked post next to the gate.

The scarecrow appears to be propped up midway between the gate and the door to the hutit lurches to life and swiftly moves to attack anyone crossing the line of the fence. The Old Beldame does not emerge from her hut, even if the PCs fight the scarecrow outside. She is somewhat hard of hearing anyway and trusts the scarecrow to take care of any troublesome intruders. She attacks only if the PCs make it past the scarecrow and enter her hut uninvited. She is initially unfriendly to PCs, but she is not evil-hearted, so successful @Check[type:diplomacy|dc:15|traits:action:make-an-impression] checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.OX4fy22hQgUHDr0q]{Make an Impression} may be able to defuse the situation before it turns violent.

The Old Beldame is human, although fey blood runs in her veinsover the years, her magical heritage has given her skin a strange greenish cast and lengthened her ears to points, further fuel for the locals rumormongering. Should the PCs wish to talk to Elga instead of fighting her, theyd do well to announce themselves by striking the bell on the pole next to the gate before they annoy the scarecrow. The Old Beldame peers out of a window of her hut and angrily demands to know who the PCs are. Initial diplomatic contact must be carried out at this somewhat awkward distance, for if the PCs enter her fenced-in area, she shrieks, ducks into her hut, and lets the scarecrow handle the defense of her domain. If she is made friendly or helpful to the PCs, she invites them into her hut to chat. If she invites the PCs inside, the scarecrow doesnt attack, though it does turn its head to watch them menacingly as they pass by.

During an extended conversation with the Old Beldame, the PCs find her to be knowledgeable, though crotchety and ill-tempered. She can warn them about the dangers of the hateful hermit to the west (area @UUID[.XVAPsU3tc3i5rS2j]{TW6}), setting foot on Candlemere (area @UUID[.fraqnPjBmnq2ToHs]{KL4)}, the lizardfolk village just west of Candlemere (area @UUID[.dqCbC2C5XlKMdbrm]{KL3}), and the Lonely Barrow to the east (area @UUID[.0KcdmwGleIUTokCO]{TW5}). She can be convinced to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.rmwa3OyhTZ2i2AHl]{Craft} magical items or provide spellcasting for the PCs at standard prices, and if shes impressed with the PCs, shell even hire them to do her a favor (detailed in the Black Rattlecaps section below).

@UUID[Actor.M5taHH2tfvxycf2T]{Small Metal Box}: A small metal box hidden under the Old Beldames bed (@Check[type:perception|dc:15|traits:action:search] while Searching to find) contains 21 cp, 31 sp, 38 gp, and 9 pp. Under the layer of coins is a scroll of scrying and instructions for a legend lore ritual that Elga hopes to one day learn.

Resource: If the PCs ally with the Old Beldame then establish a settlement here, she and her hut grant the settlement a free herbalist structure.

Black Rattlecaps

  • 30 XP

The PCs are tasked with gathering a batch of black rattlecap mushrooms from a dangerous mud pit. The Old Beldame uses the spores from these very rare mushrooms to brew a potent tea. She sends the PCs to the Mud Bowl (area @UUID[.WZB1k6alpwK5lu24]{KL5}) to gather as many of the mushrooms as they can for her.

Source: The Old Beldame

Completion: After defeating the hideous guardian of the Mud Bowl, the PCs can harvest several black rattlecaps. The Old Beldame wants as many as the PCs can find for her.

Reward: The Old Beldame promises a payment of 5 gp for each black rattlecap the PCs bring her.
TW7. The Old Beldame.name: TW7. The Old Beldame

RL6. Dead Noble.name: RL6. Dead Noble
RL6. Dead Noble.text:
• Secret

This hex contains nothing of interest until the PCs are approached by Edrist Hanvaki after they establish their kingdom. Edrists concerns about his vanished sibling Temin are presented in the quest for "@UUID[JournalEntry.OnxXPMl0iaK9lUp1.JournalEntryPage.j8TeGFWUJIA8E5yp]{A Missing Brother}." Once this quest is active, poor doomed Temin can be found in this hex.

Any time after the quest becomes active, allow each PC who enters this hex to attempt a @Check[type:hills-lore|dc:13|traits:action:recall-knowledge], @Check[type:hunting-lore|dc:13|traits:action:recall-knowledge], @Check[type:nature|dc:13], or @Check[type:survival|dc:13] check or a @Check[type:perception|dc:17] check to note and understand the presence of buzzards wheeling in the sky. Any success allows the party to discover Temin Hanvakis body, sprawled dead in a shallow gulch in the foothills here. Temin had hoped to make it to Varnhold to seal a business deal with that villages gem cutter, but in his haste to make good time, he slipped and fell into this gulch, breaking his neck in the process.

@UUID[Item.gvJfV47gcA971U8h]: Temins corpse still wears a mother-of-pearl brooch worth 10 gp; its this brooch that Edrist seeks. No other valuables can be found here.

KL6. A Cry for Help.text:
• STANDARD

@UUID[Actor.T3low0wQNMO0SEtr]{leucrottas}

Severe 4

Creatures: A pair of cruel leucrottas roam this craggy section of the Kamelands, scouting an old trail that crosses a narrow creek. The leucrottas are allied with the troll @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.mcnuxpRVYOo6gRYn]{Hargulka} (detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.36YItDu6VgX6IRWV]{Chapter 4}) and are looking for territory he can add to his kingdom. If they notice the PCs, the leucrottas use their talent at voice mimicry to sound like a pair of humans in distress. You can use the @UUID[Scene.GriPsZInGkgPH9Q6]{Creek} scene for this encounter.

If the PCs defeat one of the leucrottas and reduce the other to 20 Hit Points or fewer, the survivor attempts to surrender. If its life is spared, it admits that they were both looking to earn the favor of King @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.mcnuxpRVYOo6gRYn]{Hargulka} and warns the PCs that the troll king is going to rule these lands very soontheyd best do what they can to prepare their own offerings to King Hargulka, so that when he demands their obedience, he wont be annoyed with them. The leucrottas know the troll king and his minions dwell in the woods of the southern Narlmarches, but arent sure where.
KL6. A Cry for Help.name: KL6. A Cry for Help

NM2. Statue of Erastil.name: NM2. Statue of Erastil
NM2. Statue of Erastil.text:
• RESOURCE
  • STANDARD

A fifteen-foot-tall statue of Erastil stands a silent vigil here, partially overgrown at the base but towering above the surrounding shrubbery.

Once a stony sentinel standing before a hunters lodge, this statue is all that remains after a fire and centuries of growth obliterated the building itself. Yet despite years of neglect, the site remains sacred to the god of the hunt, for the priest who built it was particularly favored among the Taldan explorers. A worshipper of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.mm1j6UbHqFCI8fwB]{Erastil} feels safe and at peace within 60 feet of this statue, and no wild animals will approach within that range; any wandering monster rolls that would result in a wild animal encounter in this area should be treated as no encounter, making this an excellent site for a camp.

If the statue is cleaned and a worshipper of Erastil prays before it, the god of the hunt takes note and grants that creature a minor boon: whenever that creature critically fails a Survival check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.49y9Ec4bDii8pcD3]{Subsist} in the wild, they gets a failure instead. Further cleanings and prayer do not cause a repeat of this one-time blessing.

Resource: If a settlement is built here, the statue grants a free Monument.

GB11. Boggard Lair.text:
• Resource
  • Standard

The ground slumps into a soggy mire, and a pair of ruined stone buildings jut from the ground. This location is presented on the @UUID[Scene.DEn6KiaBL6TrKnYv]{Swamp Village} map.

Creatures

Moderate 2

These buildings have been claimed by a lone @UUID[Actor.JkBJ8B07ElXrfDaG]{boggard} named Garuum and his monstrous, froglike pet, a slurk called @UUID[Actor.GxuhqOHUoVbZUTNT]{Ubagub}. Garuum was once a member of the boggard settlement @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{Mbotuu} to the west (area @UUID[JournalEntry.GRbTr3VTyhezOEhW.JournalEntryPage.F2jziCo01RR37QUd]{HT6}) until he made a terrible mistake of believing he should be the one to rule the knot (another name for a boggard village). In order to prepare for his coup, he gathered and devoured several dozen of the knots sacred blue dragonflies, hoping to gain great power and skill from the insects. Alas, while the feast bolstered his self-confidence, it did nothing for his battle skills. He rode his slurk Ubagub into the center of Mbotuu to declare war, whereupon he was immediately captured. @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.GM5bmf3HiUN2tBP4]{Mbotuu}s ruler, @UUID[Actor.sedubjznhIbVfCkD]{Sepoko}, sentenced Garuum and his slurk to death after a day of humiliating punishment.

Fortunately, Garuums captors forgot about him after getting drunk on bog whiskey. Later, he used a rock to smash his manacles and escape. He freed his slurk and fled eastward into the Narlmarches. Following his escape, the priest-king branded Garuum an exile and demanded that he be slain on sight should he ever return.

Garuum knows his previous life is over and has made do as best he can. He moved into this ruined village and thinks of the two ruined buildings within as his empire. Garuum sleeps in a nest made of swamp reeds, soggy planks, and mud in the ruins of the smaller buildings tower. Neither he nor Ubagub react kindly to intruders, each croaking loudly to alert the other. Yet Garuum has learned from his past mistakesnow he moderates his violent impulses. He even knows several words of Common.

As soon as he sees the PCs (and assuming they dont immediately attack him or Ubagub), Garuum holds up his hands and croaks out, Truce! Truce! Garuum just wants to be left alone, but his limited knowledge of Common (the only words he knows are boggard, bug, slurk, snake, truce, hungry, me, you, die, and go) might make communication difficult. Garuum is quick to interpret attempts to search his kingdom or simply to walk through it as offensive acts, and attacks.

If the PCs establish a line of communication with the boggard, he tells them his story and that he doesnt want to cause problems; if the PCs leave him be, hell reciprocate. In fact, hes willing to tell the characters what he knows of the nearby woods in return for them leaving him alone. He can tell them about the statue of Erastil in area @UUID[.FaEGQyzM1OWCNePT]{NM2}, the location of the @UUID[Scene.baSxEegtGfsoihWN]{Temple of the Elk} at area @UUID[.ZyMSUFOBkSXlRhmM]{GB6}, where Tuskgutter lives at area @UUID[.x20Bq8Uu3Lgo0QIM]{GB12}, and of the tatzlwyrms living at area @UUID[.TUUvCrADHplbc1pa]{GB16}. At your discretion, if the characters treat Garuum particularly well, he might offer to let them rest in his domain (an uncomfortable but safe place to sleep) or even accompany them on their adventures.

@UUID[Actor.oVp0y7XJDPK0j2A3]{Garuum's Treasure}: Garuum has gathered a small hoard of treasure. It consists of 21 gp, a chunk of iolite worth 5 gp, a deep green spinel worth 9 gp, and a shard of blue quartz worth 11 gp.

Resource: If the PCs defeat or befriend Garuum, this hex functions as a Refuge if it is Claimed. If a Settlement is built here, the buildings can be rebuilt into Houses.

Award: If the PCs befriend Garuum, award them experience as if they had defeated him and his slurk in combat.

Garuums Revenge

  • 30 xp

If the PCs befriend Garuum and he still lives once they reach 10th level, the boggard finally approaches them with a request. Since he was exiled from Mbotuu, his festering anger has finally reached a boiling point. He claims to have found a magic rock and promises to give it to whoever can travel to Mbotuu, kill its priest-king Sepoko, and return to Garuum with Sepokos head so he can feed it to Ubagub.

Source: Garuum

Completion: Kill Sepoko and bring his head back to Garuum.

Reward: Garuums magic rock is in fact a greater invisibility armor runestone.
GB11. Boggard Lair.name: GB11. Boggard Lair

KL8. Hunting Grounds.text:
• STANDARD

This region is particularly infested with dangerous monstersa perfect place for a hunt! If the PCs explore this hex before @UUID[JournalEntry.Kmwzfr7NS9r9Vhb0]{Chapter 5} begins, theyll automatically encounter a wandering monster here. Later, additional dangers can be encountered heresee @UUID[JournalEntry.Kmwzfr7NS9r9Vhb0.JournalEntryPage.yTJR4dc9eSM3RkZ5]{Part 2} of Chapter 5 for more details.
KL8. Hunting Grounds.name: KL8. Hunting Grounds

TW1. A Delicate Situation.name: TW1. A Delicate Situation
TW1. A Delicate Situation.text:
• STANDARD

This encounter doesnt take place until the PCs have driven off @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.70FiR5COVuuS28ZD]{the Stag Lord}if they explore this hex before then, they could encounter the nixie Melianse, but its more likely that she remains in hiding and simply watches the PCs pass by. After defeating the Stag Lord, if the PCs had already explored this hex, you should consider having them hear rumors about the freelance loggers having problems here shortly after establishing their kingdom in Chapter 5 to lure them back to this hex to deal with the situation.

Use the @UUID[Scene.RFsr7Wh4lgTft3Dj]{Forest Pond} map to run this encounter.

The river makes a sharp bend here, widening into a deep pool dotted with lily pads and fringed by waving reeds. Three freshly felled trees lie beside their stumps on the shore of the pool, their crowns dangling in the water among fading tendrils of mist.

Creatures

  • @UUID[Actor.48o307dry03xazvd]{Corax}
  • @UUID[Actor.RTd4FwqGq8gBjdAO]{Melianse}
  • @UUID[Actor.UAlHSl6Cpujld1dx]{6 loggers (Corax)}
  • @UUID[Actor.UAlHSl6Cpujld1dx]{2 loggers (Melianse)}

Encounter

Severe 3

Creatures: A band of freelance loggers under the leadership of a man named Corax recently decided to harvest a grove of coachwood trees in this glade, unaware the nixie sorcerer dwelling in a nearby pool. The nixie, @UUID[Actor.RTd4FwqGq8gBjdAO]{Melianse}, did not take kindly to the loggers despoiling her home and unsuccessfully attempted to scare them off with ample use of @UUID[Actor.RTd4FwqGq8gBjdAO.Item.5kg7JjXt6IFWf6Wf]{ghost sound} and @UUID[Actor.RTd4FwqGq8gBjdAO.Item.veuImnnlVr4xjZzt]{obscuring mist}. When that tactic failed, Melianse took the time to inveigle one of the lumberjacks, and then another, and both now stand guard in front of her pool. Since both are good workers, @UUID[Actor.48o307dry03xazvd]{Corax} has resisted the urge to fight his own employees, but he is fast losing patience with the nixie and fears the blow to his reputation in his workers eyes if he dithers much longer. The two groups are now in a standoff, with neither willing to make the next move.

When the PCs arrive on the scene, Corax and six of his eight @UUID[Actor.UAlHSl6Cpujld1dx]{loggers} stand angrily near the felled trees, about 30 feet from the pool. The other two lumberjacks stand at the waters edge, facing Corax. Melianse floats in the center of the pool with only her head above water; she remains about 20 feet from the shore, out of the loggers reach, and silently observes their response.

As soon as Corax notices the PCs, he sees them as potential allies. He quickly hails them and explains the situation in a gruff voice liberally laced with profanity, claiming that the nixie attacked his workers unprovoked and complaining bitterly about how hard it is for a decent man to make a living with all these damnable fairies in the woods. Melianse responds calmly to this accusation, claiming that she politely asked the loggers to leave at first but was forced to enchant two of them after Corax threatened to hang her from the nearest tree to drip dry. She adds that the trees felled by the loggers had been growing next to the pool for more than 200 years and deserved a far better fate than serving as some grubby peasants slop table. Both Corax and Melianse appeal to the PCs for help. The conversation soon devolves into more accusations and shouted insults.

Unless action is taken by the PCs to defuse the situation, Corax eventually loses patience and orders his six unaffected lumberjacks to subdue their entranced colleagues and attack the nixie. Melianse responds by ordering the inveigled loggers to defend her pool while she targets Corax with her spells. If the PCs ally with Corax, Melianse focuses her magic on them. If the PCs ally with Melianse, Corax orders three loggers to focus on Melianse while he and the other three fight the PCs. Corax surrenders if reduced to 10 or fewer Hit Points, vowing to practice his trade someplace where the damned fairies dont run the show! Melianse fights to the death to defend her home.

If the PCs want to defuse the situation, they must negotiate an accord between the two parties. First, Corax and Melianse, both of whom are quite angry, must be calmed down and convinced to talk. Diplomacy or Intimidation checks might work (both Corax and Melianse are unfriendly to the PCs at the start of the encounter), or spells such as charm or calm emotions can be used (although if they fail, both sides might be spurred to attack the PCs). Once the two agree to negotiate, both must be satisfied with the result. Corax wants his lumber and demands that Melianse release his two workers from her influence. Melianse wants the loggers to leave her glade and provide reparation for the trees theyve already felled.

Obviously, there is no single correct answer to appease everyone; reward players who come up with creative solutions as long as both groups get something out of the negotiations. (One possible solution is to provide the loggers with another source of lumber; a PC who succeeds at a @Check[type:nature|dc:18] or Forest Lore check recalls an untouched grove of coachwood trees 10 miles to the north, near the old tatzlwyrm den, that the lumberjacks can freely harvest if shown the way to the grove.) For her part, Melianse releases the two entranced loggers if the group leaves and replaces the three trees theyve cut down (as detailed in the quest Melianses Trees below).

Melianses Trees

  • 30 XP

The PCs must replace three trees that have been cut down in the prime of their lives. Melianse doesnt care how the PCs replace the three trees, nor does she care what kind of trees they replace the felled ones with. She simply wants three new trees planted in her glade to help restore her home.

Source: Melianse (area TW1)

Completion: The easiest solution to this quest involves gathering three tree feather tokens and placing them near the three felled trees. If the PCs dont think of this, the nixie can suggest it, recommending they contact the dryad Tiressia to the northwest (area @UUID[.bLxVZCuHjKPssNXv]{KL1}). Melianse knows the dryad has a few of these feather tokens but suspects Tiressia will want a favor before handing over the tokens (Melianse doesnt know about @UUID[.bLxVZCuHjKPssNXv]{the scythe tree problem} facing the dryad). Alternatively, the PCs could buy three of these feather tokens from a merchant in a city.

Reward: Not only does Melianse agree to release the two inveigled lumberjacks from her control, she also agrees to teach the PCs the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5pwK2FZX6QwgtfqX]{inveigle} ritual if they wish. Once the PCs establish their kingdom, Melianse agrees to keep an eye out along the Greenbelts rivers for any trouble or rumors of danger, and to spread word of the PCs reasonable nature to other fey. As long as the PCs dont build a settlement or Work Site in this hex, they gain a +2 circumstance bonus to all checks made to resolve Hex or Settlement events in this zone.

GB18. Fangberry Thicket.text:
• STANDARD

A patch of raspberry-like fruits known as fangberries grows in a valley between two low hills here. Much of the thorny thicket is draped in the white gossamer silk of spiderwebs. The best of the berries lie at the heart of the thicket, but harvesting must be done slowly to avoid being lacerated by the thousands of fangberry thorns. To gather a basket of fangberriesenough for a meal, or to satisfy Bokkens need for them (completing @UUID[.NSCPFMAAUkbqCpsv]{Gathering Fangberries}), a PC must perform the Gather Fangberries activity after the thickets denizens have been dealt with. The thicket itself is difficult terrain. A creature who moves through the thicket in a reckless manner (by making a Strike or taking more than one Stride during their turn) takes 1 piercing damage from the thickets thorns at the end of their turn.

Creatures

@UUID[Actor.1upVC05DY7YzxNsr]{2 Chew Spiders}

@UUID[Actor.1upVC05DY7YzxNsr]{chew spiders}

Moderate 2

The webs that infest the thicket were spun by swarms of @UUID[Actor.1upVC05DY7YzxNsr]{chew spiders}a species of aggressive arachnids the size of a humans thumb with particularly large, serrated fangs. Two swarms dwell in the thicket, and they attack intruders as soon as anyone starts to gather fangberries, rolling Stealth for initiative.

Gather Fangberries

  • Exploration
  • manipulate
  • move

Attempting to gather enough fangberries for a meal or for Bokken requires 10 minutes of work and a successful DC 18 Survival check. Creatures wearing medium armor gain a +2 item bonus on this check, while those in heavy armor treat their results as one degree of success higher than the actual result. Anyone with the Woodland Stride ability or a similar effect automatically earns a critical success.

  • Critical Success: The character gathers a full basket of ripe berries and takes no damage.

  • Success: The character gathers a basket of ripe berries but takes 1d6 piercing damage from the thorns.

  • Failure: The character gathers half a basket of berries but takes 1d6 piercing damage and 1d6 persistent bleed damage from the thorns.

  • Critical Failure: As failure, but the character fails to gather any berries and becomes clumsy 1 from the pain. This clumsy condition lasts until the character receives any healing.
GB18. Fangberry Thicket.name: GB18. Fangberry Thicket

GB16. Tatzlwyrm Den.text:
• STANDARD

Islets create a ford across this section of the Skunk River, two of them connected by rubble and log jams. The islands make for a natural choke point, but also serve as a nest for a pair of mated tatzlwyrms. You can use the @UUID[Scene.YoMcZ0NVRai2VbX7]{Tatzlwyrm Den} for this encounter.

@UUID[Actor.UnWr8QSMq2VZUQhX]{1-2 tatzlwyrms}

Moderate 2

One of the tatzlwyrms spends most of its time coiled leisurely upon the central island, sunning itself, while the other generally remains hidden in the rubble, sleeping or digesting a meal. The first time the PCs explore this hex, roll a @Check[type:flat|dc:11]. On a failure, one of the tatzlwyrms is out huntingotherwise, the PCs face both creatures and anger them into battle by their mere presence in their territory.

@UUID[Actor.lbeZCSFNo051BAOX]{Skeletal Remains}: The skeletal remains of a long-dead explorer makes up the tatzlwyrms meager horde. A successful @Check[type:perception|dc:12] check is all a character needs to spot the skeleton wedged in the debris of the tatzlwyrms nest. The skeleton wears a suit of ruined scale mail and clutches a +1 cold iron longsword in one bony hand. On a critical success on the Perception check, or if a PC specifically digs through the mud and rubble under the skeleton, additional treasure is revealed in the form of a rotting leather backpack that contains 12 gp, 62 sp, a pewter drinking stein worth 2 gp, a silver ring worth 7 gp, a jade carving of a female elf worth 11 gp, and a watertight scroll tube that contains a map.

The explorer had been working to create a map of the northwest corner of the Greenbelt, so the PCs can use it to help with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Ba9EuLV1I2b1ue9P]{Map the Area} individual hexploration activities of any hex in Rostland or the Greenbelt; doing so grants a +2 item bonus to Survival checks made to Map the Area.
GB16. Tatzlwyrm Den.name: GB16. Tatzlwyrm Den

KL3. Lair of the Lizard King.text:
• Landmark
  • Resource

This area is detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.9PIQlzot3RTQio8U.JournalEntryPage.mKdVQkTwjei6oLPc]{Isle of the Lizard King}.

Resource: The lizardfolk who dwell here function as a Freehold. If the PCs bring this Freehold into their kingdom, they automatically gain a village settlement that contains the following free structures: Barracks, Houses, Shrine, and Wooden Walls; its four Urban Grid borders are also all Water borders.
KL3. Lair of the Lizard King.name: KL3. Lair of the Lizard King

RL2. Bokkens Hut.text:
• Standard
  • Resource

Gathering Fangberries

  • 30 XP

Bokken sure knows how to make delicious potions. His secret to deliciousness is fangberry juice, but hes running low on these supplies. A large thicket of fangberries grows about 55 miles southwest of @UUID[JournalEntry.AgbaF8i9XDLEtxqe.JournalEntryPage.fTB6r42OJIsE5Y3e]{Olegs Trading Post}, and he needs someone canny and strong to fetch them for him. (Helpful PCs may want to ensure the berries they give him arent dirty; Bokken wont bother washing them before he uses them.)

Source: Bokken (area RL2)

Completion: Bring Bokken a full basket of berriesenough to make fangberry juice for seven potions.

Reward: Bokken gives the PCs a 25-percent discount on his potions for 1 month. Alternately, hell give them any three potions he currently has in stock for free.

Although the Greenbelt is far from safe, the seclusion promised is too much to resist for some, including eccentric potion-maker Bokken (CN male human alchemist 4). With a manner like a nervous bird or a jittery child, Bokkens speech is swift and clipped, as if hes eager to finish every conversation he starts. Yet Bokken is no hater of gold, and his eagerness to sell his potions is well known to many travelers in the areahe usually sells directly to Oleg, but hes willing to sell to the PCs if they ask. He generally keeps two @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.2RuepCemJhrpKKao]{minor healing potion}s, two lesser @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.e0vSAQfxhHauiAoD]{lesser healing potions}, a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.G7haQ5gDt30ftJLC]{moderate healing potion}, a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.bDnk4TSzvD5BQmE5]{lesser potion of fire resistance}, and a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.mRs24OwmGPjoIDvO]{lesser potion of cold resistance} handy.

In any extended conversation with Bokken, hes likely to mention his younger brother, Kurmil. Bokken spits and curses a fair amount as he does so, bitterly holding up his right hand and indicating his missing pinkie finger. Bastard cut that offa me the last time he hit my mother, Desna rest her soul. But he took off right after to live in a hollow tree down south rather than face the guards, so I guess it all worked out well enough. Bokken decided to become a hermit a few years after his brother left home and their parents passed away. Originally, Bokken had toyed with the idea of tracking down his brother and getting revenge, but the wildlife in the Greenbelt was too frightening and dangerous, so he instead settled down not far from the edge of Rostland to live the rest of his life in nature.

Resources: If a settlement is built here, Bokkens Hut grants that settlement a free Alchemy Laboratory.
RL2. Bokkens Hut.name: RL2. Bokkens Hut

The first time they arrive here, theyll find @UUID[JournalEntry.PoopszF8pbV8RtX8.JournalEntryPage.wF0M7MjVsD1F2v0E]{Oleg and Svetlana Leveton} worrying about an imminent visit from bandits; @UUID[JournalEntry.AgbaF8i9XDLEtxqe.JournalEntryPage.tW1I3M4wNJlV4RAr]{Part 1: Trouble at Oleg's} provides more details on this initial encounter, and @UUID[JournalEntry.AgbaF8i9XDLEtxqe.JournalEntryPage.QLSVaG3lMK58DM2l]{Settling In at Olegs} details some of the services and information that the players can benefit from when they return to the Trading Post.

RL5. Fort Serenko.name: RL5. Fort Serenko
RL5. Fort Serenko.text:
• Resource
  • Standard

This wooden fortification has stood for years on the southern border of Brevoy, but with the growing tensions between Rostland and Issia, the soldiers and scouts stationed here have been recalled to Restov. The fort itself is empty, with any examination revealing evidence that it was abandoned in a swift but orderly manner.

Resource: The empty fort functions as a @UUID[JournalEntry.BIu4C1T1RR17QNwl.JournalEntryPage.IVR7vGeMPHkp5KoE]{Structure} terrain feature if the PCs Claim this Hex as part of their kingdom. The fort is rather small, but functions as a Barracks in a settlement established in this hex.

The sites proximity to Brevoy, though, brings with it an extra complication, as Rostland considers it part of their nations holdings. If the PCs dont secure diplomatic relations with Rostland before attempting to incorporate Fort Serenko into one of their settlements as a Barracks, Rostlands @UUID[JournalEntry.ufhwExwde2g3iEa7.JournalEntryPage.eATwgXlHtXmEU16S]{Negotiation DC} increases to 20, as its nobles consider the PCs move to be crass and a bit aggressive from a political standpoint.
